description:
My friend wanted to get some Ethiopian food. We heard this place was pretty good, so we decided to check it out. And boy am I glad we did.

I've been here three times, and each time I get the gored gored. I always want to try something new, but the gored gored tastes so good that I can't resist ordering it. When the food arrives at the table, the aroma is just amazing. I feel like I can smell it just by writing this review.

Ah I'm making myself hungry. I should come back again and maybe I'll actually try something new this time.
author: Daniel N.

description:
One word: Honeywine

that wind is bomb af!
I also like how you must eat here with your hands, utensils unavailable.

make sure to come hungry!
author: Jray M.

description:
Great food at really affordable prices, don't not find that much these days in SF but New Eritrea got you covered!

I came here with a girl friend and we shared the meat combo and the veggie combo. We completely cleaned the plate. The veggie combo had four items, collar greens, yellow lentils, red lentils, and potatoes/cabbage. The meat combo had one lamb, one beef and one chicken. 

Everything was really good, I didn't even have a favorite! We also got a side of the cheese and yogurt. The cheese was light and so fresh tasting. 

I will probably be ordering takeout from this place since it's available. Yum yum!!
author: Alice W.

description: Still my favorite restaurant in SF. Kind, friendly staff and wonderful food. Relaxed environment and ALWAYS delicious food. So appreciative of this gem and always leave happy!
author: M M.

description:
My friend and I were craving Ethiopian food, and decided to drop by at New Eritrea! The space was pretty big, but the best part was the back of the restaurant where they had a sun roof. Since it was a sunny day, the lighting was so nice :) Initially, there were a number of fruit flies where we sat, and so we asked to be moved as the flies just didn't seem to want to go away from us. 

The food was so-so. We split a meat combo of chicken, lamb, and beef. It wasn't tender at all, so wasn't too tasty. But I did enjoy the vegetarian combo we added, which was tumtumo, hamli, and alicha. Tumtumo is made up of lentil beans puréed ,& simmered with Eritrean spices, onions & herbs. The hamli is made up of collard green and spinach, and the alicha has seasoned mixture of potatoes, carrots, cabbage, garlic and ginger. I really enjoyed the hamli and alicha! The portions weren't super big, so we ordered another dish :P what can we say..we were hungry haha. We added the kilwa, which is tender beef sautéed in butter with tomatoes, onions, garlic Eritrean spices. This dish was much better than the meat combo.

The service was also really great! Our server was quick to move us because of the fruit flies, and super kind. Overall, great service, but I think there's better Ethiopian restaurants in the city of SF I would rather try next time.
author: Jackie C.

description: Efficient service, great food, relaxed ambiance, nice selection of beer and wine - I had the Ethiopian Walia Lager, and it went well with the combo vegetarian/meat combo platter I shared.  Will definitely come back!
author: Roger E.

description:
I shuffled in after work on a Sunday evening and to my dismay, the place was packed. I'm usually pretty tired after a long work day and the last thing I need is someone catching me lookin' drained. My growling stomach got the best of me and I decided to take a seat and grub anyway. 

When you enter, it's a bit tricky. I must've stood at the door searching for the hostess podium for a good few seconds until I realized that it was actually past the long bar, about halfway into the restaurant. I was then quickly greeted and seated to a cozy little nook. 

My order:

Meat Combination - Zigni Beef simmered in red sauce with authentic Eritrean spices, Zebhi Dorho Chicken Drumstick marinated and simmered in onions, tomatoes, clarified butter, and red pepper sauce, and also Alicha Begee Lamb cooked in mild tumeric sauce with onions and garlic. Coupled with a side salad and injera, OMG, this dish was incredible. So flavorful and comforting. 

New Eritrean Special - Tenderized boneless chicken mixed with mushrooms, onions, tomatoes, garlic, and spices. This was probably my favorite of the night. Delicious!

Stuffed Jalapeños - No no, not like the ones at Jack in the Box, but even better IMHO. Loaded with tomatoes, onions, and a bit of olive oil, these unassuming jalapeño bites elevated my overall dish experience to the max. Fresh and crunchy and not at all as spicy as you would think; then again I do enjoy spicy. They do a good job cleaning out the seeds and membrane to avoid steam coming out of your ears. 

Service is incredibly friendly and helpful. I also like how they set the whole bottle of water at your table so you can fill up your glass as needed. I drink tons of water, so this was perfect. 

Great casual spot! I'll definitely be back!
author: Ann S.

description:
This place is so yummy! It's the first time we've tried Ethiopian food. The decor was very nice. We got the veggie sampler platter and the lamb. They just put the lamb with the veggie platter. So there's this very tender and soft sour bread under the mashed up veggies and lamb. They also give us baskets of the bread. 

The veggie platter includes okra, greens, carrots, potatoes, and something else. Some of them were spicy. The lamb was delicious with tomato flavor. So you use the bread to grab some of the food. So the bread is like a spoon. The bread is so warm, airy, and soft, yummy! 

The service was good and there are bathrooms. Overall, it was yummy!
author: Amanda L.

description: My favorite restaurant in sf. Best kitfo I've ever had and the service is amazing. Love love love this place
author: Chaeyon L.

description:
My friends and I hadn't been planning to eat here, but we're so glad we did! 

First, I need to establish that this was the first time I've actually HAD Ethiopian food. In fact, in our group of three at the time, only one person has tried any before. So us knowing how to do anything at all during our time there is mostly thanks to her. But whether or not this is a new culinary experience for you, it's a relaxed, low-key place to eat and rest after a busy day.

New Eritrea Restaurant and Bar is located in the Sunset District, which is frankly where all the TRULY mouthwatering Chinese restaurants are located (seriously, look up Chinese restaurants with "Outer Sunset, San Francisco, CA" inputted into Yelp's location bar). But it's not just Chinese cuisine either and New Eritrea proves that. Originally, we had been trying to get into San Tung down the street. But it was the weekend and in the middle of dinner rush, so that wasn't happening. We wandered up and down Irving Street, looking for a place to eat, but the other two places we stopped by also had a very long wait period. New Eritrea was our fourth choice and the first one where we could immediately be seated.

This is a lovely spot to eat with a lot of options if you are (or with people who are) vegetarian, vegan, gluten-free, lactose-intolerant, or are adherent to Muslim or Jewish dietary restrictions. Half of the menu was vegetarian/vegan, with even the meat dishes being vegetable-heavy, and there was no pork dishes. Additionally, the sourdough injera bread was made with teff flour and was great for the friend that was avoiding gluten. 

When we asked our waitress, she talked about how New Eritrea serves Eritrea food, which is a mix of dishes and flavors from all the surrounding areas/countries around the state of Eritrea in northeast Africa. The most prominent influence, of course, being Ethiopian food. From the way it was explained, the melting pot and blend of cuisines in this manner kinda reminds of the way Singaporean fare came about. We ended up ordering a vegetarian combo platter (though none of us were actually vegetarian), and we all enjoyed it. I was pretty full from eating my own injera as well the injera that was being used as a plate for the combo and splitting one of my friend's leftover bread with the other friend. She ended up still being hungry and ordered more. The injera itself was a treat, as I enjoyed the slight tang of sourness and how it played with the flavors of the different parts of the vegetable combo. Eating with it kinda reminds me of dumpling making, where you have to use the dumpling skin to scoop out the filling while being careful not to squeeze while doing so.

The reservation system on their website is straightforward and easy to use. Additionally, they deliver to the inner and central Sunset District, the inner and central Richmond District, Cole Valley, Haigh-Ashbury, North Panhandle, and Laurel Heights. Inside, it's a bit worn, but it's clean and the setting is decorated and can flex between casual and semi-formal. Overall, I felt like it actually added to the low-key, relaxed charm. It's good for large parties of most kinds and I saw such a party while we were there. Their full bar wasn't really occupied at the time, but I'm sure it can accommodate if you're looking for a much more casual get-together.

Parking is...challenging along Irving Street. If you're not taking public transportation, you're gonna have to try the surrounding street parking. If you can and you're lucky, try to grab one of the spots along Irving Street. If THAT doesn't work, be sure to check the street parking on the roads running adjacent to Irving (ex. 9th, 10th, 11th, etc.). My friends and I had parked in the Andronico's Community Market parking lot (turn from Irving onto Funston Ave, it'll be to your left. Turn from Irving onto 14th Ave, it'll be on your right). It's technically only for Andronico's customers only, and we did end up buying some groceries and midnight snacks from them before leaving.

All in all, I had a great time trying something new and it was pretty delicious! That, and we were all pretty tired after a day Muir Parks and San Francisco exploring. Be aware that they're only open for dinner and are closed on Mondays. So if you're in the area during the dinner rush and don't want to deal with the long wait time you'll face with many of the Sunset District's restaurants, New Eritrea is definitely an option if you're looking for an accommodating, relaxed place for a satisfying, sit-down meal.
author: Christine L.

description:
Have you ever seen that episode of The Simpsons, where Marge, Bart and Lisa becomes yelpers.   They became yelpers after they were introduced to Ethiopian food.  Well, because of that episode, it made me want to try Ethiopian food, so the search begins.   I first had Ethiopian food in Seattle and it drove me crazy when i came back. And so begins my search for Ethiopian food in the Bay Area and that's how I found this place. 

I've been here a few times already, and i love it here.  You can get a platter for the right size of your party, and makes it perfect for sharing.   The vegetarian option is my favorite, more than the meat option.   The Injera bread is usually a little bit too sour for me, i wished it was less sour. They will give your more bread if you need more to pick up your food with. I love their honey wine, and it's best to get the whole bottle as oppose to a glass. The service is always great and i will continue coming back.  I also wished they were opened for lunch.
author: Belinda C.

description:
This was my first time at an Ethiopian-like restaurant, and it was awesome!

Definitely a unique experience as you'll be eating from a shared plate and with your hands. Try to make sure everyone's not sick for this one!

So I can't recommend specific foods as they served all the orders on one communal platter and didn't specify which was which. But we ordered the meat combination, the New Eritrea special, and the veggie combination with the okra and mushroom substituted in.

We also got the gluten-free "teff" which is a single bread-like piece you tear off and use to scoop and eat the food.

Overall, there's lots of mixed flavors and they're all pretty delicious. My friends say there are better places in the city (and Berkeley), but since this was my first time, I don't know any better. Definitely on the pricy side though; I was still a bit hungry despite paying $16 average before tax + tip.
author: Greg G.

description:
Delicious Ethiopian food. Plain and simple.

It's a little tucked away so it feels like a secret find, which is nice. 

We had the injira plate with chicken and it was perfect after a long day of sightseeing.

If you're visiting SF and want a spot that feels "local" (i.e. not some touristy chain), I recommend New Eritrea for good eats.
author: Hassan A.

description: This was my first time trying Ethiopian food! My family and I shared a platter meant for three people with a mix of the meat dishes and veggie dishes. I thought it was pretty good! The lamb and beef were super yummy! If anything I just wish the food was warmer when we got it, I felt it was sort of cold. Also it'd be cool to have some different textures in the dishes, everything was pretty mushy. Still enjoyed it a lot and thought it was a cool experience. Also the staff here was really nice and answered any questions we had about the menu.
author: Bisma P.

description:
I was looking for a place with vegan options close to Golden Gate Park and this place came up in my results. I saw that it had a solid 4 star rating and vegan as a keyword so decided to give it a shot.

When I walked in on a Sunday around 4pm I was either the only customer or one of the only customers. I think their dinner hours only start at 4pm, so that could also be the reason. I was seated at a table that was under a large glass elevated sealing, but the glass looked a bit dirty and it wasn't very scenic to look up. The rest of the atmosphere was a bit shabby too, where it felt slightly dated and maybe corners had been cut when it came to sweeping in the evening. Let's just say that I wasn't impressed and I didn't want to linger in this kind of environment.

The menu states that all of their vegetarian dishes are also vegan. I ordered the Vegetarian Combo to try as much variety as possible. My food was good, but the portion wasn't enough for leftovers if you are super hungry and I only got one piece of injera in a basket which seemed skimpy to me. I would have asked for more injera, but I believe I saw on the menu that it said extra injera was $3. I'm used to be served as much injera as I want with my meal at other places and this is the first time I have encountered being give only one piece of injera with my meal. 

Overall, as someone visiting from out of town, there is no reason for me to come back here since there are so many other options available.
author: Regina W.

description:
I've never had Eritrean or Ethiopian food, so I was very excited to try something new in terms of taste palate and dining experience. I've read reviews describing Eritrean/Ethiopian food as similar to Indian curry, which I beg to differ! It totally has its own unique flavors and spices. Indian curry isn't even a close sister. I enjoyed the food at New Eritrea and the traditional experiencing of eating this cuisine with your hands. 

I went to dinner with my friend and her family. While waiting for our food, we had some honey wine. I highly recommend trying this wine if you're a fan of dessert wines. We ordered a giant platter of the meat combo and vegetable combo. The meat combo had lamb, beef (my favorite), chicken, and catfish. The vegetable consisted of boiled potatoes, different types of beans/lentil mashes, and okra (my favorite). You are provided with injera, which is sour bread, to pick up the different types of meats and vegetables on the platter. You can also eat the injera lining the platter since it is used to sop up the delicious sauces left over.
author: Katrina C.

description: My favorite! Super friendly staff, lots of space, good location near good bars and Muni, and the FOOD. I usually go for the veggie platter and substitute in mushrooms for one of the usuals because they are SO YUMMY. The mixed veggie sambusas and a glass of the pinotage are also great calls.
author: Anastasia Z.

description: My favorite restaurant in the Inner Sunset.  I hate to admit that I walked by it for 10 years before I tried it.   A foodie friend convinced us to go, and we have never looked back.  Great Eritrean food and lovely, warm owners.  The great thing is that it's a large restaurant, so it's good for groups with kids.  You don't usually have to wait long, and you can put the teenagers at a separate table with their own platter to share.  Also, the Blue Moon on draft is great with the food - a perfect combination.
author: Traci B.

description:
-For what you pay: okay. We have had more for less. Quality is good though.
-Ambiance: a petite Ethiopian shotgun restaurant with classic table seating with white table cloths in the front and a open ceiling back area equally as nice
-service: can be slow but this is typical of Ethiopian restaurants in my experience. Was punctual when we asked for something but not fastidious
-taste: pretty good!

A stow away eclectic bar restaurant with pungent and unique dishes. We ordered the said "Amharic" way - accustomed to our traditional Ethiopian places - to which  our server hesitated and then replied "oh you are ordering it in Amharic". 

"Miser" was not listed as neither "Gomen" or "Berbere" but the servers know what you speak of -inexplicably so. I suppose it shows how connected the culture is. 

The meat was lavished in sauces, spices and bedded on a delicate tuff of injera. Recommend getting extra injera. 

Overall, very good but do prefer it a bit more spicy. 

UPDATE: went back to try the spicy gored gored.  Was covered in a pasty semi appetizing hot sauce.  Injera was too soaked to pick it up. Salad was a bit pitiful.
author: Rob C.

description:
Finding a restaurant that can accommodate a large group of foodies, several with different dietary restrictions, most of whom have "tried it all," is no easy task! I personally try to avoid places that insist on prix fixe (never seems worth it) or worse, family style (someone always leaves hungry) as well. New Eritrea fit the bill perfectly!

Seemed like most of group did not eat Ethiopian food on the regular, and even those of us pretty familiar with that spicy/tasty Ethiopian goodness, were not familiar with Eritrean cuisine (myself included). I love Ethiopian food and make the most simple vegetarian stews at home (all hail berbere!) One of my colleagues, Helina G (read her very informative review) is of Ethiopian descent and her advice on the menu was really appreciated by the 8 others in my group. About half of us were keen on the meaty stuff while the other half leaned towards vegetarian. I'm vegan and to my knowledge, anything on the menu noted as vegetarian is also vegan. Two of us needed the gluten-free injera, which you ideally request in advance. 

I loved everything on my plate (veg platter) and might have inhaled it. It's an abundance of stews, vegetables and legumes kissed with spices and wrapped up in that spongy, slightly sour, incredibly delicious injera. Wins all around, for my group was pretty enthusiastic about their food as well.

The exceedingly gracious host and hostess (seemed like possibly the owners) were so helpful and accommodating to our group. You truly felt welcome and appreciated here, but not in an overbearing manner!

If I lived in the neighborhood, or in SF for that matter, I would easily put New Eritrea in my regular rotation for casual, budget-conscious dining on those especially hungry days (so much food and such reasonable prices!)
author: Joi B.

description: I had never had Ethiopian food before and had no idea what to expect. We went with friends who love Ethiopian food and let them do all the ordering. The food and service was amazing!
author: Kate S.

description: Best Ethiopian in the city! This surprisingly large place in the sunset has hands down some of the best Ethiopian I have had. The portions are huge and perfect for sharing. I came with a large group and while the place did fill up we got a table and weren't rushed out or encourage to leave after our meal turned into an hour or so of after meal chat. The menu is huge but the combos are for sure the way to go.
author: Sarah F.

description: This place was very delicious and a great place to try Ethiopian food for the first time. The vegetable platter was a good option for vegetarians and eating with your hands and the bread is fun. The service was great despite being busy and our waitress was very nice.
author: Gabriel L.

description:
Such friendly people here, and they want to share the culture of Eritrea and Ethiopia. The food was fabulous! We ordered the meat combo and the veggie combo and an extra Kilwa beef...that beef was the best, well, along with the collared greens and lentils and okra and especially the injera bread on the bottom of it all once it soaked up all the amazing sauces...how could a Salvadoran chef cook East African food so well? Mystery!
The one tough spot for me is the price...if the people here were not so friendly I would take away one star for the price...it feels pricey; at about 15 bucks per dish it came out to 120 for the five of us with tip included--and one glass of wine (super healthy pour of a South African Chardonnay). So price is an issue but I would return for the people and the food!
author: Brett S.

description:
What a lovely spot for authentic Eritrean food! I got the chicken tibs and veggie combo which were delicious. The chicken was juicy and tender. And the injera was fresh and yummy. I got the steamed milk with honey on the side which was also very good.

Great ambiance with traditional music playing. Atmosphere is very casual. And the staff are super friendly!
author: Jacqui C.

description: My favorite! There are plenty of Ethiopian options but this one is my go-to because of the easy menu and selections.
author: Stella D.

description: Super friendly service. Server knew it was our first time trying Ethiopian food and was super helpful. Water came right away and food also didn't take long at all. Food was new for us and was all a bit mushy (reminded us of baby food) but the place itself was very nice (decor and ambience as well as service).
author: Kermeka D.

description: A solid 3.5  The gored gored was the best dish we both tasted. Lamb was nice and tender Overall it was a nice experience and I hesitated between 3 or 4 stars. The prices are pleasantly affordable for SF. I will be back
author: Gia M.

description:
I'm not going to be reviewing the food itself since this is a new type of cuisine for me.

Not just a new a cuisine but I was not expecting our utensils to be ... bread?  It's a type of flat bread that kind of reminds me of a steam cake/crepe.  I looked pretty confused I'm sure so the waitress explained that you use it to scoop and eat the food.  

I'm not sure how pathetic I looked, but halfway through the meal they came out with forks and I was very grateful.  

The food came out on another piece of their bread on a single tray so it was easy to share with my partner.

Waitress was very nice and the best part.... she didn't ask how the food was in the middle, but while I WASN'T in the middle of stuffing food in with my hands!
author: Sara P.

description: We love Moya's vegetarian sampler in SF. Sadly it was closed today so we decided to branch out. We got our delivery and everything tasted like bland baby food. The texture was very fine and veg tasted the same. The to go food was laid on top of an ingera and everything got super soggy during the relatively short delivery time.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I really like this place! New Eritrea has excellent vegan and vegetarian options; their vegetarian menu is completely vegan and everything on it is absolutely delicious! We always get the vegetarian combo plate, but I recommend subbing out one of the six standard entrees for the mushroom dish (the kantisha) just ask, they are happy to accommodate! The collard greens and okra are some of  my other favorites! The injera is lovely, and fresh, and fairly sour, which I really like. They could maybe give you a bit more injera with each order, but honestly the two person combo plate is so large you probably won't need it!

The service here is friendly and fairly fast; all the service staff recognize us now since we come here so frequently, they are all super friendly.

I haven't tried much of what they have to offer for drinks here (though they do have a full bar). However, I can recommend a glass of the pinotage that they offer which is quite nice and pairs well with the spicy curries and sour injera.
author: Nathan S.

description:
This restaurant is classified as an Ethiopian restaurant, but it's actually Eritrean. I am Ethiopian-American, and there are subtle distinctions between the two aside from the language and geography. Eritrea was formerly a part of Ethiopia until they won their independence in 1991. However, even before that, there were several historical events that shaped these cultural and food distinctions. For example, Ethiopians eat some dishes that include raw/tartare meat (kitfo, terey siga) and cook with heavier spices. Whereas Eritreans have a heavy Italian influence in their cooking that typically includes a lot of tomato-based stews and will even offer various interpretations of pasta and lasagna dishes. However if you're simply looking for injera, spicy stews and/or vegetarian combination platters, either type of cuisine will generally fit the mark. 

Recently dined at New Eritrea for a team dinner. They did an excellent job accommodating our large group. The service was excellent and the space was open and inviting. Our server was attentive and extremely patient with our specific requests for gluten-free injera (made wholly with 'teff' grain, indigenous to the horn of Africa). Wine glasses remained full and there was a genuine hospitality that we all very much appreciated. Everything was awesome from the service aspect. Unfortunately, the food itself was average. I grew up eating and cooking these dishes and was very excited to show off the delicious flavors that this type of cuisine had to offer to our group. However it didn't meet my expectations. If you go here, your best bet is to try one of the meat stews (tsebhi or 'wat') or 'tibs' which are some of the most popular items on the menu.
author: Helina G.

description: Honey wine is amazing- fresh and sweet. Had warm milk with honey- like being home. Highly recommend the lamb. Very friendly staff. Loved the spicy paste.
author: J H.

description:
I split the (all vegan) vegetarian platter for two with my husband here, one night a couple weeks back. We live in the neighborhood and are always impressed that there are so many wonderful places to eat when we don't feel like cooking.

Everything was tasty and there was plenty of injera for both of us. I'll definitely come back. The price was also excellent; it was a very reasonably priced night out.
author: Erin M.

description: This place is always great! We usually go into the restaurant with friends for dinner. I noticed they now deliver. Danger! What we received from delivery was just as good as what we expect when dining in. We got two of the veggie combos and a side of the gord gord beef, it was a lot of food for just us two, but so so good!
author: Christina W.

description:
Stopped in here after a hike for an impromptu  dinner around 9pm. 

My dining companion was nice enough to eat the vegan options with me!

Had the platter with everything and it was great. 

Collard greens and lentils were among my favorite options. Food was good enough for us to order more injera to finish it and my dining companion finished every last morsel!

It was his first time trying Ethiopian cuisineand he enjoyed it.  

Its wasn't as good as my favorites in Toronto but definitely worth a visit. 

The service was friendly and consistent. The restaurant was clean and relaxed.
author: Jannies L.

description: It's been a while since we had Ethiopian food. Last time we had it in San Diego and it was awesome food. We went in with same expectations but food wasn't that good. Decor was ok based on the space. Food wasn't that good or tasteful. We tried vegetarian plate for 2. Quantity was not much. So overall our experience was not great.
author: AJAY G.

description:
Great food and great service.  We had the combo veg and combo meat plater. It was perfect for 2 people.  For desert, we had the baklava which was delicious.

It was a very cold windy night out, but the front area was all seated.  The place is very warm and it has a nice bar.  I highly recommend this neighborhood Restaurant.
author: Jennifer T.

description: This was a good Eritrean/Ethiopian place! We got the vegetarian platter for 3 people, and it ended up being ~$14/person for a good amount of food. It's not that distinct from other Ethiopian places (doesn't necessarily stand out a ton), but it is a good affordable meal and great to come with friends.
author: Kimberly T.

description:
We came on a Tuesday night and there was no wait. If you're looking for a fun place to eat dinner with friends or a large group of people, this would be the spot. There is also great lighting up the back of the restaurant. 

This is a good local spot in the sunset for Ethiopian food. There is a good selection of beverages including honey wine and milk with honey. The vegetarian platters to share among groups of two or more people are also sizable and pretty affordable for San Francisco dinners. The injera is moist, fresh, and delectable. The meat options were also good. The chicken was tender and fell right off the bone.
author: Katherine L.

description:
I'd give 10 stars If I could!
One of my favorite restaurants to have a supper at. The food is absolutely amazing and always fresh. The owner and waitresses are always extremely hospitable, polite and friendly. However the last time we were there (1 week ago?) I felt that the portions of plate for 2 got smaller. I may have been wrong.
If you come with a friend, try plate for 2+ fish or plate for 2 + tar tar.
And that bread tho! amazing bread. 
Wish best of luck to this place.
author: Asiya M.

description: I have always been going to the few ethiopian restaurants in san jose and so wanted to try one in san francisco. Came here for dinner today. The restaurant feel was pleasant and welcoming. We got a table pretty soon and ordered asap. It took 25 mins to get the appetizers. We were disappointed. Then when the main course arrived (veggie house sampler) we were even more disappointed. All the dishes were pretty ordinary, not even a single veg entree was flavorful. I came here looking at the yelp reviews but it didnt live up to the mark.
author: Shatakshi G.

description:
YUM! I have brought friends and family here numerous times and it has never failed to impress! Each time I've gone I've shared the large vegetarian platter, and each time it is delicious.

The spices and variety of the items on the platter are amazing. I personally love the yellow lentils best, but nothing goes unconsumed when I'm eating at New Eritrea.

If you are looking for a unique dining experience, want to be able to make reservations, and are just generally interested in incredible meals, I highly recommend this place! I hope to return again and again.
author: Zoe H.

description: I love this neighborhood spot!  Been going here for years and I can't get enough of the vegetarian platter -- and I'm not even vegetarian.  I just love the dish so much, I'm not interested in trying another.  It's a family owned business, with a very nice owner.  Check it out!
author: Denise C.

description: My coworkers Heli and Johnny wrote significantly more educated reviews on this charming spot than I will be able to offer, having only eating Ethiopian food a handful of times, and Eritrean perhaps once without being fully aware of the differences. What I can say for sure is that the mixed vegetarian platter at New Eritrea was delicious, like a lesson in how to make unique and filling vegetarian dishes. The gluten free inerja was tasty and light and the service was incredibly warm, thoughtful and welcoming. I loved our table in the back where it feels like dining in a greenhouse, and I loved the happy easy mix of patrons enjoying this cozy, affordable, heart warming food.
author: Risa D.

description:
I've been eating Ethiopian food for many years but I think this was my first foray into Eritrean food. While there are many similarities there are enough differences that it's worth noting that one is not the other, much the same way you shouldn't conflate Indian and Pakistani food. From what I experienced, I would gladly take another go 'round with this cuisine. It was great stuff.

Despite the very casual appearance, the restaurant takes reservations, call ahead orders and can accommodate groups. If you prepare a trip in advance, know that you can request the injera be made with 100% teff flour. This will ensure that you're eating gluten-free (if this is a concern). Once this is done, come in and get ready to have a good time. The restaurant bears the bones of what it was before. I'm guessing it was a bar. The architectural elements are interesting and worth noting. Also worth noting is the very affordable wine list. I opted not to get honey wine (it's hit or miss with me) and, instead, enjoyed a glass (or five) of South African rose'. As much as I wanted to go to town on the sambusas, I knew that they weren't safe for my gluten sensitive stomach. I bravely soldiered on, drinking wine and waiting for the shared (and, giant) vegetarian sampler. It was worth the wait. With my own basket of warm g-f injera at the ready, I dug into mound after mound of red lentils, yellow lentils, okra, collards, potatoes, and chickpeas. The Eritrean spices made the vegetables even more delicious. Because I am a glutton, I couldn't resist my neighbor's NON g-f plate of lamb tibs and chicken. I should have. My belly was not happy with my folly the next day but when I tell you those tibs tasted so good on the way down, I am not giving proper respect to how incredibly good they were. I don't know whether my issue was the cross-contamination or if there needs to be a particular g-f preparation for the dish but I know that if it's possible for me to, safely, have it in the future, I will.

Our server (the owner?) couldn't have been more pleasant to our somewhat unruly group. There were many of us who'd never had Ethiopian food before, much less Eritrean cuisine. He took questions, complicated orders and kept the wine coming with a smile and much grace. I appreciated him. For the entirety of our (very long) meal, the restaurant was packed with patrons. Evidently the word is out about New Eritrea -- and for good reason.
author: Johnny T.

description: After 1 year, this place still rocks!  Friendly service, cleanliness, delicious homestyle food and great prices still 5 stars!
author: Maxie P.

description:
The food here is great, if pretty expensive. Case in point, a vegetarian combo platter for two is $27. I've been to other Ethiopian establishments (granted, mostly in the San Jose-exurbs where rent is likely much cheaper) where this same veggie combo and amount of food cost $14-16. Personally, I didn't care much for the tomato-y okra dish (strange, because I normally love okra) so next time if we got the veggie combo I would just ask for more collard greens, because they might have been the best I've ever had!

That being said, the quality was very good, and the injera was particularly delish here. I also highly recommend the lentil sambusas, which were among the best fried-dough-wrapped-veggie appetizers that I've eaten.
author: Anna B.

description:
BE PREPARED TO SMELL!! 

There was a weird vinegar-like, sour, strong smell in the restaurant. I couldn't quite figure out the source of the smell but it was potent! When I left the restaurant, my clothes still smelled like it, which I didn't appreciate because we were going out to a bar afterwards with friends. Just like leaving a Korean BBQ place and smelling like it afterwards, my clothes and body reaked of the smell from this restaurant. 

Since it was my first time at the restaurant, I ordered both the Vegetarian Combo and the Meal combo to share with my boyfriend. He's more of a meat lover than I am. I can do without but Is till want to try it so that I can review it. :) 

I was able to substitute one of the sides on the vegetarian combo plate for something that I preferred which was nice. The vegetarian combo came with 4 items including a side salad. The 4 items were: lentils, collard greens, chick peas, and potatoes (but I substituted mushrooms instead). 

The meat combo came with 3 different meats: beef, chicken, and lamb as well as a side of lentils and a side salad. 

Overall both combo plates were spicy! I never noticed the spicy-ness of Ethiopian food until I ate at this restaurant. This restaurant definitely used a different type of spice or just different ingredients to make their dishes because I had a difficult time finishing my meal. 

The enjera was the same thankfully. I enjoyed that a lot. 

Overall, I wouldn't say this is the best Ethiopian restaurant out there. A lot of customers seemed to be enjoying their meal. I saw more men than women here. But maybe for some, it's a good introduction to trying Ethiopian food.
author: Mel H.

description:
I walked out of here with not a food baby, but a food octuplet. Between two people we ordered  the beef tartare and the veggie sampler. We usually have to get a lot to be satisfied but the food here is so filing that we even had left overs, so dont underestimate that airy injera!!!  Overall the experience here was good. although its not as lively as Shiba on Fillmore, I thought the food was better and its not pricey at all! 


1 star off for slow service but it was a packed house.
author: Angel Y.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant to go to with my little family! The staff are so warm and welcoming! You don't need to be intimidated if you've never tried Ethiopian food before, they are happy to explain menu items, and show you the ropes. My kids like it cuz you can eat with your fingers, and all the menu items are so tasty! My fav is #5. 
If you're curious about Ethiopian cuisine, give this place a try! It won't disappoint.
author: Hillary A.

description: This is a great little spot. The food was solid and authentic. Service was great. I love the family vibe you get. We got the vegetarian platter for two. It was more than enough.
author: Candace C.

description: The food here is phenomenal, if you haven't had Ethiopian cuisine this is a great place to give it a shot - both the vege and meat options are really well done. The interior of the joint feels dated and a bit hap-hazard, it wouldn't be my choice for a romantic first date, but for a good meal with friends it's a real contender.
author: Preston G.

description:
Had the good fortune to make the acquaintance of Mahna, the soft spoken yet affable patriarch running this family-run neighborhood gem going on 20 years now

Whatever you order, remember to accompany it with a glass of tej honey wine!
author: David C.

description: This is the only Ethiopian restaurant that I know of that mixes greens into their kitfo, which I love. The injera is sour and spongy and delicious. Plenty of mitmata served on the side and try the honey wine, the sweetness holds up nicely to the spiciness of the kitfo/mitmata. And the people who run the place are lovely.
author: Scott B.

description: Love this place! Food is always excellent and portions are big. For those who have never tried it, but love spices and flavor, give it a go!! They have meat or vegetarian options. It's a hidden gem!
author: Christina V.

description: I liked this food very much. Exotic flavors, a new experience to eat without silverware. The sharing plates are most popular. I enjoyed it a lot.
author: Coté M.

description:
Let me start off by saying, I have never had Ethiopian/African food, it was quite an experience that if you haven't been I definitely recommend going.

We started off with the meat sambussa, which was good, however in my opinion a little too greasy.  For the main course we got the meat combo and the veggie combo, it was served with thin bread that's a bit sour, the meat sampler was tasty and so were the veggie dishes.  You will be using the bread to eat instead of eating utensils so be prepared.

It was a good first experience, very similar to Indian food but yet different, I will most likely be back to try the tar tar that people seem to rave about.  
Service was great, I do wish they would give out wet naps since you are eating with your hands.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
I had some really good Ethiopian food when I visited Washington DC a few years back, so I was happy to come here after finding out this place was in the neighborhood.  However, I can't say I'm a fan of this place.

We ordered the meat and vegetarian combo which was delicious.  The meat and the potatoes was my favorite.  But the injerra bread provided was way too sour for my taste.  We were fine with it in the beginning, especially since the food was spicy, but after a while, the sour taste was too overwhelming.  I'm not sure if that's normal, cause I don't remember that being the case in DC.
author: Karen L.

description:
I am in love with African food. In SF I go to Bissab Baobab,Axum Cafe,to name a couple. But my favorite is Eritrean/Ethiopian food. Of all the Eritrean and/or Ethiopian restaurants in San Francisco my favorite is New Eritrea. 
Their food is delicious. I always get the Meat Combination which is Zebhi Dorho (Chicken),Zigni (beef) in red pepper sauce and Alicha Begee (lamb)with carrots and potatoes. I never leave here hungry or wishing I ordered something else. They are willing to work with you on the level of spiciness so people with sensitive stomachs shouldn't worry. The injera(flat bread)is fresh,spongy and delicious.
The service is warm and friendly. They are attentive without showing up at your table every 30 seconds. 
The drinks menu spans from African beers,other imported beers as well as American craft beers. I always get,and I always recommend to others,the Hakim Stout from Ethiopia. It is chocolatey,malty and a bit roasty which is great for quelling some of the heat from the spicy food.
The ambiance is reminiscent of an 80's bar you see in movies that was re-imagined in Ethiopia. It is funky and cool which is all part of it's charm and only makes eating there that much better.
author: Zardu H.

description:
Lots of good flavors in the dish. Have some vegetarian options.
Always great to eat family style.  My kids new favorite place for this cuisine.
author: Brad R.

description:
Everything is good here

I get the veggie and meat combo every time and every time I'm elated. The staff is incredibly sweet and I enjoy them, as well as the interior atmosphere.
author: Jenna L.

description:
Well,
They have a new menu.
Short and not so sweet!
I usually love the stews of tender meat with long simmered veggies and Eritrean spices.

Now you have to order the veggies separately. 
I don't want 2 entrees. 
Disappointed with the change.

Still nice dining room and friendly service.
author: wally i.

description:
New Eritrea Restaurant & Bar is a wonderful time with friends to dig deep into some injera to grab the goodies lying before you on the circular tray.

I came here on a Sunday night with two other friends and was seated promptly. The seating towards the back is very nice as the ceiling is made of glass thereby allowing the natural sunlight to illuminate the area. The service here is super friendly, always being attentive, helpful when ordering, and smiling.

We started off with some meat and vegetable sambusas. The meat one is very simple with some ground beef inside, but the vegetable sambusa has a number of vegetables within for more complex flavors. The chili paste that comes with this starter is absolutely amazing! It has a thick paste consistency to it and has quite a kick of heat and spices. If you like both spice and spiciness, then I highly recommend getting some sambusas to give it a try.

We ordered both the vegetable combo and the meat combo which seems like the way to go if you're not sure what to get and want a bit of everything. It comes with injera on the side and also under all the goodies, soaking in all the sauces and flavors until it is revealed at the very end. The injera has a unique sour taste to it and is quite spongey as well, making it more interesting than a typical piece of starch. Each of the meats and vegetables were all unique in their own right. What I love about the variety is that each part of it is doused in a separate sauce to get all types of flavors. They have the flavor of Indian food with the variety of spices, but a bit more subtle, not being so strong and powerful. I enjoyed the experience overall and would recommend this to anyone wanting to try some Eritrean cuisine!
author: Joshua M.

description:
This was my first Ethiopian experience and I'm impressed!

For 6 people we ordered the honey wine, House Sampler-Vegetarian Combo for 3 people, meat combination, and the new Eritrea's Special. It was a belly full of food even for 6 people, and I would recommend getting a vegetarian combo for 2 and 3 choices of meat or vice versa for better portion size. The vegetable dishes were a bit salty for my palate but the meat (especially the chicken and lamb) were cooked and seasoned well. 

I liked the concept of sharing food out of a central plate. There were no utensils so we literally dug right in to our food--using our hands! I would recommend this place for a more casual, family/friend outing (it can get messy for a first date;)) 

Overall, I liked the service and cozy ambiance, but  the bathroom could use some improvements with a better sink and quality hand paper towels paper, especially since we're using our hands and sharing the food with the table.
author: Linda K.

description: This was the first time I ate Ethiopian food. My opinion may be bias but it was very good I went with my girlfriend and her friend and we got the vegetarian dish dinner deal for 3 with 6  items.
author: Sean P.

description: Hands down THE BEST Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant in the Bay Area. Some might say this is because I grew up on 10th and Irving and others would just simply agree! I have ate at every single Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant intentionally to see if there was better. Good...sure but no where near how good they are here! I would highly suggest this restaurant if your looking for good flavor, relaxing environment, great employees and just all out good food. If you want a meat dish they have it, if your a veggie person don't worry they got that for you too!
author: Jeremiah S.

description: My husband and I adore New Eritrea. I order take out from them weekly! I love the Vegetarian sampler platters. Service is super friendly, and the food is always excellent.
author: A M.

description:
Great food. Great people. Best way to chill and eat really good food family style.

Honey wine is awesome. The new Eritrea special is delicious. 
They take there time to make the delicious platters so plan to hang and chat.
author: R P.

description: Welcoming and attentive service, great food, full bar, what more is there to ask? They even accommodated when I asked for things not explicitly on the menu.  I would recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a delicious bite to eat in one of the best neighborhoods of San Francisco.
author: Emmaline H.

description: I'm happy to say that upon a few return visits and a couple of deliveries, this place is killing it on the food front. Super happy to have them down the street from me.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
I went twice during my month-long stay in SF because I couldn't get enough! The first time I went, I ordered the Zebhi Dorho (chicken dish cooked in clarified butter and spices). It was served atop injera with salad and several lentil and vegetable sides. It was amazing. The chicken was falling off the bone, and the sauce was so flavorful. Honestly, I wish I could eat this every day! For one person, this is a LOT of food, so it's well worth the price. 

The second time I went, I went with two friends. It definitely is more fun to eat here with others, because injera is meant for sharing! We ordered the house sampler vegetarian combo for 3. It came with collard greens, lentils, potato and vegetable stew, okra, and chickpeas. Each was perfectly seasoned and so delicious. 

New Eritrea is an excellent option for people looking to eat healthfully. It's also a good choice for people with gluten sensitivity like myself. The injera is almost 100% gluten free, and the small amount of wheat in it is fermented, so it didn't bother me. 

Maybe I went at weird times, but I think this restaurant should be a lot busier than it is. It has a full bar and the ambiance is casual but on the nicer side (tablecloths, soft music playing). It's only open for dinner.
author: Emily G.

description: Came here for dinner with a group, and it was alright. We ended up splitting a bunch of dishes, and most of them were just not very exciting in terms of flavor. Also, the injeera that we got with our meal was cold- one of my facorite parts of Ethiopian food is the warm fluffy bread! Overall, i have my go to Ethiopian place in oakland, and I'll probably stick to that.
author: Rachel D.

description:
Yum! Very filling Ethiopian food. But questionable service?? 

FOOD: 2 of my friends and I shared the house sampler platter for two ($24), which came with 5-6 different dippings and an injera at the bottom, and the Kitfo ($14), which came in a rice-bowl sized mortar. Each of us also ordered an injera ($1 each). 

My friend taught me to tear small pieces from the injera, which had a sour taste, and use it to pick up the dipping and/or the Kitfo. I really liked how there was a variety of dippings (or are they dippings?) to try. Kitfo was tartar of finely chopped lean flank steak, which I really liked and would recommend! We were all so full by the end. So one piece of injera was definitely enough for everyone. 

SERVICE: We came on a Saturday evening and were seated immediately. The food took 10-15 minutes to prepare, which was reasonable. The waitress was very friendly, but the manager WAS NOT!!! I was kind of upset when HE ASKED US TO LEAVE RIGHT AFTER WE PAY THE BILL, even though there were MANY EMPTY TABLES next to us. What.

SETTING: The place looks small and shady from the outside, but the interior is pretty big. There is a bar section, and two dining sections. So a lot of space but not big enough because they just had to kick us out. 

PRICE: With tip and tax, we paid $48 total ($16/each). Definitely worth it.

OVERALL IMPRESSION: I would come back again because the food is good and fun to eat, but I am NOT impressed by how they treat their customers after they received the bill.
author: Wendy F.

description: Amazing food and service! Veggie options that taste amazing so good for vegans and dairy free people
author: Lucas G.

description:
New Eritrea is a great East African restaurant in the inner Sunset--you wouldn't necessarily expect a restaurant like this in such a trendy area, and it's easy to overlook! The decor is nice and simple, and the dining area has a huge skylight above it and is one of the brightest dining rooms in a restaurant that I've visited. The food is also great and a good introduction for people who might be less familiar with this type of cuisine. My favorite dish was probably the appetizers--the sambusas, fried dough filled with meat or vegetables. The sambusas came with a spicy chile paste that was absolutely amazing--it added the perfect amount of spice and flavor to the dough pockets without being overpowering. Then came the main dish--my two friends and I split one each of the vegetarian combo and the meat combo and were served both on one plate. The meat dishes (chicken, lamb, and beef!) were all very tender, having been braised or stewed, and the vegetable dishes (chickpeas, potatoes, lentils, collard greens) were all tasty as well--no one item stood out for me, but having a little bit of everything was definitely a great way to try out the different components. The best part of the main course was eating the injera on top of which all the different stews were served--the sauces by this point had soaked into the sour, pancakey bread, and it was delicious!

The service at this restaurant also stood out--the wait staff was patient, friendly, and attentive throughout the night.
author: David K.

description:
Delicious delicious! My personal favorites were lentil sambusa for the appetizers and the lentils in the family style main course! The place/ambience is really chill. Our server was a funny polite lady who made great dish recommendations for us. Will definitely go back here to satisfy eithiopian food cravings! 
This place also has a ton of good bars, dessert spots around it. Nice neighbourhood to take a stroll in!
author: Soundarya C.

description:
I visited on a Friday night. The restaurant is spacious with ample seating. There's a bar and a TV. It wasn't busy.

I had the honey wine and vegetarian combo plate. Their injera might be the best I've had, so sour and flavorful. The rest of the food was delicious as well.

Staff was friendly. They checked in periodically but weren't too intrusive.
author: Heather M.

description:
Although I grew up going to Ethiopian restaurants in the DC area, it had been some time since I'd been to one, and I wasn't at all sure what to order. Also, I was there with my three daughters, who hadn't ever had Ethiopian food before. The waitress was extremely nice (and patient) as we figured out what to get. And everything was delicious!

The girls all loved it, and we're hoping to go back again soon.
author: Charlie P.

description:
My first Ethiopian restaurant, and I really liked it!

The place: A comfy place, my friend and I went there around 7:30PM, it was not crowded and not empty too. Great!

The server was really kind, and efficient. We had our dishes 10 or 15 min after which is pretty fast. I appreciate that. 

I went there with a friend and we chose a Kilwa Begee (lamb meet) with some vegetables, it was amazing, really tasty, served in a big plate that we shared. How about the drinks? I took a Nigerian beer, pretty good, not heavy that you can drink while you are eating.

Finally, we had to pay $44, with the drinks and the dinner. Not expensive, not cheap, it's average but I do need to try another Ethiopian restaurant.

Amazing experience, I will definitely come back there. Great service, nice place and tasty food = 5 Stars!
author: Lino M.

description:
I've been coming here since I moved to San Francisco, and returned frequently in 2014 with friends and family.  And everyone that has dined here with me, and has taken up on my recommendation, absolutely loved their experience at New Eritrea!

The food is absolutely delicious, and I've always been greeted with smiles from the employees.

The usual for me is the veggie sambusa and a veggie combo.  I know I need to try something new, but what I order has been consistently good every time I come here.

I'm a fan for life.
author: Vira P.

description:
The kilwa here is fantastic - sautéed beef in tomatoes, onions and lots of butter - definitely recommend! 

We also got the veggie combo and substituted one of the options for the kantisha (mushrooms with tomatoes and onions - maybe there's a trend here), which ended up being my favorite. The others (chickpeas, lentils, split peas, potatoes, okra) didn't particularly stand out to me.

I'd come back to try the meat combo with the kantisha, rather than the veggie combo with an added meat dish. Ordering meat does increase the waiting time but it's worth it!
author: Linda Y.

description:
Came here a few weeks ago for dinner. I've had Eritrean/Ethiopian food before in Berkeley and LA but had been on the lookout for a good place in SF. 

We had to wait maybe around an hour to be seated? It was definitely packed and busy. 

Customer service: It was okay, our server was pretty nice. Definitely seemed to be stretched a bit thin given the amount of people in the restaurant. 
Restroom: Pretty decent and clean, which is pretty important given that I was going to use my hands to pick up and eat the food. 

FOOD: Ordered the meat sambusas to start off - they are pretty much like samosas and came with a hella spicy red dipping sauce - use sparingly. Gonna admit, the red pepper sauce wasn't my favorite, but to each their own.
Then, we ordered the meat combo and vegetarian combo platter. It came on a large circle of injera and separate injera on the side. At first glance, it may not seem like much, but the injera definitely expands in your stomach and fills you up. Similar to past experiences with this cuisine, I didn't like every separate entity within the meat and vegetarian combos. However, I'm not sure if they spice it differently from other restaurants, but I just didn't like some of the dishes that I usually like. 

I did like the lentils and the simple salad (I think it's iceberg lettuce?). Was not a fan of the collard greens. As for the meats, I liked the zebhi dorho and zigni. Injera was spongey and not too vinegary. Typical prices for Eritrean/Ethiopian food.
author: K W.

description: On a HOT Sunday, we showed up just as they opened.  We received the kind of hospitality I usually only see when I've become a store regular.  So then, we ordered.  The food came out quickly, and was delicious.  We had ordered a vegetarian dish and a meat dish, as well as sambusas.  They gave us the option to have the dishes family style, which made it even better.  We split and shared everything, and it was ALL delicious.  I cannot recommend this place any more highly.  It was a wonderful lunch.
author: Tom T.

description: The best Ethiopian restaurant in San Francisco hands down. A large space that is great for groups. We typically will get the vegetarian platter it comes in various sizes depending on how many people in your group. One large platter is presented on the table. Everything is shared and eaten with your hands with a special bread. The veggies are spiced wonderfully with a little kick of heat. Depending on tastes we will sometimes add a meat dish or two with the meal! Staff is very friendly and always welcoming and willing to explain the cuisine and different choices! More than just a meal it is a experience! The imported Ethiopian beer is a great pair with your meal! I love this place and visit as often as I can! I always leave super satisfied with my meal!
author: Michael B.

description: Great Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant with warm ambience and genuinely friendly and competent waiting staff. Delicious spicy beef tips and lamb in garlic butter on injera bread. Will definitely go again.
author: Les E.

description: Fabulous food and service.  We brought our 4 year old here.  He loved it!  Highly recommended
author: J K.

description: Great food and service! I visited the place on a Sat evening and there were lot of people waiting to be seated which gave a sense that it would be having good food. I would recommend people with a group of 4 or more to get the platter as it has different main course dishes and you get to taste different dishes. I would recommend them to upgrade the restroom properly though.
author: Smokin P.

description:
We have eaten here many Fridays having a variety dishes each of which has been tasty, adequate in quantity, and fair in price.

We shall return when convenient.
author: Icono C.

description:
sunday night - walked in and no wait, but also lots of tables were filled up. lots of families and pleased it was family friendly place.
super nice waitstaff 

we ordered just one vegetarian platter - 2 orders of Okra plus 
Tumtumo (Lentil beans puréed ,& simmered with Eritrean spices, onions & herbs) and Hamli (Collard green and spinach simmered in authentic Eritrean spices) and we got 2 extra orders of the gluten free teff bread which was yum. (we weren't super hungry so we just ordered one entree and some extra bread)

flavors were all DELISH. 

we will be back! thank you for a wonderful light dinner that truly hit the spot.
author: Win H.

description:
I have never encounter Eritrean & Ethiopian food before, so we decided to eat here to kick off our bucket list of food we have never tried before!
 
We were not disappointed with the food and service. I decided to order the meat combo with the sour crepe-looking thing called injera - is a sourdough-risen flatbread with a unique, slightly spongy texture. This one was pretty good and has interesting taste. Oh, you eat food with your bare hands, just like our Filipino culture. The entrees are great for 2 people, but we only ended up only ordering 1 entree for the two of us that result our tummy very happy and delightful! At top of that, we had a bottle of honey wine from Ethiopia to try out. It was overly sweet, but it was a nice experience. We took the bottle that was half full to add to my wine collection. I got a little buzz as I walk my way out of the restaurant :). 

Will come back to try out more!
author: Jan P.

description:
This restaurant is one of my favorites. I order takeout from here probably once a week. The staff is kind, warm, accommodating and prompt. I love seeing the whole family helping out. It makes it feel like a quaint neighborhood place. 

The food is incredibly flavorful and delicious. I always get the vegetarian platter and it's always been amazing!
author: Sarah S.

description:
I am a vegetarian and I love the fact that they have so many vegetarian options on the menu! The food is flavorful and served fresh - I love the aroma of their spices. I particularly like their Kantisha and Okra. It is a homey and casual place, with wonderful people to serve you. After trying out several Eritrean restaurants, I have settled on this one and have been going here for the past two years. 

P.S. Keep some time aside for parking on weekends as Irving street gets super busy.
author: Swati B.

description:
About the place: bigger than it looks from the outside actually and good for groups or date night. The decor is East African throughout mostly but the lamps over the bar look like the TGI Fridays lamps...hehe. Big bar with plenty of stools to eat, drink, or do both. Full bar btw. Servers are very nice. 

About the price: average $10-$14 per plate. 

About the food: you eat with your hands! Scooping your dish with a crepe like piece of bread. First we had the Sambusa with ground beef...AMAZE. Two puff pastries filled with nicely seasoned beef and it comes with a side of something spicy...a kind of paste you can dip it in. So good!! For dinner we had the Kilwa beef and the New Eritrean Special (chicken). The chicken dish BLEW the beef away. It had so much flavor and the chicken was cooked perfectly. They bring both dishes out on a silver platter sitting on top of the crepe like bread called injera and place bean paste and a small salad in between the two for separation. You can eat it with the bread but I also sort of wrapped the meat in the lettuce. I had the meta lager (Ethiopian) which I really liked. Had a hint of honey. 

Will definitely be back!!
author: Neal B.

description: The food is to die for. If you eat meat try the kifto. It's buttery goodness. The mushrooms are excellent as well. I could eat here every night. Oh and the people that run this place are sooooo nice. I'm a fan
author: Krista A.

description: I very much enjoy the food and I think Mana is a great guy.
author: Gull S.

description: Ive reviewed before and this place is consistently good Eritrean food.  We love coming here.  The staff are so friendly and the food is delicious.
author: Steven B.

description: Very good Ethiopian food. Friendly staff. We had the vegetarian platter and was positively delighted. Would definitely come here again :)
author: Brendan M.

description: I love the food and the staff here! It's one of my favorite places in the city. The skylight room towards the back is the perfect place to eat a delicious comfort meal on a foggy day. I love the meat combo + veggie combo for two. Add a bottle of wine = fantastic.
author: Kaitlin S.

description: I never had Ethiopian cuisine and had to try this place.  I loved it.  The servers were super nice and very accommodating to our requests for suggestions.  I feel like we had a truly authentic meal with even Ethiopian beer.  This is a great place for vegetarians and vegans also.
author: Jason G.

description:
I had heard good things about this restaurant and to be honest, I was expecting more.

The staff was very pleasant but not the most attentive. Once the food came out, we never again saw our server and did not get a water refill. 

We ordered the lamb and okra. The lamb was very tough, almost chewy and did not have a lot of flavor. I probably would have mistaken it for beef if I hadn't ordered it myself. The okra was spicy and more flavorful, carrying some chocolatey notes. I was surprised that it was very mushy, almost more like a paste with only a few distinguishably pieces of okra. Perhaps this is the standard, but I like the texture of okra so I was a bit disappointed. 

Our entrees came with "salad" served in the middle of the tray, but really it was just glorified iceberg lettuce with a few slithers of carrot. I was surprised that the tray did not come with other sides. I guess I was expecting more of a sampler of sides because that is what I have gotten previously at Assab Eritrean. Also, I felt that the portions were on the smaller side.

Perhaps this was just a one time fluke, but I am hesitant to return.
author: Nina M.

description: On a Friday night my friend and I were looking for an affordable dinner in walking distance to out Golden Gate Park area apartment. The wait was 15 minutes so we sat at the bar immediately. Service wasn't super fast, but was incredibly friendly. We split the vegetarian combo platter for 2 and every veggie app on the menu. So delicious!! We absolutely loved the food and the price was incredible affordable.
author: Anna S.

description:
Went with a group of five. It wasn't busy when we got in, but it was packed by the time we left (post Bluegrass festival). The service was good, but a bit slow on account of the crowd. Still, the staff was super friendly, pleasant and helpful. 

We got the vegetarian platter for 4 + mushroom dish. The food was plentiful, but just not the best Eritrean I've had. The injera is good, but the potatoes were flavorless, and salad didn't have a great dressing to it.

Generally, I was fine with it. But it's was  A-OK. I'd much rather go to Sheba for music and Ethiopian. Their spices come through strongly, and it's a very aromatic meal.
author: Dimple B.

description:
Last night was my first time trying Eritrean food, and while I'm not sure the flavors are entirely up my alley, I was quite impressed with the restaurant itself.

New Eritrea was very accommodating of my 10 person party, and it was a really fun experience getting to try out something new with such a large group. I'd never eaten with my hands like this before, and it was surprisingly not too messy.

My side of the table shared a vegan platter as well as a meat combo, and while I do usually tend to prefer meat options, I think the vegan option was actually better. The menu calls the vegan options "hearty," and they really are. I'm clearly not Eritrean (or anything close to it), and yet it felt like comfort food--especially in the cold Inner Sunset microclimate.

I don't know that I'd come back, but if you know you like Eritrean food, or if you and your large group want a place to go, I'd highly recommend it!
author: Kelly R.

description: Been here with my family half a dozen times and each time has been incredible and memorable for us. The nicest people ever work here, they take care of us so well every time we're there. The food is delicious, the best you can get, and we've sampled a lot of Eritrean/Ethiopian food in San Francisco. The sampler plates are great, especially for groups. Can't wait to go back!
author: John P.

description: If you want something different than your usual Asian, European or Latin-American food, then you should definitely come here. It has a quiet environment. Good for dates and good conversations. We usually order one plate for two people and it fulfills us pretty much.
author: Richard C.

description: Very good Ethiopian food-- I had the veggie combo without the collard greens and added the chicken Doro, which was fantastic. Very flavorful, rich, and authentic. I loved the injera, it wasn't bland or too flat/ thin. I just wished they gave you more than one piece before you have to pay for extra. The service and people there were very nice and courteous. I look forward to going back and trying more meat dishes!
author: Amanda Y.

description: Well. That was awesome. The vegetarian plate for two wins a place in my heart for ever. I will be back. I may not share next time.
author: Kelli M.

description: Food is delicious here! Love the meat & veggie combination platters & of course their special bread injera. I love eating the food with our hands. Great ambiance, staff & cooks!
author: Arlene Z.

description:
SUMMARY: Went with 3 others for dinner on a Friday night around 8pm without a reservation. Seated immediately with very pleasant service, yummy food, and overall lovely time.

WHAT I TRIED: House platter for 2 (vegetarian) + 2 orders of Meat Combo + 2 extra orders of injera

----MORE DETAIL----
FOOD: GOOD: I've been a bit spoiled by Ethiopian food in DC - I had a favorite place there which is hands down the best Ethiopian food (and some of the best food) I've ever had. However, this ethiopian food was legit and I enjoyed it. My friends loved it and thought it was the best ethiopian they've had in SF. What I thought could have been better: 1) the injera was a bit more sour than I like it - but that is also more authentic (likely that they had a higher ratio of Teff flour) - so it's a matter of preference, 2) the meat was a little overcooked and therefore dry, and 3) the sauces were a bit sour and not as flavorful as I'm used to, but I think they were also healthier (less clarified butter). What I really liked: 1) they had Eritrean + Ethiopian food and I haven't had as much Eritrean before - friend pointed out that Eritrean tends to be creamier (they really cream up the lentils for example), 2) portions were a good size, and 3) I don't usually like okra, but their okra was delicious.

SERVICE: GREAT: Nothing exceptional or unique, but the servers were very nice - didn't rush us but were still attentive and joked around with us a bit. Very friendly.

AMBIANCE: My friend described it as "Italian restaurant-y" which I liked and thought was accurate. It had an "African flair," but you wouldn't really have been able to tell it was Ethiopian/Eritrean from the ambiance. Low mood lighting + clean, interior but nothing special. It was quiet enough to talk without screaming and we sat in the back which was like a greenhouse.
author: Christina K.

description: I like New Eritrea a lot, given the fact it's the only Ethiopian place here in SF I've been to and I've eaten here about 14 times. I really enjoy the meats/food here and the bread. Not very much of a fan of the salad or lentils. Each of the sambusa flavor options are great. Friendly customer service:)
author: Kiwi B.

description: This is my favorite place to eat in San Francisco. Firstly, I love Eritrean and Ethiopian food. Secondly, the staff here is super nice and helpful and the service is very fast. They have an amazing vegetarian platter that is great for sharing. It has tons of different items on it and each dish is delicious. I also love their milk with honey for a little sweet treat. Definitely order that! I came here for my birthday with about 10 friends and they put some tables in the back together for us. It was perfect.
author: Lindsay L.

description: The food is still good. Had the Okra, and the Kantisha (mushrooms). However, it was way understaffed--the waitstaff barely had time to take our orders, and then it was nearly impossible to get their attention for the rest of the meal.
author: David W.

description: The food is really good here. The service is very friendly. The restaurant is nice and spacious and not crowded. The only thing is the portions are rather small. The prices are decent but for the same price in the South Bay, you can get twice the amount of food. Here, for two people, you would need to get 2 combos. Whereas in the South Bay, one combo would be enough for 2 people.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Food is amazing people are amazing I am in Frisco for about two weeks for work and by far this is one of the best places I've been so far but its only been a couple of days so ill let you guys know lol
author: Chesean R.

description: If you've never tried Ethiopian food, it is an interesting and amazing experience! They offer vegetarian and non-vegetarian options, and serve their plates on traditional Ethiopian bread called injera. I recommend the meat and vegetarian combo for two people.
author: Sandra S.

description: My first time eating ethipian food and it was a lovely experience. This place is definitely delicious. We order the lentil/ veggie and meat sambusas which were delicious!! We got the veggie combo plate and the chicken and lamb for mains. I felt the injira bread was a little too fermented. the spinach and lentils were amazing!! but the cauliflower potato was not very good. Loved the place and ofcourse the lovelyyy Honey wine!!
author: Ashmita V.

description:
The honor of my first review on this short visit back to the US goes to New Eritrea.

Servers were warm and friendly. It was a bit crowded when we arrived, but we didn't have too wait too long for a table. Portion sizes were plentiful. Unfortunately, we weren't able to finish the meal between the two of us. For the number of dishes we ordered I definitely wish we'd had a third person along.

The seasoning for every dish was spot on: flavors were not just spicy but complex. I couldn't stop eating the gored gored, it was so tender. And the kitffo was smooth and had just the right level of spice. We also had the cooked collard greens and puréed chickpeas, which tasted like some sort of magic mashed potatoes. 

The honey wine was so lovely but quite heady! With all that food, even one glass will probably send you into a deep sleep.

The only better Ethiopian I've had was in D.C, which is probably the best place outside of Ethiopia to enjoy their cuisine.

4.5 stars because it would've been even better if they served Ethiopian coffee.
author: Chrissy B.

description:
Favorite Ethiopian of the 3 places I've tried in San Francisco

Kilwah beef and kilwah dohro and vegetarian combo were plenty for me and my 2 friends. 

This is the first place I've ever been to that charges for extra injera :(
author: Dorothy Y.

description:
Although Ethiopian food has never been on my list of top-cuisines-to-try, at least I can now say I've tried it. To put it briefly, New Eritrea is ideal for those who enjoy meat and lentils with spicy and sour flavors and family-style dining.

Get the combination meat and vegetarian platters for a variety. Personally, I liked the meats and lentils much more than the spinach and collard greens. The beef and lamb were quite spicy but delicious, and the chicken was very moist. The spinach and collard greens dish was VERY SOUR for my taste. The injera flatbread (also slightly sour) basically functions as your utensil to scoop up all the meat and vegetables. Eating with hands becomes extremely messy, but it's overall a fun experience.

New Eritrea is perfect for large groups. However, if you're not a fan of sour foods, I wouldn't recommend eating here. And if eating with your hands isn't your forte, they offer utensils as well.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Always enjoy coming here, it has an old school atmosphere and has been in the Sunset for a long time. Great food, love coming here with a group of friends and sharing a big dish. The food is very good (my 2nd fav Ethiopian restaurant in SF, but I won't name my first here ;) 

Come grab a drink of Tej and enjoy some injera with friends!
author: Esther F.

description:
Came here with my sister because we felt adventurous. 

The place was half dim in the front and half lit in the back. We chose to sit in the back because we like to see what we're eating. The server was really nice and attentive. She refilled our water without us asking. We ordered the meat and veggie combo plate, so we can try a little of everything. Food came out fast on a big circular tray. It was fun to eat with your hands. I thought the food was a bit salty, but it might just be how the dishes are supposed to be like? The food wasn't good or bad, just not my type of cuisine. The flat bread was also sour and I didn't like that too much. Saw two people come into this restaurant for take out, so they might be regulars. This place may not be for me, but you can try it before you pass out on something you might be really into.
author: Helen C.

description: Excellent food. Good prices. Friendly and attentive staff. Parking can be a bit hit or miss, but this is par for course in San Francisco. Nice ambiance with chill lighting. As typical I would suggest asking for your meals on separate pages rather than "family style", as you seem to get more food. Definitely worth checking out.
author: Jason W.

description:
Other than visiting the Eire-Trea food truck, I haven't had much exposure with Eritrean cuisine.  So my visit to New Eritrea was a brand new experience for me.  Especially with the concept that there are no utensils and everything is eaten with your bare hands.  Okay, maybe not a completely new concept since I eat burgers and sandwiches with my bare hands.  But this was kind of different because you get served family style.

Zebhi Dorho - Marinated chicken drumsticks simmered in onion, tomatoes, clarified butter and red pepper sauce.
http://bit.ly/ZuWjkQ
Did you see all that food in the pic?  YUM!!  I only picked this because it said on the menu that this was an all-time Eritrean/Ethiopian favorite entree.  I strongly agree!  The chicken was very moist and was easy to pull off the bone, especially since I had to use my hands.  The red pepper sauce had had a nice flavorful kick to it and that went well with the chicken and injera bread.  It also came with hard boiled egg, so overall this was a really protein packed dish.

I had a great time with my first Eritrean restaurant experience and actually had a lot of fun just using my hands to eat up my platter.  It does get messy, but the food was great and I wouldn't mind going back again.
author: Rodney H.

description: Wonderful food, great service, casual but comfortable ambience. Definitely excited to go back!
author: Michael S.

description:
Amazing food, great service.
If you go early enough a reservation is usually never needed.

The ambience is really pretty and the oldschool bar gives the entire restaurant a really cool look.
