Before that I only had Ethiopian food once so I didn't really know what to order. That's why I ordered the Vegetarian Sampler. I ordered rice as a side because I thought I was gonna need it. Bad idea because you really don't need it! You get a huge slice of thin sour-tasting bred that was absolutely delicious. All against the western culture you were actually asked to eat with your hands rather than ordering a fork and a knife. 
Earthing with your hands made the entire experience even more interesting. 

The vegetarian sampler consisted of bread, spinach, potatoes in yellow sauce, spicy lentils and yellow squash. My favorite were definitely the potatoes. But the rest was amazing as well. 

Definitely planning on going there again!
author: Magdalena Victoria B.

description:
I've wanted to try Ethiopian food ever since I saw that Simpson's episode where Marge and the kids become foodies after wandering into an Ethiopian restaurant. 

I made reservations for a party of 6 about an hour before our 6pm dinner on a Sunday evening and it wasn't a problem.  I was looking forward to the meal after speaking with the owner who sounded really friendly over the phone. 

For the 6 of us, we ordered 4 dishes (which was plenty of food) and went family style with one giant platter in the middle of the table. 
1) Zebhi Dorho - (chicken in a tomatoey red pepper sauce) - not ideal for sharing b/c the dish only comes with 2 drumsticks 
2) Kilwa (beef in a red pepper sauce)
3) Vegetarian Combo (lentils, collard greens, and potatoes/carrots) 
4) Vegetarian Allicha (potatoes/carrots) 

Everything was delicious - flavorful, saucy, spicy, and satisfying - and the combination of meat and vegetarian dishes produced a well-rounded meal. The experience of scooping the food up with the spongy injera bread is really fun and I highly recommended doing so, even if it's not really your thing. I can imagine this place being a fun date night with your hubby. The food doesn't look like much when you get it, but in combination with the bread, all of us were stuffed. Overall, great food and wonderful service. 

There were hardly any people at the restaurant when we arrived, but by the time we left at 7:30pm, there were anxious patrons hovering over our table at the front. If you like Indian food, then you'll probably like this place as well. The spices are different, but both cuisines have the same earthy richness to their dishes. This place is definitely worth checking out and was a great change of pace from the typical Asian restaurants that make up Irving!
author: Deanna Y.

description: Was a surprise but happy one. Great lamb and vegetable dishes . Love the bread. Light and spicy. Been there twice now both time great food.
author: Blue B.

description: Outstanding for groups. We needed a reservation for 17 people and they were incredibly accommodating and gave us quick and upbeat service--the server even helped us with a group photo at the end. The food has rich flavors. Their meat dishes are delicious, but you're not losing any flavor by sticking with the vegetarian combo. The staff has a good sense of how many plates you need for any number of people, and they were spot on with our group.
author: AJ P.

description:
I will be back to this place regularly. Sweet as pie staff. Delicious nice food. 

I love the chicken, lamp, vegetarian & sambusa dishes. I basically have never had a bad dish here. My two sons love eating family style with their hands. 

Service is quick & friendly.

Come prepared to eat with your hands & enjoy the experience till every last finger licking bite. Go home happy... Repeat as necessary.
author: Tara P.

description: We came in around 8:30pm on Saturday night, and we were seated right away. We ordered the vegetable sample for two ($24), and it arrived about 15 minutes later. The vegetable dishes were all great - my husband's favorite was the okra, which had some nice spice to it, and my favorite was the collard greens. The injera was the perfect texture and nicely fermented. Great neighborhood spot!
author: Laura M.

description: This was my first time having Eritrean food, and wow it was so good!! Service, food, and atmosphere were all great. I got the veggie platter and my boyfriend got the meat combo. They asked if we would like it on the same plate, which was nice of them to ask. The service was attentive and very friendly. Definitely coming back!
author: Rose Mary W.

description:
What a wonderful neighborhood treasure. This was my introduction to Ertitrean food and it definitely opened my eyes and belly to all-new flavors. The meat combo is delicious if you want a ton of food or a plate to share. My favorite is the vegetarian combo which is so satisfying that even this die-hard carnivore rolls over into a food coma with a dumb grin in his face afterward. 

The owner and staff are attentive and friendly - though weekends can get busy. It is my favorite place for a meal on a rainy winter night.
author: Chris K.

description:
Service: prompt, polite, and friendly.

Food: outstanding flavor and generous portions.  My friend and I shared the Eritrean Special (#16) and the Meat Combo (#11).  Both were perfect and very filling without being fatty or greasy.  Quality meat and flavorful spices.

Anytime I'm in the Inner Sunset, I'll be coming back here!
author: Cody C.

description: Very good food . People who work here are awesome everything about this restaurant is great . We have tried fish, shrimp. Chicken , lamb vegetarian dishes no complaints at all.
author: Nancy K.

description:
Finally got around to trying this place after living nearby for the past 4 years! Beautiful and very large space that you wouldn't expect from the small entrance outside. All the servers are genuinely nice, but service can be a bit slow on a Friday night. Not sure if it was just because we were all really hungry, but it seemed like a very long time before the food came out. But, wow, that food was deeelish when it came out.

My fiancé and I shared the meat combo platter, which appears to be the popular choice, and with good reason! With the airy, spongy Injera bread to scoop and soak up all the sauces and meat, it was fun eating with just our hands! (do make sure obviously to wash your hands before and after eating though).

The lamb platter was alright. Sauce and flavoring was excellent, but the meat was gritty which was a major turn-off.

Oh and if you want strong coffee, and I mean STRONG coffee.. you can definitely get it here!

Would I come back? Definitely. This is a neighborhood treasure that is worth it!
author: Andrew T.

description:
Felt adventurous and decided to try this place. Upon waking in, it looked welcoming and I had a feeling that I skins like this place. I wasn't wrong. Really enjoyed their service, friendly server with a great smile. Food recommendations were spot on, from appetizers to main dishes and drinks. We've order a bit of everything to try, ie combo #11 and #24 with addition of a fish dish #26. Really liked everything and highly recommend these items to those that aren't familiar with this type of food. Don't forget to try their honey wine and lager, especially if you are having their spicy sauce, it will help to put down the fire :) this place is not for those that can't take some spice with their meal
Taking one star off for a dirty restroom. C'mon son, clean that up!
author: Abe L.

description:
I've never had Ethiopian food before, and decided to come here on a whim just to try something different.

Here's the thing: there's no utensils. They give you this sponge-y sour bread like thing and you rip it up and essentially use that to pick up your food with.

If it's your first time, I would recommend getting the meat combination and the vegetarian combination, so you get a taste of everything. And they can adjust the portion depending on how big your group is.

I thought most of all the meat ones were pretty good. And I'm normally just not a huge fan of anything vegetarian, but the flavors were really good. Everything was really flavorful and I actually really like the sourness of the bread wrap thing.

Overall, Ethiopian food reminds me a little of Indian food. It was a cool experience. I don't know how often I would come back for more, but I liked what I tried.
author: Sophia Y.

description: I love Ethiopian food and this place is one of the best I have been to. I had meat and veg dishes, delicious!
author: Nigel J.

description: I love the food here. We usually get takeout (meat combo and veggie combo), though the atmosphere is pleasant. Ethiopian spices are amazing, and this preparation is one of the few ways I truly enjoy vegetables. The staff is friendly and nice. Very happy with this restaurant.
author: James R.

description:
Had been meaning to try New Eritrea ever since I moved into the neighborhood 11 years ago.

But probably won't go back...everything seemed rather flavorless on the vegetarian platter. 

Nothing at all like my first exposure to Ethiopian food lo these many years ago at the now departed Blue Nile on Telegraph in Berkeley. That place was awesome and the food delish. Sigh.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Over the past fifteen or so months since our first visit to New Eritrea, we have dined here some eight times. Every time our meals were tantalizingly tasty, and the service is always excellent. Sadly, we make it here so infrequently that, although we always arrive with other intentions, we always order our two favorites- kitfo and the collard greens. The kitfo is our kryptonite, quite honestly, and is always incredibly fresh and tasty. My GF had spent half her life living in the South, and she prefers the collards here to anything she has ever had before. It's a good thing we live outside the city or this restaurant would become addictive for the both of us!
author: T. K.

description:
TL;DR Reviews!

Pros:
+Meat and vegetable options were very tasty.
+Meat sambusa was very good
+Eat with your hands!
+Great service, always check on you
+Not too crowded, fast seating.

Cons:
-Injera (spongy sour flatbread) was too sour on the mouth after a while (first time eating, and sourness overwhelming)
-Hand eating will end up leaving a mess
-Can be difficult to eat if you don't want to get messy

Tips:
Bring some wet wipes and hand sanitizer!
author: Oliver L.

description: I have been coming to this restaurant with my friends and family for a couple of years now, and it never disappoints. It's family owned, so right when you walk in you're greeted with the biggest, welcoming smiles . The food is delicious and it's the perfect place for me to have a vegan meal alongside my non-vegan fam/friends. If you drink, they have a full bar that includes some East African drinks, like Tusker beer and of course the honey wine (Tej)- which i recommend trying. They can get pretty busy on the weekend evenings, and due the neighborhood/ all the surrounding restaurants parking can take a while to find on a weekend night, but nonetheless its still very much worth it. There's never been a time when the food wasn't great. My favorites are the tumtumo, alicha, and the collard greens (forgot what they're called). My fam really likes the kilwa doro and zebhi doro.
author: Delilah B.

description:
My boyfriend and I come here so often that the really sweet waitress, Yodet, recognizes us the moment we step in. The service is great and the food is amazing. I always get the vegetarian platter and swap out the hamli (collard greens) for shiro (chickpeas). I'm also not a fan of injera so I order rice on the side. 

When New Eritrea was closed for a week last month, we went to Assab on Geary - that was a HUGE mistake. You can't expect the same type of friendly service there. Not only did they forget the dish of someone in our party, they also gave me so much attitude when I asked for rice, I felt bad that I might have offended them. According to the staff here however, there's nothing offensive about asking for rice at an Eritrean spot. That was my punishment for cheating on this place!

If you've never had the food before, try it. And get a bottle of honey wine. SO GOOD.
author: Tracy W.

description:
The service is friendly and efficient. They have a nice little solarium in the back which is ideal to sit since the restaurant has a large bar. 

I thought veggie combo sampler was very good. I would definitely come back to try some different dishes.
author: Derek S.

description: Delicious, good portion size, good ambiance and food doesn't take too long to come. We came at 8pm in a Saturday and we didn't have to wait, which is great. Only downside is it did take a bit of time to place our order but I would definitely go back. In terms of Ethiopian food, I prefer it to Assab and sheba and it's as good as moya (with better prices and location) and oasis!
author: Shruti T.

description:
Initially wanted ramen but the wait was too long so we all decided to eat somewhere else. This place sounded the most interesting and the least expensive. 

The place itself seems pretty nice and the service is nice too. Cozy atmosphere. 

I ordered kitfo (lean beef steak tartar served with collard greens, house made cheese, and salad). I also ordered honey wine because it sounded good. I forgot what my cousin and my friend ordered but I do remember the taste. 

The honey wine came first. It did not taste as sweet as I thought it would be. I guess I was expecting it to taste like mead. I thought it was okay.

My kitfo was really good. It doesn't look like a lot, but it's actually really filling. I think it's because of all the oil in the meat. It says lean beef, but but there was a pool in the little bowl. The flavors were so good though. Eritrean spices! Eritrean spices are pretty much in every dish on the menu. 

Overall great food. Interesting to eat. No utensils! I wouldn't mind going back again.
author: Sofia R.

description: Fantastic tasting food. I has the #5 Beed dish. Definitely worth the effore getting there.
author: James M.

description:
Decent, wholesome Ethiopian food. Not the best I've had, but ok if you're in the area and want some Ethiopian cuisine. 

I ordered the turmeric based lamb and the portions were generous and the lamb was tender. My friends shared the vegetarian platter which comes with 6 different dishes. 

Service is slow and there was a 45min wait on Saturday night!
author: Mary F.

description:
Consistently delicious food, consistently friendly service, consistently good price. Looks a little divey (especially the bathroom), but totally worth going to. Be warned: you will be hooked!

This is probably my most frequented restaurant in San Francisco. Great spot to take friends and visitors. I think that both the meat combo and veggie combo are great ways to taste several items. Once you know your favorites, I'd recommend getting one combo and then your favorite dish too. Also, the veggie platter for 2/3/etc is awesome.

The steamed milk and honey is like drinking heaven!!!!
author: Lowell R.

description: Let's start out with the pros: it's a beautiful little restaurant, we were seated promptly, and the menu has very good variety.  Unfortunately, the service was snail slow.  We decided on our food pretty quickly (the vegetarian platter and a couple other entres, which were fine but nothing special), and then it took maybe 10 minutes for our waitress to take our order (okay, sure, not abnormally slow), but then our food took 45 minutes to get out.   We were eating for about half an hour, and it took 20 minutes for our waitress to clear our plates, and then another 20 minutes for her to drop off our check.  We also had to hunt her down to refill our water.  I'm not sure what the hold up was, but we won't be returning.
author: Sarah P.

description:
This is one of my family's favorite spots in SF to dine and also take our out-of-town guests. The food is delicious...we usually do the meat and veggie combo. For our vegetarian friends, they can serve on a different platter. The service is warm and lovely--you feel like you're part of a family. We brought our 10 month old there and the owner brought out a little dish for him telling us that this is what he fed his girls at this age. 

Anyhow, flavors are amazing, service is stellar and the vibe is very relaxing. We've rarely had to wait for a table but when we do, I don't mind b/c I'm just so happy the place is getting the business it deserves. Haven't been to Eritrea, but eating at this restaurant makes me want to go.
author: Annie T.

description:
A new experience for me and one that I'm glad that I was able to try. I was a bit hesitant at first with the idea of eating with your hands, but it was something new and I'm always down to try something different! Came here on a Friday night. Easy to get a table and the server was nice and helpful in suggesting dishes that would be a good introduction into Ethiopian food. 

We decided on two combo platters and a sambusa. 

vegetable sambusa - It had good flavor and was pretty impressed by it. The accompanying sauce had some spice to it which was pleasant. The only downside was that it was semi-cold in the middle. I guess they didn't heat it up all the way? 

Meat combo:  It was a platter of beef, lamb and chicken. The beef had a good sauce and the injera (flat bread) soaked it up nicely. The lamb was a bit too gamey for me, but was still enjoyable. The chicken was a drumstick in a tomato based sauce with spices.

Vegetable platter: This had 4 separate  portions of lentils, collared greens, potatoes and chick peas. I think the star of the dish was the chick peas and collared greens. Tons of flavor and i liked how you could mix and mash everything together to create a new flavor. 

Good place to go to if you want to try something out of the norm. Just make sure you wash your hands before digging in!
author: Andrew S.

description: Lots of choices (especially for vegetarians).  If you are in a group with people who like to try different foods, you can order a platter with almost all of the vegetarian options for 2, 3, 4, + people and they bring it in a giant platter.  The lentil sambusa were really flavorful--slightly spicy with the sauce and really good.  We ordered several of those (2 per order).  Really nice service and they were nice to the children in our group.  (the kids could run around without being yelled out).    If you haven't had Eritrean food, you basically eat various vegetables/meat that have different sauces with a bread made from teff.  The best ones were the potato one and the one with collared greens.  The mushroom one was spicy.  Prices were reasonable (about $11 a dish) and two would be enough to share for a couple.
author: Jackie K.

description:
This place has great food and friendly, fast, and flexible service, but it's important to note that the atmosphere is kid-heavy and less good for a date.

My boyfriend I went here to have a nice date and enjoyed the amazing honey wine, an appetizer, a meat sampler, and a veggie sampler. All of the food was excellent. Lots of flavors, and a nice presentation. The service was friendly and flexible (as we were hoping to sit a while before our meal).

My only real complaints about this place were about the atmosphere. The back room is a little sterile and the seating and decor didn't match the quality of food. There was also a screaming child in the back for the entire duration of our meal. It seems like this is a place that welcomes  small children and I know that that's something that a lot of people specifically look for, so I don't want to lower my rating on that criteria, but it made it less great for a date spot.
author: Allxie C.

description: This was my second time eating Ethiopian food. The first time was 4 years ago and that experience wasn't great. This one, however was delicious! I like that they leave a glass bottle of water on the table so you don't have to wait for refills and the venue was nicely lit and spaced out. I ordered one of the chicken entrees (not the popular one with drumsticks) but I think the one that came with potatoes. Hard to recall since this was a couple of weeks ago, but the experience was very good and I would like to return again. The service was pleasantly warm and welcoming and the prices were okay ($11+ per meat entree). This experience made me look forward to trying more Ethiopian restaurants and if those fail to impress me, then I know I have this place. The reason I'm not giving this place 5 stars is because my cousin ordered a three meat meal and I disliked every one of his meats (including the popular chicken one). Liking 1/4 of the options I tried isn't very consistent so I can't give a perfect rating. Mine however was great so 4 stars is fair.
author: Kristy F.

description: Delicious with generous portions. Service is great as well. We are addicted to the New Eritrean special kitfo. Rarely a wait, a great go-to neighborhood restaurant.
author: Tina W.

description:
U.S. Representative for California, Dana Rohrabacher once said:

"Next door to Ethiopia spreading out along the strategic Red Sea coastline is Eritrea, a relatively new country, and a place that few Americans seem to fully understand."
 
This is true in my case.  My understanding of Ethiopian and Eritrean culture is minimal and my experience with the food is a blank page.

So walking in I didn't know what to expect.  I met Manna, my server, a very friendly man, native to Eritrea.  I had glanced at the menu before coming and I wanted to try the Meat combination, Kilwa Begee, Dorho, and beef.  

The food came out with the flat bread on the side.  Manna told me I was suppose to eat with my hands.  Hey Manna, you don't have to tell me twice!  Bare hands + food= flavor, in my book.

And it was tasty, kind of chili like in appearance.  The mixture of spicy, wonderful seasoning, and 3 different meaty textures was a hearty meal.  Along with that the plate had some lentil stew and salad. A well rounded dish.  What I was taken back by was the perfect amount of spiciness to really pull out the flavor, oh, plus combined with eating with my bare hands...

Now I understand why Ethiopians also don't need pork.  Because they sure can make lamb, chicken and beef taste delicious, they aren't missing out on anything. 

While I may never fully understand Ethiopia and the surrounding areas.  I do understand and know now, that they eat well.
author: Michael L.

description: 4 stars. I liked it. In fact New Eritrea's food put all our mouths in heaven. Out of everyone in our party's food there was only one thing I didn't like. The restaurant was a little quiet that night, maybe because it was early, but the propietors, Eritreans, are SUPER friendly (and a far cry from Eritrean cabdrivers I've experienced in Washington DC.)  We'll definitely be back to New Eritrea. It may only be open at night. (no insult to New Eritrea or Eritreans but I also like Ethiopian food).
author: Robert F.

description:
Interesting cuisine. You are expected to use your fingers to dip the injera into the veggie and meat plates but utensils are available on request.

The chicken (16) was really well flavored. Ordering two dishes was more than enough for two people.
author: Ryuta O.

description: A great experience with unique flavors and even way of eating. We had the meat combo and the veggie combo, and added the chicken and mushroom. It was all good. Some of the items had a bit of heat, but in a pleasant way, you can choose mild. The chicken mushroom was a favorite with my party, but just barely as it was all so tasty. The slightly tart injera, and lack of utensils was a  fun and unique way to eat. There is really nothing like it. It is great that there is injera on the bottom of the platter to soak up all the flavors. We have just enough injera to get to that, then we start on the bottom ones! Service is very neighborly and friendly. Our server patiently and happily shared knowledge about the culture and foods. Highly recommended.
author: E. W.

description:
First off, there are only a handful of Ethiopian restaurants in SF.  I've recently changed my diet to mostly plant based (not quite vegan). The great thing about Ethiopian food is that you can find something for any diet and everyone leaves happy.  

Needless to say, I was craving lentils, veggies and injera so I made the 20 minute drive out there from Noe. I was happy I did! I ordered food to go (vegetarian combo) and took a seat at the bar while I waited.  I immediately felt at home. The servers were extremely friendly and I was asked several times whether I needed anything.  The portions were generous and the prices are very reasonable.  There is even a sunroom that would be great to rent out if you had a large party, assuming they do that (I didn't ask).  Parking can be a little tough in this area but there is usually a ton of parking on Lincoln Way if you're willing to walk a couple of blocks.  Just be sure to read the signs!

 I'm definitely adding New Eritrea to my list of go-to spots.
author: Antoinette O.

description: BOMBBBB ETHIOPIAN FOOD!!! My first ethiopian cuisine in SF. I ate quite a bit in san diego and in oakland, and this was definitely up to par. For 4 people, we shared the Veggie Sampler and the MEat Sampler. We were stuffed. The service was great too. The waitresses are very smiley and friendly. Can't wait to come back!!!!
author: Annie K.

description: Recently had dinner at New Eritrea and was surprised at how big the place is.The ambiance is nice and the food is really good. My party of 4 ordered everything family style. It is served on a large plate which comes with a sour flatbread. You eat with your hands.I would have given this place 5 stars except I specifically asked if the entree we were ordering had peas in them( I am really allergic to peas) and was told they didn't but I got a bad allergic reaction and I thought the food tasted like peas.So other then that I would recommend.
author: Christopher E.

description: I hate to write a less than stellar review, but I've got to be honest.  I live by Cafe Ethiopia, but I was in the neighborhood & thought I'd give New Eritrea a try. I ordered both the veggie combo & a meat combo. Not impressed.  Flavors are rather bland & just not delicious. Price is OK, but I'll stick with Cafe Ethiopia.
author: Emily S.

description:
I've been to a few Ethiopian restaurants in the city, but this is far and away my favorite spot. Add to the fact that it's a MUNI ride away from the Sunset and it's a heavyweight contender for the top spot. 

The food here is straight up, no BS, no frills, amazing. AND FAST.

If you were to go to Ethiopia and befriend a local who had a wife or mom that was an amazing cook, this is the type of food you'd eat. 

It's consistently awesome - the true benchmark of an amazing chef. Hats off to whomever is cooking back there. 

My mouth waters just thinking about it and if you and your date like eating with your hands, you're going to have an amazing experience. Try the combos so you can sample a myriad of things. 

Also, if there's a sporting event and all of the regular bars are packed to the gills, this is where you want to go. Fantastic finger food, great company, and they have a full bar. 

This is where I'll be when the Superbowl or World Cup happens next.
author: Byron E.

description: It was great food. We tried the veggie combo which was awesome. Blend of 3 different types of Ethiopian food. Very nice service !!
author: Santosh L.

description: Parts are good parts not so good. The special spicy outdo was the best ever. The dals mushy. Super sour injera like I like. Good service.
author: Carol m.

description: Food and service are both great. I came with a large group for a friend's birthday and ate family style. The staff were very accommodating and patient with us.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Very good Ethiopian food. We got the #10 Alicha Begee lamb, Kitffo beef tartar and vegetarian combo dish. Everything had a wide range of spices and was savory. The injera was flavorful - just the right amount of spongy and sourness to complement the dishes. 

The meat was all good quality, the lamb was juicy and tender and the beef tartar was very moist. The service was very prompt and helpful. My favorites are always the veggie dishes and these were no disappointment. The collards were very flavorful and  savory, and the lentils were also plump and well spiced.
author: Tiffany S.

description: Reasonably priced, an interior with character, friendly service, and let's not forget that Ethiopian food is delicious.  One of our go-to's when we're in the mood for something a little out of the usual routine. Very relaxed setting, and easily accessible via the 44-O'Shaughnessy and N-Judah :-)
author: A.J. F.

description:
It's really fun to have a silver platter of meats in the middle of the table, and have everyone just dig in with their hands. I thought the Kilwa Begee (lamb)  was really good. It had a rich sauce, and the spices gave it a nutty quality that paired well with the lamb's slight gaminess. Even though I'm a native of this city, I don't really enjoy sourdough, but I thought the Injera bread was good, spongy, and not too sour for my tastes. 

The honey wine seems to polarize a lot of people, but I'm all about it. I like sweet Muscat dessert wines, so I guess it makes sense that the honey wine works for me too.
author: Nei N.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!

This is one of my favorite restaurants. Family-run (very friendly) and delicious (spicy!) food. If you like spicy food, you will love this restaurant. 

My favorite dishes are the meat combination and the kitfo. Their vegetable & lentil sides are also fantastic. If you like okra, come here. The injera is fresh an pleasantly sour. 

Try the sambusa appetizers and the sweet honey wine (tej)!
author: Anna G.

description:
Wow, just wow! 

First off, I want to thank the owner and staff for making our group's dining experience (went from 12 people to 15 midway) so great. Thanks for being so accommodating and for providing people with delicious food and friendly service during Saturday dinner rush. I hope you guys liked the cakes and icecream I made :)

Let me just start with a little background: emailed the restaurant via their website to set up a reservation. Their online reservation system is a bit off, as you can only reserve in increments of five people, but forget all that. If you want a reservation, just call them. The young man who answered the phone was so nice. He double-checked everything and when asked questions he was kind enough to find out the answers for me if he didn't know. Genuinely a sincere experience that gave me a great impression. I was reserving for 12 people and asked if it was OK for me to bring cakes and icecream to celebrate two birthdays (because, as I'm sure most of you guys know, some new popup hipster restaurant will say no if you don't use milk from your own organic beer-fed and hand-massaged cow). Not only was it perfectly acceptable, but they proactively told me that they could provide disposable plates if needed and that they would store the cakes and ice cream for me. 

Now, on to dinner: parking was a pain, so most of the people got there about an hour late. The staff never rushed us (the people already seated) and were so patient. If it were my restaurant I think I'd be pretty PO'd. They have a full bar so some of our crew opted to get drinks there and all were very satisfied with the quality. The food was delicious. We got both vegetarian platters and combo meat platters for our group, and the amount was perfect. It was an almost even split between guys and gals, and everyone loved the food. I personally preferred the vegetarian selection because you can really taste the different flavors better than the meats, but the meat options were just as yummy.

When it was cake time the owner cleared off a little space so that my friend and I could prepare and light the candles. He gave us matches and when we couldn't get the matches to light, he got new ones and helped light them for us. Keep in mind, this was all during a Saturday night dinner stretch! All with such a friendly demeanor! Seriously, the best service I've encountered in SF!

Our group was there til closing and we didn't even know it. The owner and staff just let us stay. We didn't realize that the whole restaurant was empty until about a half hour after they officially closed. 

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this place for birthdays :D
author: Jamie C.

description:
My husband and I recently ate here, and the whole time we were lamenting the fact that we have lived a block away from this restaurant for a whole year now and had never been (though we've talked about going many times).

What it really boils down to is, the photos simply don't describe how flavorful the food really is. The presentation is traditional but not the kind of thing that photographs well, so even though the reviews all rave about it, looking at the pictures was never terribly inspiring, and we always ended up going elsewhere. However, having now been, I would most definitely go back--and I'm sure we will.

We tried the meat and vegetarian samplers so that we could try everything. It was a really good choice. The flavors just blew me away. My favorites were the--I don't know if it was spinach or okra--it was green for sure!--and the lamb and beef, but everything was good. Loved the injera too, and it is fun to eat with your hands! There were two lentil-type dishes on the vegetarian side, which were tasty but less potent in terms of flavor/spice. The spices in the greens were really mind-blowing. The spices in the meats were amazing.

The service was great--very friendly, warm, welcoming, helpful, attentive. The ambiance was nice--homey, nothing fancy, but it felt clean, organized, attractive. 

I definitely regret not trying this place sooner and look forward to going back!
author: Jennie S.

description:
Update, I still love this place, but I think you would do better if you made the injera gluten-free, maybe increasing price minimally. The only thing that stops me from eating there more often is that I have to call before 2PM to be able to request gluten-free injera. Since injera is traditionally gluten-free, why not just make it all that way? I am pretty sure that just this small change would lead to even more frequent and happy customers.

Love this place - thank you for all your delicious vegan selections. I could eat here everyday. My only complaint is that parking can be tricky. Can you open up a restaurant off of Ocean Avenue? I'd be there every day!
author: Michelle S.

description:
My son has had dinner over a friends house who is from Ethiopia and he swears the flavors and textures here are on par with home made dinners.  We ordered the vegetarian platter for 2 and loved the injera with its slightly sour taste.  

Certainly coming back.
author: Dude D.

description:
Family style atmosphere with mirrors EVERYWHERE that make you feel like you're in that Justin Timberlake mirrors music video.

It was my first time trying Eritrean food and I personally was not blown away by the flavor s. However, the service was FRIENDLY AND ON POINT, and I think everyone should try Eritrean food at least once. I actually really liked the chicken
author: Yan Y.

description: Food was amazing. It's mostly gone now, lol. Fantastic blend of different vegetables and curries! Very affordable, definitely a must for anyone visiting San Francisco!
author: Brent E. J.

description: Really amazing food! We got the veggie platter for 2 and sambusas and they were excellent! Great price for the amount of food. Some of the best Ethiopian food I have had! The service was great and the owner was very friendly!
author: Lucy B.

description:
The food was done authentically, I'm sure. However, it wasn't to my taste. We ordered the 5 person platter but asked the waiter to modify it with some meat. He did so. The lamb was a little gamier than I expected. The chicken was good but not very extra ordinary. The spicy beef was the best. The vegetarian options were pretty mild.

The restaurant is a good addition to variety of food in SF. Everyone should try it themselves to come up with their own opinion.
author: Foo L.

description: This is one my favorite restaurants in the Inner Sunset. The food is delicious (I highly recommend the lentil sambusa) and the service is wonderful.
author: Monica K.

description: I've been coming to this place for the last 13 years as I live in the neighborhood and love Ethiopian and Eritrean food. I'm vegetarian so I almost always get the veggie sampler to share so we can have a little bit of everything. My favorites are the Hamli/collard greens and okra stewed with tomatoes and spices. There's a good level of spice to most of the dishes but not too much. The owners and staff are super friendly and the decor and ambiance are classic. I hope this place doesn't go away!
author: Anne T.

description:
Delicious food, a warm environment, and a gracious staff!  AMAZING place to eat!!! 

Ohhh... the food is SO GOOD!!!  And the honey wine is a perfect compliment to the food. 

We recently held a large family celebration here and everyone had a marvelous time!!!  They really went out of their way to make the celebration special and I thank them sincerely for their thoughtfulness and generosity .  

You guys are the best!!!
author: Leira W.

description:
I have, alas, been spoiled by the great Ethiopian places in the East Bay, so my grading standards are a bit higher for this cuisine. Our goodie platter (technical term) was, while perfectly edible, a monotonous blend of chunks of different meat kibbles in sauce. Granted we ordered two meat items, but they should have added some veggies to the mix beyond the lettuce leaves in the middle. Just like they do it over in O-town, yo. It did have a tasty chicken leg though. 

NERB offers genuinely friendly service, and they seemed to know many of their customers by name. But since I wouldn't personally go back, three stars is as high as I can go.
author: Nick C.

description:
Sorry New Eritrea, Ethiopian food is not for me or my family. I feel terrible giving one star but I am just voicing my opinion. Coming with my family, I was so excited to come and try a new cuisine. The portions looked huge, the dishes were service family style in a huge plate, and you use injera (flat bread) to dip in the dishes. Ordered the House Sampler-Vegetarian Combo for three, Kilwa, and Zebhi Dorho. And a cup of honey wine. With a name like honey wine, I expected the sweetness of moscato but it tasted like Halls Honey Cough Drops. The huge platter arrived and we each received an injera. I originally thought that we would need to order more injera but after tasting it, I decided against this idea. All of the vegetarian dishes are sour, really sour. The injera is also sour, so it is sour on sour. Not for me. Tried to finish as fast a possible so I could go home and eat something sweet. 

What I recommend:
-- Zebhi Dorho
author: Andrew W.

description: If you like Ethiopian cuisine, you should come here. On a Sunday night, it was packed! The food is delicious and priced reasonably. We got the veggie combo (lentils, chickpeas, collard greens, and cabbage/potatoes) and the catfish entree to share, family style. Everything was served on a metal platter with a piece of injera at the bottom, and each of us got our own injera as well. Trust me, it doesn't look like a lot of food, but you will be filled up. Great place for your Ethiopian cravings!
author: Sherry L.

description: I come here quite often with my friends, sometimes just to get honey wine. 1 bottle is $20 & when shared between 4 people, it's a pretty good deal. Granted, I've ordered 2 bottles between just 2 people because it's an amazing time. I love how sweet the wine is and how it's shipped over from Oakland. When it comes to food, I haven't tried enough to give a good enough review but from what I've seen, everything has large portions & the quality looks superb. The atmosphere is very calm, great for the 20's and older crowd & feels rather homey when you're inside. I love coming here and feel like I will continue to come here with my friends as long as the business keeps running!
author: Kai S.

description:
This place gets 5 starts for being consistently excellent in service, quality, cost and speed over several years of eating here. Since I don't want to drive to Oakland every time I get a craving for Kitffo, I have tried every East African restaurant I could find in the city looking for something comparable.
 I keep coming back here. 
I always get the raw Kitffo and each time it is even better than I remember- how could it keep getting better?! Don't worry, I've never gotten sick, they use quality product and have a sanitary kitchen. I have visited enough that I have tried almost everything on the menu and it is consistently good with most dishes being excellent. 
The staff is always polite and welcoming. Even when I started bringing my rambunctious infant son (who broke a plate on his first ever visit) they still treat us like they can't wait to have us back. They have plenty of high chairs and seem to enjoy families (rather than loathe them the way many SF restaurants do). I have never been disappointed in the food, and finding that I am still a valued customer despite my recent procreation is a bonus.
author: D M.

description:
Had a great meal here with our toddler which doesn't happen that often;-)!

We came here without a reservation, but they were able to seat us relatively quickly.  The hostess and wait staff were so friendly and accommodating with our little one.  And the food was reeeeally good.  Highly recommend the meat papusas to start.  My husband had the honey wine and said it was much better that most honey wines he had had at other Ethiopian places.  

The atmosphere is casual and family friendly.  Kind of feels like an old pizza parlor with the bar and lighting, but that gives it a warm feel.  There's a big room in the back that would be great for private events.
author: Joy O.

description: Amazing and delicious food with vegan options, awesome service and great prices. Total hidden gem!
author: SF Dweller G.

description:
Well-priced for portions and attentive service. My friend and I ordered the Meat Combo and the Vegetarian Combo. Meat dishes separately were around $11 and vegetarian dishes around $9, so having a three-in-one order for $12 and $11 sounded like a good and convenient idea! On top of that, we ordered a bottle of honey wine. Very sweet initially but it pairs perfectly with the spiced Ethiopian foods. Pours about 4 glasses, well worth the 20 bucks.

For those who can't spicy, #6 Zigni has a bit of heat. Just ask for some yogurt and you'll be fine :)
author: Joanna H.

description:
New Eritrea Restaurant holds a special place in my heart. The owner is so nice, he's like a friend now because he always recognizes my girlfriend and I and really takes the time to greet us and talk to us. He knows we love his food. Who wouldn't? Its so good! Honestly, I comes here all the time because of the sambusas, Hamli (collard greens and spinach), Kantisha (spicy mushrooms), Asa Kilwa (fried catfish) and Kitfo (raw ground beef). Every single one of those dishes, especially the Kitfo are something everyone has to experience. This place isn't just something special because its Eritrean, its one of the best around. If you're new to Eritrean food, this is a good place to start. So much flavor you'll be quick to embrace the fact that you're eating with your hands. And you wouldn't want it any other way! 

Another small tip. Order a drink! They have a full bar. One time we asked for "something special" for a birthday and it was amazing. I don't know if I should have said that, but wow it really should be a thing.
author: Dexter H.

description: The food is delicious and it's possible to get non-spicy stuff if you're a wimp like me! Kenya lager is awesome and nice switch up from the standard Ethiopian lagers...also they have a full bar
author: Sonya Z.

description: I came here with my boyfriend last night, and we shared a lamb entree & vegetarian platter. We are both HOOKED! I am pretty certain we'll be returning weekly (if not more than that!) Clean food, perfectly cooked with delicious spices and complimented with the spongy injera to wrap it all up in - MMMM! And when the juices of the lamb & veggies get soaked up into the injera at the bottom of the plate - OMG!!! It's just too good! I will say that I usually prefer my lamb a bit more moist than how this restaurant serves it, but otherwise, everything was just TOPS!
author: Janice L.

description: Strangely enough I was craving Ethiopian food after an exhausting day of riding.  Came here extremely sore and hungry and it was certainly a spicy and filling choice.  Ordered the vegetarian platter and every bite was savory and memorable.  Trying hard to be aware of all the different spices and herbs and be appreciative of every delicious bite of potatoes and collard greens paired with the perfect bite of injera.....While enjoying my amazing food I was kindly waited on by the staff there making sure that  I'm satisfied and taken care of.  This is food that touches my soul.....
author: Sharon N.

description:
So, I never really knew Eritrean was basically like Ethiopian food...

I basically chose this place for my vegan friend, and it's close proximity to my house. I've seen a ton of people crowd it's doors every time I walked by, and I'm glad I finally got to try it out. 

Let's get this straight, if you don't like eating with your hands, this place isn't for you. Yes, you can ask for a fork, but they don't give you anything but a napkin when you sit down. We ordered the vegetarian platter for two and the lentil appetizer. 

The appetizer came out promptly and tasted delicious. It's basically lentils in a pastry shell. It's very savory, mostly due to it being fried, something I'd love to get again. Our main course came soon after and to explain it, it's like 6 piles of slop on top of their dosa like bread. Each person also gets their own bread to use to rip and pick at your meal. I'm not too sure what pile was which, but they all tasted delicious. I'd recommend the okra, which is a bit spicy, and the potatoes. 

They don't serve dessert here, but I was pretty full off my meal when I left. The ambiance of the restaurant is weird, since it also has a full bar when you enter. The waitress and everyone there is really nice as well. I would love to go again and try other things next time!
author: Andrew T.

description: Fantastic food, wonderful flavors, friendly service and honey wine!
author: Christina K.

description: Had such a pleasant first-time experience of Ethiopian culture and food!! Cozy and neat family owned restaurant, excellent service and people here are super nice! They give you great recommendations especially if you are a first timer!
author: Fanny Z.

description: I like this spot, it's not overwhelmed with SFers and it's relaxing. The service is excellent and the food is always tasty. The samosas are a little greasy but so delicious. The Kilwa Dorho, though very tasty was a little too spicy for me (I like mild), but it comes with a healthy serving of salad and plenty of injera (bread). Leave some room for steamed milk with honey.
author: Naomi K.

description: This place is amazing. My husband is Ethiopian and I am very familiar with the food. The food is delish, the servers are attentive and friendly. The portions are huge. The actual restaurant is very spacious, clean and nicely decorated. 5 Stars all the way!!! Highly recommend! We will come back often.
author: Mariama G.

description:
I found this restaurant because I googled Ethiopian food and didn't even notice that the restaurant is called New Eritrean lol. I suppose they just put their category down as "Ethiopian" because it's the closest thing.

But anyway, this was my first time trying Eritrean food. It's pretty similar to Ethiopian, which isn't surprising because they share a border. We got their meat combo and the kilwa begee, and each item tasted really good. The kilwa begee was our favorite. My only complaint is that the injerra was cold and a little hard, but maybe that's how Eritreans make it? They also only gave the two of us two large pieces, when you definitely need at least 2 pieces a person to eat all of that.

And of course, do get their honey wine. You can also find it at Ethiopian places, so I get it everytime.
author: Paola R.

description:
SO GOOD! 

I had never eaten Ethiopian food before but this place was so tasty and the staff were so friendly! I had read a few Yelp reviews before coming and was curious about the honeywine. The waiter let me try a little before I ordered it just to see if I liked it! 

My boyfriend and I came pretty hungry and ordered the meat combination plate and the vegetable combination plate. Both were amazing! It comes with 2 pieces of injera bread which was awesome. The bread is tangy and spongy and soaks up the great spices of the meat and vegetables. Needless to say we were both so full by the end. 

The staff checked on us a few times and really wanted to make sure we were enjoying it. 

We will definitely be returning to this place!
author: Jenn A.

description:
The gored gored is the best! Really good if you have large parties since it is family style

also be prepared to eat with your hands! It gets pretty messy

Staff are so friendly and really know their stuff I totally recommend this place to anyone who is down to try new things
author: Stephanie M.

description: LOVE! So good for vegans! We make a pilgrimage every year for a loved ones' birthday. We love it so. Highly recommend the veggie sambusas! Yum.
author: M. B.

description:
Dined here on Friday with a friend and we really enjoyed it. Nice decor, friendly and helpful service, and the food came out right away -- all tasted very fresh and wonderfully spiced. We went with the lamb and beef options, along with some vegetables, and were both comfortably full by the end of our meals (we shared everything). Also liked the small but well-priced wine menu -- the pinot noir they offer is very enjoyable! 

Definitely recommend this lovely place for dining out with 2-4 people. Looking forward to my next visit!
author: Justine M.

description:
First off, they have a full bar, which i haven't seen in many Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurants so they automatically scored points with me!  The menu is not in Amharic but they have Doro tibs and such, it's just called something different.  (It would be nice if they could put both terms).  The ambiance is very nice and the staff is lovely.

I was really excited because they have okra, which is hard to find.  The food was all very tasty.  I am giving one star mainly because i had to pay for more injera (although only a buck or two)...not a big deal but annoying, particularly since they don't start you out with much.  However, that is not enough of an issue to keep me from going back.
author: Angela R.

description:
Oh man! I came here 4 years ago with my buddies yearning to try something "exotic" and "adventurous." At New Eritrea we got exactly what we wanted. 

The food was exciting and a brand new experience for all of us, as we were supposed to use our hands to eat all of the ingredients, both wet and dry. To make it a little less messy, they give you these pieces of bread that feel as fluffy as thin pancakes with a flavor similar to a subtle sourdough bread which you can use to scoop up the saucy meats and vegetables. 

It was a fresh experience 1) eating with our hands and 2) having everyone constantly fishing around in the same plate at the middle of the table. It's a really nice, intimate way of sharing food that truly puts the focus of the conversation on appreciating the meal and sharing it with each other. It's like a more intimate spin on our Western concept of "family style." 

Anywho, everything tasted great and wasn't overly spiced or bland. The ingredients tasted fresh, from the lamb, chicken, and beef (do they have all of that in Eritrea?) to the vegetables and bread that came with it. 

All in all, I think New Eritrea is the perfect, safe place for the curious American to dive into more exotic flavors and styles of eating without diving straight into anything too extremely foreign.
author: Stephen D.

description:
I found my solo dining visit to New Eritrea to be such a comfortable and pleasant experience, that despite having to basically waddle home (their spongy bread definitely expands in your stomach) after my meal, I often find myself wistfully contemplating return visits here.

New Eritrea has a sincere vibe. It's got mellow inviting lighting, a casual bar area, and family style wooden seating, which makes it a great spot for groups.

Their prices are pretty reasonable and their dishes are ideal for sharing. I only sampled the mixed vegetarian plate here, which was extremely filling and consisted of a sampling of lentil beans, collard greens and spinach , and a seasoned mixture of potatoes, carrots, cabbage, and chickpeas. While I thoroughly enjoyrf my meal, I did wish that some of the sample size dishes had more flavor and spices. 

If you're looking for a laid-back family style place with quality rice home-cooked food - New Eritrea is a fantastic spot. You can sip on honey wines, while gathering up delectable veggie goodness in massive servings of injera bread. They even have some great vegan options.

And if you're by yourself and just looking for a hospitable warm place to fill you up - you definitely can't go wrong with this spot. Just make sure that you eat slowly and savor the food. Your stomach will thank you later.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I finally managed to convince my vegetarian parents that they NEEDED to try Ethopian/Eritrean/East African food. We headed to New Eritrea Restaurant to check out the scene at this very friendly, cute, dive-y restaurant in the Inner Sunset. 

We ordered the following items:
- Vegetable sambusa
- Lentil sambusa
- Meat sambusa
- Vegetarian combo (which came with tumtumo, hamli, vegetarian allicha, alicha-ater) 

It was the first time that I tried sambusa, which I would equate to an Indian samosa or a Latin empanada. They were slightly oily, but definitely tasty!

I have to say that I think New Eritrea was more expensive than Assab (which I have also tried and love), because New Eritrea charges per person rather than per platter on the combo dishes. 

, the food was fabulous and the service impeccable! I love, love, love East African food!
author: Mansi A.

description: So, I've been back a few times after this review. The owner now welcomes me with a smile and recognizes me; makes me feel all warm and fuzzy. The food has definitely improved over time, and now I think it's the best Ethiopian in the SF area (the East Bay may have better ones, but this is the best we got). The Ethiopian honey wine, while sweet, goes very well with the spicy food. This is my go-to place for Ethiopian now.
author: A J.

description: My friends and I shared the Vegetarian Platter, and it was SO tasty! We also ordered the Gored Gored beef, which was delicious, especially the way the injera underneath the entree was saturated in amazing sauce and spices from the beef. Great food! I look forward to returning!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
When you dine here, expect big, delicious portions.  Ordering the vegetable plate had so many amazing dishes that I couldn't pick just one!  Each one was better then the first.  

The one thing I did not like, which came highly recommended was the honey wine.  Yuck! I love honey and I love wine.  However, I couldn't take more of a few sips of this popular beverage before ordering a Diet Coke to wash the taste away.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I've never been a fan of Ethiopian food (the only Ethiopian food I've actually enjoyed was in Uganda) but the food here is delicious. And it's close to my home in the Sunset. 

Plus, a Tusker in SF? Brought back a lot of good memories of living in East Africa.
author: Devy E.

description:
Pros:
- I got to eat with my hands.
- Ordered #1 (Sambusa stuffed with ground beef), #11 (meat combo of #6, #8, and #10--chicken, beef, and lamb), #13 (tartar ground beed w/ house-made cheese).  
- Filled me up fast as the meal started to feel a little heavy after several bites.
- Honey wine was very good (apparently it has a bit of Brandy in it so there's a kick to it)

Cons:
- None that I can state right now.  Hmm...maybe they should have 1 wet-nap to hand you instead of handful of paper napkins...?
author: Wendy T.

description: Good stuff here.  The location is a bit tough to find parking for but the food is quite tasty and full of spices. I ordered take out one night and the food was still hot when I got home 20 minutes later.The New Eritrean Special (Chicken with mushrooms) and Kilwa (beef) were both very good.  We also had the okra, which was so so.  I ended up adding sauteed chicken to it the next day for another meal.  With that said, there was a good amount of food with each order, which includes the flatbread, side of mashed lentils, and a simple salad.  There was enough food for the two of us for about three meals.  Total was a little less than $40.  This is the closest place to get Ethiopian (style) food in the outskirts of SF and Daly City.
author: Alice L.

description:
New Eritrea is tucked away in the Inner Sunset near golden gate park. They boast a full bar and fantastic food with friendly service to boot! I especially liked the Kilwa Begee (lamb). New Eritrea also offers 100% vegan friendly options that also taste great! The house sampler is a great option for those vegan eaters out there.  

2.5/5 Keto rating: to stay keto I'd avoid the injera [which is like eating indian with out the naan very difficult :( ] and also avoid dishes made from beans and potato. Most meat dishes are safe, however its pretty hard to get full of just the entree with no injera and the food is a little bit pricy.
author: Kevin S.

description:
This place is cool because it's fairly unique.  The atmosphere is very zen.  I ate here years ago and remember the food being slightly better but it was still pretty good.  A friend and I split the veggie platter and the meat platter to get a little taste of a lot.  The collard greens were tops the potatoes were not that good (only thing that didn't get finished). Everything else was pretty good but not crazy.  
Service was very friendly.  
I will eat here again but I hope its better next time.
author: David G.

description:
Disclaimer: I've only been to two ethiopian restaurants- I'm not a huge fan of ethiopian food BUT I like this place!


It's also a good restaurant if you're into family style dining but frankly, I feel like they give you more if you order them separately instead of having it all served on a single platter. 

All the dishes have good descriptions on the menu so that alone should give you a good sense of whether or not you'd like a particular dish over the other (I like spicy food so I looked for a dishes with a slight kick). If that fails, go for the combo platter. 

Spongy sour bread? Gives me the goosebumps if I stare at it too long but I try to ignore it by drowning each piece in the delicious mix of curry-based like chicken and veggies. 

If you're unsure about ethiopian or want to be spontaneous, I think this is the best place to test it out. I've been here a total of 4 times- never had to wait for a table and good for groups. Servers are attentive. Now go anti-bac or wash your hands and be prepared to dig in.
author: Patricia K.

description:
First time going there tonight with co-workers, definitely won't be the last.

Went on a Monday, called the same day right when they opened to ensure they could accommodate us since I was told it was a pretty small place (true, but not tiny).  Talked to a man over the phone who was very nice, said I had 12 people, said we would be there at 6:30, he said they could take us no problem.  Our party turned out to be 10 and they did not hassle us about it.  Everyone also did not arrive at the same time (some came early, some on time, some late) and despite this those who were early/on time were still seated.

We took a long time - A LONG TIME (I want to say 30 minutes) - to decide on appetizers and entrees.  I felt our servers (we had 2, one man and one woman; the man was the person I spoke to on the phone) were getting a little impatient, but that's understandable and they were not rude or snappy with us at all; they were, in fact, EXTREMELY NICE. Example: There is this hot (as in spicy) spread ("spread"...not sure what to call it) that comes with the appetizers we ordered. Two words: 

HELLA GOOD. 

So good "HELLA GOOD" deserved it's own line (it was a mix of ginger, garlic, chili powder, andsomethingelseidon'trememberbutitdoesn'tmatterbecauseit'sallmagicalandwonderfulmixedtogetheranyways). 

After we finished our appetizers I was scraping the ramekins for the remainder of the spread ("spread") and was licking the spoons.  When the female server came to collect the empty plates I protested when she picked up the ramekins and she replied: "But they're empty.  You want me to bring you a new one?" 

MY FACE LIT UP LIKE TIMES SQUARE, THE VEGAS STRIP, AND TOKYO COMBINED. 

I felt like a winner. 

I asked our male server later if they sold it in jars.  He said no, lots of customer before have asked the same thing, and they were considering it, but as of now - no.  A sad, sad no. 

We ordered HELLA FOOD.  7 entrees total, I believe.  Plus the appetizers.  Plus two bottles of wine (the honey wine and a white wine, which we discovered were quite good mixed together).  $217 total before tip.  

I'm not much of a foodie, so describing the food with nuance and accuracy.....sorry, can't do - ask someone with a more refined palate for that one.  However, my non-sophisticated tongue was quite pleased, for whatever that's worth.  The LAMB, though...#s 9 + 10 are both lamb...I forget the names, I forget which one is which...but the SAUCY ONE - not the drier one - THE SAUCY ONE.  

My IJUSTLIKEFOOOOOOOD taste buds give that dish a resounding HELL YEAH.

Overall, really great food, really great service.  I'm gonna go Wiki Eritrea now.......
author: Kristen S.

description:
My friend and I split the vegan platter. I'm a meat-eater and i was totally happy.

Also, the service was REALLY friendly.
author: Wil S.

description:
Delicious! I love their beef tartar plus the meat combination. Two people will aways walk away full with that order, and it could probably stretch to three people. The honey wine is a great accompaniment as well.

Note: this style of food does get messy and not everyone will like it. You have a spongy thin bread that you scoop everything with to eat. No utensils, except maybe if you ask.
author: Krista J.

description:
The ambiance has a relaxed vibe. Unfortunately (at least on this trip) that means that anyone wanting a nice dinner is out of luck. 

Apparently relaxed vibe here means that this place is family friendly. By that I'm alluding to the very loud children that were welcomed into the restaurant on my visit. 

If you want any kind of quiet or intimate conversation you won't find it here, at least I didn't. If this is a regular occurrence, you definitely won't get any kind of pleasant dinner or nice environment here. It sounded more akin to Chucky cheese going ons in the front of the restaurant.  Now mind you, I understand a child's behavior is a great reflection on the parenting. There was a child closer to me that was completely unheard. You would not even have known she was there but to glance over and see her. But the other family, that was a different story. And for the restaurant to allow such behavior to continue, apparently that's the crowd they want.
I'm only taking them down a bit for this since they don't choose dinners. But they do choose who stays. It was akin to the drunkard whose had one to many at a bar and is now bothering the patrons. Maybe you didn't invite him in. But you can cut him off and ask him to leave.


Now on to the food...

The food was delicious. I've always wanted to try Ethiopian food, and i was not disappointed.

I opted for the veggie combo. It allowed me to try a few different things as one dinner. The flavors were homey and delicious. Reminiscent to the best stew you've ever had. So delicious.
The flavors were not strong or over powering. More comfort food style.

I always thought the bread stuff that works as your spoon would be more like naan. Instead it is thinner and has less flavor. I don't mean this in a bad way.It allows the dishes to stand out on their own. More like the casing to a French crepe. It's not exactly like that, but the best I can describe it. There is a large piece provide for your meal. Additionally, your meal is served on top of one of these bread pieces. So you have more than plenty to eat your meal.

Overall the food was delicious. I wish those horrible children hadn't ruined the experience. But there were several families coming in with children.... So it's hard to assume this was really unusual.

Nevertheless, this was a good experience with Ethiopian food. Maybe it was just an off day... So I will likely be visiting again, and will update the review when I do.
author: Zoe D.

description:
I came here with a large group, which made ordering quite a bit easier, since we could get large samplers and try a lot of different things.
I was a huge fan of all of the dishes we ordered, including the Kilwa, Alicha Begee, Hamli, and Tumtumo.  I also loved the slightly sour flat breads that are basically like crepes.  
A good place to go with a larger group so you can really sample everything.
author: Max L.

description:
I have never tried out Ethiopian cuisine before, so this review might be subject to change, but...

My taste buds seemed to like it.

I ordered the vegetarian sampler combo for two (completely vegan), as well as the tej. Mmmm. My mom and I are certainly not experts on the quality of injera bread, but it seemed pretty good to us! We loved everything except the collard greens. They were just "meh." If I were hungry enough, maybe I would've tried some more, but the remainder of the dish was filling enough.

Teff (the stuff traditionally used for injera bread) expands in the stomach, so in due time, you'll start to feel the effects of eating a hearty Ethiopian meal.

The staff was very nice and friendly, and if I ever come back to the area, I would visit again!
author: Katie-Rose N.

description: 5 of us went here and ordered the vegetarian for 3 people + one order of house special chicken and we still had left overs! They give plenty of food for an affordable price. Would def return !!
author: Ss S.

description: This is my favorite restaurant. After going vegan I have been eating at this place at least once a week. We are usually waiting outside right before 4pm waiting for it to open. The server is so nice also. She knows what we order and always helps us with the order. The House Sampler platter is our favorite. You get all the best vegetarian items! When I ate meat, I tried their lamb, chicken, and shrimp, those were great also! This is a must try place. Very tasty!
author: Arti L.

description:
Am pregnant and had a ridiculous craving for Ethiopian food, so turned to Yelp when I couldn't get over it. Found New Eritrea and couldn't believe it was so close to home. Hopped in the car and headed straight over. It was delicious! Had been hungry for a traditional vegetarian plate, which is what I ordered plus a side of shiro. The servings were huge and the flavors even better than expected. Came home and told my partner that he'd be making future trips for me for takeout :).

Oh, and service was delightful!
author: Lisa L.

description:
First Ethiopian restaurant (and now my favorite) that I've ever been to.

Get one of the combos, I recommend chicken. The spices they used are delicious and the injera bread is great for soaking up all the juices.

Try the honey wine too! So yummy.
author: Mary M.

description:
I love Ethiopian food and wanted to check this place out. First impressions; good size restaurant and seating area is nice. They have the place setup with a bar counter, which I didn't mind, but the presence of a TV in a restaurant discourages me from going back there.

The food is excellent. The menu is good and my girlfriend and I had no trouble swapping a dish within the vegetarian combo meal. Asking for more injara was pleasant and hassle-free. 

Service is really friendly.
author: Joel J.

description: Did not enjoy our dinner at this restaurant as much as other Ethiopian style restaurants. The kiawa beef was very chewy, almost inedible. The vegetable sampler was tasty, but a little cold. Also the injera bread was served cold, which isn't as good as when served warm. Dining area was fairly run down.
author: Joshua P.

description: From the people that work there to their food...Best experience ever.I have never tried Ethiopian food and was skeptical about it at first,But after my experience here I will never have second thoughts about Ethiopian food!!! The Sambusas are A MUST HAVE.Enjoyed every last bite. Great hospitality and they give you the option of having Family style or for just one.Will be coming back,hungry for more.
author: Charlie B.

description: Amazing food and staff!  We enjoyed a wonderful vegan meal with friends here.  The staff was friendly and helpful, and the restaurant was clean and welcoming. It was also really busy, but that didn't affect the quality of the food or service.
author: Dee B.

description:
This is our favorite Eritrean restaurant in the Bay Area - and we have been to many.  My husband and I have been going here since the late 90s.  3 kids later this place is still our go to Eritrean restaurant.  We went last night after not having been there in awhile and it reminded me why I love this place so much.  The owner is always warm and welcoming; and even if we have not been there in awhile he always remembers us.  We had a party of 11 and service was on point.  We went with family that had never had Eritrean cuisine.  We started with lentil and meat Sambusas.  Followed by   Zigni Beef; Kilwa Dorho (boneless chicken), Kilwa Begee (lamb) Okra, Kantisha (mushrooms) and veggie combo.  We also had the Asa Kilwa (catfish) for the 1st time and my kids devoured it.  The food was DELICIOUS!  A must have on the beverage front is the honey wine and the Harar lager.

New Eritrea also serves lunch at UCSF Medical Center every other Monday at Moffitt Cafe on the 2nd floor and in honor of Black History Month, this February they will be at Moffitt Cafe on Fridays.
author: Maritess H.

description:
Everything about this place was great from the ambiance, the friendly staff and the delicious aromas in the air. I ordered the vegetarian combo, kilwa begee (lamb), and a bottle of Tej (honey wine). Everything was delicious. If my stomach had the room I would have devoured it all in one day, that's how good it was.  

The only reason I'm giving 4 stars and not 5 is that the website posting a menu is outdated on the prices. Still was well worth it, but should update the website menu.  Definitely will be a return customer, and it would be a great place to bring a date.
author: Lemuel Y.

description:
I've walked past this place hundreds of times, and never really ventured in cause to be honest, it never looked busy.  Deceptive!  This place did not have a free table by the end of the night.  There is also another dining area, near the kitchen which has more light than the initial dark eating space you see from the window. 

Appetizer:  Sambusa (meat)  This was good and had a spicy sauce to smear on top of the crispy casing

Entrees, served family style with injera:
Gored Gored (Beef) Very very spicy.  Good, a bit chewy but just the right amount was served.

Meat Combination (combining three of their dishes): Zigni (beef),  Zebhi Dorho (Chicken) and Alicha Begee (lamb).  The Chicken dish had a better blend of flavors and I would have it again.  This was listed on their online menu $2 cheaper than their actual menu at the premises, so not sure how many other price discrepancies there are.  The website doesn't seem like it's been updated in a while.

Overall the food was OK.  The lamb was not tender and the beef a little chewy.  Chicken was really good though.  Prices are higher than the quality of the dishes. This is not as tasty as the Eritrean on Geary, but the service was friendly and they did well in getting the food out, considering how many people were dining.

Something I really don't understand about some restaurants is how many things are missed.  I know I go there to eat, but I also judge my whole experience.  The door for the ladies room was propped open, I discovered due to the fact that the handle was hanging on by a wish and a prayer, as all other nails had disappeared over time.  The cubicle I was in had a toilet seat that desperately needed a little love and I was apprehensive to park my rear on!  The only tap in the room did not run correctly and instead soaked the underside of the tap and the sink unit.  These are things that just need a little bit of care, I'm not looking for a palace, just a working restroom.

I like supporting local businesses, but I think it will be a while til I'm back here:(
author: Angela D.

description:
If you've never had Ethiopian food, set your worries aside about the sour injera bread and come here!

I recommend just trying everything so get the meat platter ($14) and veggie platter ($12).  If you look at the menu that's posted in the photos, add $1-2 to everything since prices did go up!  Nevertheless, it was still worth it.  Just tear off a piece of the injera bread and use it to sample the dishes.  If you run out of injera bread, don't order more!  Just use the injera bread that is served with the dish on the bottom.  You save money and it soaked with all the flavor.  The meat was savory and moist.  Veggies were delish too!  The chicken and the potato dishes were my favorite.

The honey wine was very interesting.  A glass is $6 and a bottle is $19?  The bottle holds about 5-6 glasses so I suggest getting a bottle if you're ordering more than a glass.

The owner is super sweet & service was quick.
author: Stacey P.

description: Amazing vegetarian options, good drinks and friendly atmosphere.
author: Connie H.

description: Authentic and simply delicious Ethiopian food! Clean and friendly. My only complaint is that they don't have one in LA because now when ever I'm craving this, I will be so sad that's it's all the way in San Fran!
author: Valerie L.

description:
Having had a great experience during my last visit, I felt compelled to grant praise to this Sunset gem. 

I've been here more than a handful of times now and have never been disappointed. The food is delicious, it's never been TOO crowded for me, and the prices are very reasonable. The wait staff is also very noteworthy. 

My last visit was for my birthday and to say that the restaurant was accommodating would be an understatement. I made a reservation for 25 a week in advance and there was absolutely no problem with my various calls throughout the week to update the party number. Also, they have a policy where parties of 20+ require a preorder and it worked out very well because by the time we all got there we didn't have to stress about what we wanted to eat.

 Having so many people allowed me to order at least one of everything on the menu and everything was great, especially the lamb. The honey wine is also a must and one of my favorites. The night was definitely topped off when I was given a bottle to take home for my birthday.  Thank you ! :)
author: Jenny F.

description: Service was great.  It was nice trying out a new type of cuisine, as I have never had Eritrean food before.  Girl and I split the beef sambusa as an appetizer, and the veggie and meat combos for the entree.  The beef sambusa was our favorite part of the meal.  My favorite of the meat was the lamb (Kilwa begee), and my favorite of the veggie was the potato dish (Vegetarian Allicha).  The food is served with this flatbread called injera that you basically use as your utensil.  Still, I felt myself looking for a fork or spoon to finish off my plate and had to remind myself that wasn't the way things are done here.  Making of the bread includes a fermentation process, which makes for a sour taste that is a little off-putting.  I would've preferred something like a warm tortilla or crusty bread.  In any event, it was an interesting experience, and I'm glad I tried it.
author: Ronald T.

description:
We found this place just by accident. We were on our way to another restaurant and I said to my BF that if we can't get a table let's try this place. I guess it was meant to be... This was our first time having Ethiopian food. We sat at the bar and waited about 5-10 minutes before were were seated. We weren't sure what to order and the waitress was really helpful and gave us some suggestions. Keep in mind you're suppose to eat with your hands. They will give you a fork if you ask but you don't want to be the prude that won't try something different.

The meat sambusa was really good. that was one of my favorites.
We also ordered the Tsebhi Derho (chicken) and Zigni (beef). They were both really good. My BF loved it and so did I. We will definitely come back.

BTW, I was really surprised how diverse the restaurant was. That's the best thing about eating in SF.
author: Karen L.

description:
You know how some people judge a Japanese restaurant based on their uni? Well, for me:

Uni : Japanese restaurant :: Kitfo : Ethiopian restaurant

This exotic dish of minced raw beef (or rare, if you prefer), mitmita, and clarified butter may frighten some people. But for me and my iron stomach it's an essential--and quintessential--part of any Ethiopian meal.

The KITFO at New Eritrea was absolutely AMAZING!! It was easily my favourite of the 6 dishes we had here. The portion was generous and the beef was so finely ground it had a mousse-like consistency that melted in my mouth. But what made this dish truly memorable was the clarified butter it was soaked in--perfectly seasoned and it gave the dish the most wonderful caramel-y/nutty aroma. SOOO YUMMY!! Definitely the best kitfo I've ever had. I'm still having food dreams about it...

The other entrées we got were the OKRA (flavoured with tomato, onions, and spices) and a meat combo that included ZIGNI (beef simmered in red pepper sauce), ZEBHI DORHO (chicken drumstick simmered in onion, tomatoes, and red pepper sauce), and ALICHA BEGEE (lamb with potatoes, carrots, peppers, and curry). They were all served on one big platter over a piece of injera. (We each also got one piece of injera to eat and use as utensils.) To be perfectly honest, all of them except for the lamb looked (puddles of red stew) and tasted (tomatoes, onions, and red pepper) the same. But, they were seasoned well and tasted great with the tangy injera. I liked the lamb dish most, partly because the curry sauce made it a little different. That, and I just really like lamb!
