We also got an order of MEAT SAMBUSAS, which were deep-fried samosa-like pastries filled with ground beef, onions, and spices. The crispy shell was nice but I thought the filling was rather bland if not for the spicy chilli paste they were served with to give it a little kick.
author: Steph L.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I feel so lucky to have it in my neighborhood - I crave the food so much that I have definitely spent too much money here. I generally bring my friends and we grab the vegetarian platter for two (which is all vegan, as well), and I've definitely impressed some omnivores with how great it tastes! Yummy food, happy friends, and all at a reasonable price.
author: Monica H.

description:
Slow service = fantastic food

Otherwise, meeting up with an old high school friend of mine this past weekend brought a flood of memories back and left me shaking my head as to why I was such a dork back then.  On top of that, running into ex-coworkers from a previous job released another set of photos where I was thinking to myself, "what the hell made me wear my hair like that?!@#"

So it was fitting in that New Eritrea found us, giggling as much as we did back in the day.  He was voted the most intellectual.  I was voted (two years verified via yearbooks) class clown.  A true fit.

New Eritrea has a fantastic broad menu to season the diverse clientele that is out and about in the city.  When we usually went out, we ordered a smattering of vegetarian dishes as well as a couple of meat dishes to even out the meal.  I preferred the injera here than Blue Nile, one of my first experiences ever.  Not as tart or yeasty.  I would recommend the following:

Zebhi Dorho - a wonderful slow cooked piece of chicken that literally falls off the bone, simmered in spices.  Perfect to sop up with the injera.

Kliwa Begee - another simmered dish and the only way I'll eat lamb.

Vegetarian combination - a compilation of their three popular veggie dishes: lentils, potatoes, peas, and carrots are covered and provide the perfect backdrop to the aforementioned meat dishes.

I rarely order an appetizer because by then, after all the talking and looking over photos, has somewhat eased our appetite.  Service,however, is a bit slow if one is in a hurry, so I'd recommend elsewhere for the time strapped.  However, when you are catching up with a friend, this would have to be the place.

Great food that made me feel all warm and tumbly.....I'd like to say comfort food.  On top of that, my friend told me I had not changed, not even my laugh.

Positivity.  Seems to be a hard trait to leave behind  :)
author: Miika M.

description:
San Fran/East Bay has many Ethiopean restaurant options and I have been to many of them. The meal we had at New Eritrea was one of the best I have had in the Bay.

Four of us ordered the vegetarian platter to share. It came with the usual dishes as well as an okra dish none of us had ever had before. Overall everything was delicious, especially the okra dish.

I highly recommend trying this restaurant. I will be back and can't wait to try additional items!!
author: Melanie F.

description:
Very friendly, Great setting  welcoming place with great food and a nice bar.
Finger licking good, literally. Nice stop in restaurant off a busy area.
author: Aquamarine M.

description:
Yes, you will be eating with your hands. Yes, it will messy. Yes, it will be glorious.

Portions are huge, which is fantastic because the food is amazing. But yes, I can rave on and on about the food and really just repeat verbatim everything everyone is saying here because really, that's all you can really do with this place. 

And you know what's even better? The staff. The service here is on point. I can't think of many places that have a sweeter, more attentive wait staff as this wonderful place.

Bravo, New Eritrea Restaurant & Bar. Solid high-fives on all fronts.
author: Daniel K.

description: Me and a group of friends had the amazing meat and vegetable group combo plate. Deeelish! It was a very interesting blend of flavors and I can't wait to try more, since it was my first time eating Eritrean food. From the sour (Not in a foul way) bread to the deliciously sweet potatoes covered in a yummy sauce and moist chicken, people def. need to try this place!
author: Sharon Y.

description: 3.5 to be exact. Don't be fooled by its look on the outside, it is actually very nice on the inside: clean, long wooden bar, and sunlight seating. The service was a little slow, but there was only one guy working so I don't blame him. We got the meat patties for appetizers, which tasted good and had a nice spicy sauce. The meat platter, which you must eat by hand, had 3 types of meat which all had their own sauces. I wasn't a huge fan of a couple of the meats, I am still unsure which ones they were. But overall pretty good, and very cheap for the amount of food. I'd say give it a try.
author: Nikita K.

description:
3.5 stars.

I really enjoy coming to this place and I've been here several times.  The staff is super friendly.  Something about the flat bread just makes everything taste so delicious.  I love all the flavors and spices.  What I particularly like is the honey wine.  It's quite cheap if you get a whole bottle and it taste exactly like it sounds.  Honey.  It's sweet, awesome and makes you feel utterly very very happy if you decide to finish the bottle.  =)
author: Shirley T.

description: We'd been meaning to come here ever since we moved to the Sunset a year ago. Finally went last week. Wish we hadn't waited so long!
author: Amy G.

description: We are regulars at New Eritrea. Excellent Eritrean/Ethiopian food. Great vegetarian options and actually everything vegetarian is also vegan. I recommend coming with a group, starting with the lentil sambusas and getting the vegetarian combination platter. The South African Pinotage is tasty and reasonably priced. The service is always friendly and open, like you're being welcomed into someone's home. Great experiences every time. Also good if you have children, they are very accommodating.
author: Kelly G.

description: I've come back here twice now, once with my girlfriend and another time with a close buddy. I have definitely come to appreciate this place more. I love the injera, and the beer selection is pretty neat. The food comes out lukewarm, but it's spiced well, and the style of eating is a change-of-pace. I recommend the vegetarian platter, as it's quite filling. Have that with a beer, and you've had a pretty good meal. It's not high-class stuff, but it's pretty good for the price.
author: Danny C.

description:
Quality Ethiopian food and very friendly service. Having a full bar makes this a unique Eritrean food experience. The interior of the restaurant is comfortable and can cater to groups, families or even a date.

Will come back again.
author: Rob W.

description:
I'm a fan of New Eritrea, mostly because of the comfortable atmosphere and attentive service. The food is addictive - I always end up getting the same dishes over and over.

That being said, it's not the best Eritrean food in the city.
#1 They use too much oil.
#2 Spice level is inconsistent.
#3 Sorry, but no place can beat Assab ;)

I don't like unnecessary oil pooling under the injera on my plate. Sure, oil tastes good, and the food here is super savory. But sometimes when I'm halfway through my favorite mushroom dish, I realize it tastes exactly like pizza.

Also, that same mushroom dish I've ordered about 6 times ranges from nicely spiced to un-spiced to REALLY too spicy. Which means I can't say "more spice than usual" or "less spice than usual" because, what's usual?!

Still, I like coming here because it's close to my house, and the food comes out fast, super filling, and pretty tasty. They have more tables than Assab so the wait to sit down isn't as long, and the service is faster as well.

I also love that they have a catfish dish - which I HIGHLY recommend. It's delicious and I haven't found any seafood at other Eritrean restaurants.

So on average, I'd say New Eritrea gets 3 stars from me; 4 on a good day.
author: Laura W.

description:
Meat combo, veggie combo, and kitfo tartar. Done & done. Delicious always.

The owner also always remembers us and our order too.  And unlike many Eritrean/Ethiopian places, the food doesn't take long to come out.  It's a win.
author: Allegra H.

description:
New Eritrea is a great place to go when you feel like gorging down on some great comfort food. I always find myself eating more than my stomach can handle just because the food is so damn good! We always get a half and half plate of meat combo and veggie combo. The raw Kitfo is also clutch. Try the steamed milk with honey!

The service is really good here. The owner is extremely friendly and always happy to suit your needs. Sometimes he is the only one on the floor, which can slow down your wait time, but it's not unbearable.
author: Michael S.

description: This is the only Ethiopian place I have been to in the city so far, and found it to be a pretty good option. They have a large vegetarian section in their menu, and a bunch of sampler platters which lets you try most of them in a single plate. We had the House Sampler - Vegetarian Combo for 3 people, and it was pretty yummy! We got to try 6 different entrees along with their injera bread (which tastes like utthapam!).. Pretty filling. Service was ok.. kinda slow, but the food more than compensates for that.
author: Aditya M.

description: I reserved online, here on yelp, but they didn't get the reservation.  We waited a bit, which was annoying.  But the owner came out, accommodated us and showed us a great time.  He recommended the family plate for 6, and he treated us like a family guest, always hanging out with us.  We certainly enjoyed the experienced.  Love the food, staff, and especially the owner.
author: Dennis L.

description:
A nice change of pace. Definitely has a homemade and family restaurant vibe. As many others have suggested, my +1 and I had the meat sambusa, meat combo plate, and honey wine.

The Sambusa's were good, especially paired with the spicy paste that they came with. The meat combo and injera were great--surprisingly, my favorite of the beef, lamb, and chicken portions was the chicken. That was really good chicken. Finally, the wine was a nice addition to the meal.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Lamb and chicken are too tough. The salad is poor romaine with bad Italian dressing. Honey wine cloyingly sweet. Staff mediocre.
author: Jon M.

description: Can't even describe  how amazing this was. The food was delicious, but the service was even better - the server took the time to understand how hungry we were and actively showed us the food we might like best. Needless to say, her suggestions were right on point!
author: Anand S.

description:
Everything here was delicious. My friends ordered vegetarian dishes that, combined with injera, tasted like plant mouthgasm. I ordered the lamb tibs which, to me, translated as "oily spicy goodness you can't stop eating."

The waitstaff was extremely friendly, and our waiter was impeccably dressed.

The decor was subdued in tone, but tastefully so. Lights were dim and I preferred them that way. The setting felt intimate without being stuffy.

The speakers resonated Mulatu Astatke; I felt like I was in a Jarmusch film. 
What's not to like about this place?
author: Leo B.

description: Love this place -- simple as that.  The service is good and the food is awesome.  We get the Hamli (collard greens) and a spicy beef dish with a sauce that is unbelievable.  Only trouble here is sometimes the meat is tough and one time the table smelled a little funky.  But it's totally worth it.
author: Joseph H.

description:
For Ethiopean in SF, it doesn't really get better than New Eritrea.  I have tried out other similar restaurants several times, and even if the flavors are on par, they give you so little food that I always have to order extra dishes.  I don't think that is fair.  When I order a dinner entree, I expect to be full afterwards.

Back to New Eritrea.  Very pleasant owner and staff.  Excellent, flavorful, hearty food.  They will make gluten-free injera if you call ahead.  Other Eritrean/Ethiopean restaurants will not do that at all.  Always a pleasure to dine there.
author: Lizzie R.

description: Worth a try.  Good portions, but a bit pricy.  Everything tastes pretty good, but I didn't like their fermented crepe thing... after a while, I couldn't stand the sourness of the crepe.
author: Javier G.

description: This place is great! I go here every few months when I have an Ethiopian/Eritean craving (which is becoming more and more frequent!). The food is amazing - it's hearty, delicious and you get a ton of it! I'm a vegetarian and I almost always get their veg combo which has a bit of everything. Honey wine is my fave! Staff is warm, attentive and welcoming. A must try.
author: ellen h.

description:
split the veggie and meat platter with a group of friends. 

I think out of the entire plate, I enjoyed the doro wot the most. I wish that they refilled our injera more often because we ran out and started to eat the platter injera (which isn't terrible, but super soggy!)  I wish that the injera was warm when it came out... it was my first time having regular injera and it definitely tastes best when it's served warm! 

I wasn't too floored by this place, but I wasn't extremely disatisfied either. Probably wouldn't come back again unless I was with a group of friends.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Came here one night on a whim and had the most amazing time. We were the only couple there when we walked in, and had never had Ethiopian food before, nor did we have any idea what to expect. The staff was so helpful. They explained the different entrees and suggested the sampler plates so we could get a taste of everything. We weren't sure what to drink and they suggested the honey wine. We were afraid it would be too sweet so they poured us two glasses for free just to taste. It was great, and we ended up ordering a bottle. The food is great. A lot of people seem to complain, but it seems to be just because they aren't sure what to expect. 

When you come here know this: you are eating with your hands. The food consists of a bunch of saucy meats and veggies and hummus like substances that you eat by scooping up the food with a soft bread. It is very similar to soda bread and has a slightly sour taste, which doesn't taste very good by itself, but mixes great with the food. I would definitely recommend checking it out, but if you've never had Ethiopian food, make sure to keep an open mind.
author: Lauren D.

description: Awesome. The fermented "appam" like bread tasted great. All the veggie dishes were really good, and the lamb good as well.
author: Nikhil G.

description:
I'm impressed. The service is warm, friendly, and helpful. If the staff don't know something, they go find out for you- promptly. I've had the meat and veggie combos, the asa kilwa, and their special kitfo. All were delicious. I can't eat it anymore, but I especially was partial to the kitfo. Yum! The collard greens certainly rank as my favorite of the veggie dishes. They know what they're doing with food. They also carry my favorite brand of tej- Enat!

Small quirk- their salad dressing. This is the one place they clearly put in no effort. I've been to a few Ethiopian restaurants, and this one is the lamest in that respect.

Speaking of eating restrictions, those sadly have become a huge qualifier in my life. If you call the night before, they'll prepare gluten-free injera. (Does this give you a hint at what the process is like to produce that tasty treat?) Not many places are willing to go to the effort. It does require planning on your part, but that winds up being generally helpful anyhow.

So, one quirk out of all that. Go eat there!
author: Jeri J.

description: Try the Meat combination with sambusa sides it's an excellent choice especially for starters. The entree was very tasty, the chicken  was top notch along with their very own spices. The staff would explain what the entrees are and the place is very clean. Would try this place again on my next visit to frisco.
author: Jon B.

description:
Well.. like most first times, it was a little awakward, but once it got going it was great. And it will probably only get better.

Good food, cute little place, friendly staff, what more could you want?

Ate: The veg platter sampler and an order of the shrimp. Highly recommend the shrimp. Ordered it spicy- great heat!
author: Emily D.

description:
I've tried a few other Ethiopian places in San Francisco and this place trumps them all. The restaurant is family owned and operated, and the food truly reflects the kind of passion someone who truly loves what they do has - the kind of joy you can taste.

The service can be a bit slow when the place is packed, but that's because there is usually only one server. 

The food is outstanding - I love the turmeric lamb and the chickpeas. And of course you have to order the honey wine.

Bonus - the price is very reasonable.

Can't wait to come back again!
author: Katie D.

description:
I love Ethiopian food and when I found out there was one in my old neighborhood of Inner Sunset I knew I had to walk those seven blocks over and check it out. New Eritrea is a good introduction to Ethiopian food, good menu choices, nice staff, classy looking joint. That said, it's not the best place in the city... the injera didn't have enough teff, and I found the food to also be a little short on the spices, just slightly on the bland-er side. 
But overall, New Eritrea: lovely restaurant, definitely worth checking out.
author: Jenna I.

description: Prior to discovering New Eritrea I had tried Ethiopian food two separate times with awful results (i.e., I did not agree with the food). Thank goodness I gave Ethiopian food a third try and with an exceptional restaurant. New Eritrea brought new hope and passion for this cuisine. If you have ever been curious about Ethiopian food then this is the place to try it and fall in love with it. I find myself craving it easily once a week.
author: Johnny L.

description:
What? You have never been to New Eritrea?  Well, what are you waiting for?  Get your butt over there and be prepared to enjoy every bite of finger licking (literally) goodness that they bring out.

Hubby and I like to order a bunch of different items (I have not disliked anything so far) so that they will bring it out on a massive platter that makes us wonder if our eyes were bigger than our tummies.  We always manage to pack it away because it is so good.  You just don't want to stop eating until it is all gone.  We never even bother with ordering appetizers.  Straight to the main dishes for us.  That way you can taste more than just one or two things on your first visit.  Totally worth it.

It is a family run restaurant which is definitely to its advantage.  Everyone is SUPER friendly and the service is great.  You feel like you are being taken care of by family friends and not a wait staff.  Love that!

You don't have to eat with your hands but you totally should.  Don't be a wimp and just pick up the Ethiopian bread and use that as your utensil.  You will have fun, eat well, and definitely want to come back!
author: Kylie L.

description: My fiance and I wanted to have a dinner date so we started walking around in the Inner Sunset and came across this place. We both noticed that the lighting was very warm and the bar was beautiful, so we stepped inside. I have to say, this was one of the most memorable dates, not only because the ambiance was wonderful, but the food was amazing and it was such a different experience for us. My fiance had the combination plate while I had a chicken dish, and we loved how you had to eat each dish with the provided bread instead of a fork. We shared a pitcher of IPA as well and a glass of honey wine which would be perfect as a dessert. All in all, highly recommend.
author: Samantha H.

description:
Was enthousiastic about trying a new cuisine and looking at yelp reviews, it looked very promising.

Food was not tasty enough, atmosphere was dry,and  no desert!! Won't go back to any Ethiopian restaurant soon...

Said that, they have a good service.
author: Patrick P.

description: Wow. I've never had Ethiopian food before but as a lover of culture this grabbed my attention. It slowed my pulse and made me feel like I was in Africa with the music, demeanor of the staff and excellent cuisine. It's a low lit place, very romantic for dates and all finger food, but still classy. Excellent!
author: Natalia L.

description:
Ive been here twice and so far it hasn't disappointed. The meat combo, in my opinion, is the best because you get a variety of beef, lamb, and chicken which is great if you want to try a few different things. Their "bread" is spongey and sour, which i actually really like (the bf didn't since he claimed that it made all his food sour). Don't be afraid to eat with your hands :)

Also try the honey wine. Don't know what they put in it, but one glass will have you buzzed, and this is coming from someone who is not a light weight drinker. It's a very sweet wine (tastes just like honey) so if that's not your thing then try another of their fabulous wines.
author: Lily Z.

description:
Came several weeks ago.  We ordered a trio sampler that included beef, lamb and chicken.  Served on a huge round platter, and each person given hi/her own basket of flat spongy bread.  The beef and lamb were cubed; but the chicken was actually two drumsticks.

I thought the flavors were very good; however, I'm not a big fan of eating with your fingers.  There's definitely a technique involved with breaking off a little bread and scooping with your fingers.

Great place to come if you're dieting or watching your waistline because it'll take you 20 minutes to get with the program.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I've never had Ethiopian food before I went here. My friend Joe has a Somalian buddy of his who recommended this place, and we actually all went together. I think he claimed that there were some mild similarities between the two cuisines. Being the adventurous type, I was definitely down to try.

They can adjust the spiciness of the dishes, but i loved the flavor. The main staple is a kind of flat bread that is moist and helps you eat with your hands.

I'd definitely come back again, but I haven't found the time to!
author: Doug R.

description:
3.5 but the service rounds it up to 4

we ordered the veggy and meat platter. Spicy lentils, potatoes, greens, beef, chicken and bit of salad all served with that amazing injera. Shared between two people we were stuffed and satisfied and it was a nice change from our usual cuisine. 

Don't forget to bring a handy  wipe.
author: Jade W.

description:
Really nice staff made for nice dinner her two nights ago. Had the veggie combo and lamb. 

I really enjoy Ethiopian food and this place had the staples with really good injera.
author: K B.

description:
I've been living in the Inner Sunset for a couple of years now, and have been spoilt by the diversity of delicious, affordable food in the neighborhood. Despite this wealth of choice, there's no contest for my favorite dinner spot. It's New Eritrea by a mile.

The intimate ambiance of restaurant, and the style of eating (shared platters, injera rather than utensils) inspires comfortable, close conversation. I love meeting up here with individual friends to catch up over dinner, and it's also an amazing spot for large groups. I recently hosted my birthday dinner here, and they comfortably accommodated a group of 20. The shared platters are especially good for groups because it makes it easy to split the check later. They also serve pitchers of a range of beers.

The food is amazing: warm, nourishing, perfectly spiced. They offer both meat and vegetarian combo platters that allow you to sample a wide range of their dishes for a very affordable price. They're perfect for sharing! I would also highly recommend the gored gored beef - this scrumptious dish is not to be missed. The samusas are excellent as well. I'm not sure what goes into the spicy red sauce that accompanies them, but the end result is addictive. I find the food pairs especially well with an icy cool Tusker lager.

If you're looking for a quiet, inviting restaurant that can accommodate intimate conversation and large groups equally well, this is your spot. The food is excellent, and the restaurant owners and wait staff are always friendly. I highly recommend New Eritrea!
author: Sarah F.

description:
So I've been to New Eritrea many times, but I didn't know of the "special" Kitfo - until last night (note: if ordering Kitfo, it should be ordered raw). It's amazing. I've always really loved the food there, and felt it was 5 star worthy, but the special Kitfo brings it to a new level. And of course, the staff are wonderful too, very pleasant, always feel welcome. Real nice atmosphere too.

I think it's even better than Assab (which I've also gone to probably 20+ times), which is more expensive
author: Paul M.

description: Not the best ethiopian food i've had but the servers were very friendly and great for groups!  I was given a bottle of honey wine as a gift for my birthday when i had my bday dinner here. Thank you!!
author: Jessica N.

description:
The service was very, very friendly and we got our food pretty quick, but at the end, the food was only okay. 

My sister and I ordered the meat platter and meat sambusa. But we weren't full, so I did an order of gored gored. The meat platter was good, and the meat sambusa were two big squares of deliciousness. However, the gored gored meat was too chewy. I ended up chewing three gristles. I also recalled that the description stated it was supposed to be spicy, but I felt like only certain portions were spicy and others were not, I'm guessing the spice distribtuion was very uneven. 

I know the injera is supposed to have a slightly sour taste, but the bread was too sour and it made some of the other food sour as a result. Typically my sister would be able to handle it, but she gave up on eating it and only ate the food on top. Eventually I ended up having to resort to that since the bread slowly become too sour for me, too.

I hope to come back to give this place another chance soon, since the workers are very kind. It seems like mostly groups of people go here, so maybe we'll be able to finish everything up next time.
author: Jasmine V.

description:
This was my first experience with Ethiopian food so my experience is based on my first impressions with nothing to compare it to. First of all, the service here is very friendly and welcoming. I came on a Friday night and there were lots of tables open. Good luck finding parking though. 

For my appetizer, I had the vegetable sambusa. The pastry part was okay but I wish there would've been more of the filling. This dish comes with a mild chili paste. 

The entrees were served family style and everyone gets their own flatbread. You can also choose to have rice instead of the bread. The bread came out cold and the taste was just okay for me. I had the beef kilwa (mild), which is lean beef sauteed with vegetable oil (or clarified butter), onion, tomatoes, garlic, seasoned red pepper sauce. It was okay. The beef was a little tough for me. I also tried the Kilwa Begee (lamb), which is boneless strips of lamb simmered with onion, tomatoes, garlic and vegetable oil (or clarified butter) and Eritrean spices. The tomatoes overwhelmed the flavor of the lamb, and the lamb could've been a little more tender. 

I'm not so sure that I like eating with my hands but the meal was okay. Your hands are going to smell like the food you ate for the next few days though. The smell really lingers!
author: Nancy C.

description:
OMG I LOVE this place!!! The food is so sooo good. Anyone who knows me knows that I HATE to get my hands dirty, but I don't even care that this place doesn't provide utensils and you have to scoop the food with the sour crepe-like injera bread. The restaurant is super cute inside and they have a beautiful full bar in the front with cheap drinks. 

The food is served family style and I haven't tried anything I didn't like so far. I recommend the meat combo because that way you get to try 3 of their best meat items in one entree. The lamb is probably my favorite and I'm also a huge fan of the shrimp kilwa, which you can get as spicy as you want. 

This place is perfect for any occasion, from a big party to a date, though it's definitely not a first date type of place (might get awkward to be literally stuffing your face with your hands haha). Prices are good and service is super friendly and attentive. For an appetizer, 2 entrees, and 2 rounds of drinks, the bill was only $56. WINNING.
author: Irina S.

description: The service here is fantastic.  The food is amazing.  The vegetarian combo and the meat combo are both excellent and addictive.  I've been to a lot of Ethiopian restaurants all over the Bay Area, but this restaurant is different.  The food is consistently flavorful with absolutely perfect seasoning, every time.  The drinks are equally great.  There's also a bright airy room in the back with a glass ceiling which is lovely to sit under during the day.  It's also a very mellow environment if you go during daylight hours, which is my favorite time to go to recharge with a delicious meal.
author: Pho Q.

description: Came for the first time as a party of four. Very pleased. Ample selection of food and wonderful honey wine. We'll be happy to come again, hopefully sooner than later.
author: Sara O.

description:
A beautiful restaurant, so cozy, such welcoming staff.  A really different feel.  Great for a date

They have great selection and delicious, flavorful dishes without being too spicy.  What I love most about the place is the sampler platter options.  They allow you to taste a bunch of dishes for a reasonable price because who needs a whole plate of collard greens? no one but they are great and you should certainly attempt to try them on the veggie sampler platter.


AND awesome drink selection.  They have Ethiopian wine and beer (honey wine is great!) and sweet, hot milk in addition to a fair selection of american classics.

Very reasonable prices for what you get!
author: Meg M.

description:
Heading here for a first experience of eating Ethiopian food was totally crazy. All the food ordered comes out on a big platter without any forks or spoons. You eat with your hands? How? This grey spongy thing here is bread? This bread doesn't look like any bread I have seen before. So many mind blowing things happening at once. 

Meat combination was a good choice that came with chicken, beef, and lamb. The beef was soft and had an interesting sauce it was in. Chicken was hard to eat since it was a chicken leg. How do you share a chicken leg with people? The lamb was kind of chewy, but it pretty good.Kitffo had a lot of spices inside it. I didn't really like the kitffo. It was too weird for me with so many spices hitting my taste buds at once. Imagine all the spices used in curry but a lot more spices. There were also a small salad in the middle of the platter. Eating salad without a fork is quite difficult.

Overall the food was pretty okay. Kind of hard to get used to all the new flavors and spices they used. The service was kind of slow. The experience itself was fun and interesting. This would definitely be a fun experience with a large group of people.
author: Steven B.

description: This is pretty much my favorite Ethiopian spot in San Francisco.  It's located in the Irving district where it is notorious for awesome food spots.
author: Bianca L.

description:
Still my favorite Ethiopean in San Francisco.  I've been coming here for years.

Everything is seasoned impeccably and thinking about the food here makes me happy.  Like, truly happy.  It's such a comfort food place.  It's warm, welcoming, nice ambiance and the owner is wonderful. 

I've probably had everything on the menu here over the years, and I've enjoyed it all.  I do miss the yogurt that the old owners (we're talking years ago!) used to put on the plates.  

I'll be back... again and again!
author: Melanie K.

description: Stumbled upon this place one night when my tummy was empty but it couldn't make up it's mind to save itself. And boy am I glad, it was a meal that I wasn't expecting but so glad I had. The meat combination plate gave you a glimpse into this cuisine and I can say I like what I tasted. Don't let the looks fool you, they may look similar but the only similarity is how tender all the meats were cooked. Some of them were heavier on the cumin or spiciness but they were all good. I broke the cardinal rule and asked for a fork. It made it easier to eat the mushrooms and salad. Super friendly as well...makes you feel at home.
author: Eve C.

description:
Great food, super friendly staff.
I have brought many friends and visitors here.
author: Georgefromsf G.

description:
Having been to some excellent Ethiopian/Eritrean cuisine in San Jose, I have to say that this place was just ok. I would definitely come again because I live in the city now and this place is only 5 minutes away from me but it's not the best I've had of its type of cuisine. 

We ordered the veggie combo and the meat combo and it was more than enough food for three of us. The Eritrean style of injera is thicker and smaller in diameter which I didn't like as much as the Ethiopian style. Also, the spices of Eritrean cuisine is more subdued than Ethiopian spices. Anyway, this place is not bad at all nor is it extraordinary but it will suffice.
author: Rylan C.

description:
I've been meaning to go here for a couple of years, but it's not in my neighborhood and parking is terrible near the restaurant.  However, when I entered, I could tell instantly this restaurant was a cut above the other Eritrean places in San Francisco. The place was clean and tastefully decorated. We were immediately greeted with a smile and "welcome!" Throughout the evening, every staff member was kind and hospitable. 

When the food came, the colors were vibrant and the tastes were clean and distinct. Some Eritrean food is so spiced and cooked down that it all becomes a mush. At this place, all the dishes seemed to bring out the flavors of the individual ingredients. The portions were a good value. (BTW, I agree with another reviewer that other restaurants in SF give small portions, and you need to order 1 1/2 or 2 entrees to become full). This is now my go-to place for Eritrean food in San Francisco. 

Kilwa Beef - chunks of tender beef, seasoned and moist, but not too stew-like
New Eritrea Special - Chicken and mushrooms, again moist and deliciously seasoned. 
Vegetarian Allicha - Potatoes, carrots and cabbage. These came in sizable chunks, and were delicious.
author: Paul A.

description:
I love Ethiopian/Eritrean food!!!! And yes, calm down - they are the same thing. The workers here are super friendly and I love how they let their children run around interacting with the customers.

The injera in the basket is better than the one lined under the entrees. The ones in the entree was a little too soggy and sour. But overall - delicious and affordable.

If you love trying new food, Ethiopian/Eritrean food won't let you down!
author: Dorian T.

description:
As my first experience trying Ethiopian food, I've got to say I'm thoroughly
Impressed!
author: Josh L.

description:
Great place for a big group and not too expensive.  I went here for a birthday with a group of 25 and it was perfect!

They reserved most of the back room for us and managed to fit us all together on one table in a U shaped table formation.  Didn't care that we were standing around talking, bouncing basketballs, and eating baked goods on the side.

I'd recommend having about 4-5 people share a platter.  They were able to accommodate vegetarian and seafood diets.  Try the honey wheat beer, the honey wine not so much - too sweet and syrupy for my liking.
author: Andrea L.

description:
This restaurant embodies the taste of Inner Sunset: shallow.

I felt like eating something hot, fresh, and spicy on a cold day. I entered at around 6:30pm. I ordered the meat platter, which seems like the best deal for a first trial. I told host not to hold back on the spiciness.

My platter arrived rather quickly. It was lukewarm, none of the meats were tender, it was spiced lightly, and there was excess oil drifting to the left side of my plate. No bueno. Perhaps it was because I came alone, and they assumed I wanted to eat quickly, so they warmed up some cooked food. Still, I expect my meal to be cooked on order for dinner.

I'll have to try Eritrea again at Assab now.
author: Rahil P.

description:
So on our way back from the Yelp Elite event in Yountville, my favorite "plus one" and I were craving something really filling and substantial. I am a huge lover of small plates and little bites, but driving all the way there from Hayward really takes a lot out of a girl.

We decided to go to my usual favorite, Asaab Eritrean restaurant - but somehow, my date entered the wrong address into the GPS and we wound up here instead.

But thank goodness for that, because not only did we find out (after re-consulting Yelp) that Asaab is closed on Sundays, we inadvertently discovered an awesome new favorite place for Eritrean food!

Upon entering, it looks just like a dark dive bar, until you walk towards the back and there is a dining room situated right under a skylight, flooding the area with brightness. We chose to eat in that dining room rather than in the darker area. 

The food was fantastic and perfectly portioned. It looks like small servings upon first glance but it turned out to be the perfect amount of food. We effed up that plate and an extra order of injera like no other, along with lager and a glass of honey wine. Make sure you ask for a side of yogurt to balance out all the spices!

Service was good and fast, and the guy at the front who doubles as bartender was attentive and helpful with suggestions. I will totally come back again! I loved it.
author: Aivy C.

description: What a wonderful find! Charming, wonderful service, delicious food. And we loved the spicy goo on the side, a novel feature of Ethiopian food for us. We had the vegetarian combo and loved it. Recommend this for a relaxed no fuss meal.
author: Michael B.

description:
There is just no way that I have never reviewed this place.  I LOVE New Eritria and have been eating here since 2008 at least.  My fave, of all the local Eritrean/Ethiopian joints I've been to.
Highly recommended.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
This was a culinary adventure for me since I have never had Ethiopian/Eritrean food before.  

The price is great and the amount of food you get for the price is wonderful.  The location is also great because it is only a quick two block walk from the botanical garden.  I found it entirely on accident and stopped in to try it.   

The place could use a spruce up, but don't let the old decor fool you.  

They serve a style of bread called Injera which was very interesting.  It resembles a thick crepe with a slightly tangy flavor - think the tang of Greek yogurt.  It is very light and spongy and doesn't have a ton of flavor alone.  It is used with eating the way you eat with a tortilla.  It is just like a sponge, so it will sop up every last bit of flavor, but it is leaky, so ask for extra napkins!

I had no idea what to order and it all sounded good, so I just let the waiter order for me.  He recommended the three meat dish with lamb, chicken and beef.  I am not normally a lamb eater, but this was delicious!  The chicken was also great.  The food was much spicier than I expected, so it took me a while to power through my meal. The meats came with a variety of sauces on them and they resembled a curry.  They were very complex in seasoning and balanced really well against the meat.  Oh...the meat!  It was ALL so tender and juicy and all melted in your mouth like a quality pot roast that has been slow cooking for hours.  The chicken is served on the bone, so dig in.  

They have several wines on the list and a full bar.  They serve several wines from South Africa and they serve a honey wine that is really interesting.  It reminds me of mead.  

The food is fairly oily, but I am not sure if that is just indicative of the style of cuisine or this place.  

They don't serve the meals with utensils so if you don't want to use your hands, then you need to ask for silverware.  The server could see the confusion on my face so he offered me a fork and explained to me that you use the injera to pick up the meat and eat it.  Don't laugh - I just have never had this type of food before.  Since I like to look like I know what I am doing sometimes, I grabbed my injera and loaded up a handful of meat.  It was delicious, but I must again reinforce that I needed a ton of napkins!  I got my nails done later that afternoon and I had sauce stains all over my nails.  That is the sign of a good meal!

The service was great!  He was friendly, helpful, attentive and quick.  The food came out in no time at all with a basket of injera.

If I am in the area, I would definitely stop back by, but who knows what other culinary adventures you may miss?  If you have never had this type of food, I definitely recommend trying this place.  For the prices you can pay in SF, this is a great deal!
author: Cathy K.

description: I was on vacation for a few days in San Francisco and staying in the Sunset area so a friend recommended that I try this restaurant.   I had bever had Ethiopian foid before so I wasn't sure what to expect,  but the owners were so warm and friendly.   They explained the menu to me and I decided on a vegetarian combo plate, some extra injera bread and Ethiopian honey wine.   You eat with your hands which took a while to get used to, but that didn't slow me down!  It was soooooo delicious!  I completely killed the entire plate which left me overstuffed,  but I just couldn't stop.  I was flying solo on this adventure so the owners chatted me up at the bar and kept me happily entertained, but when they were servibg i had time to people watch and there was a very diverse clientele there...from a large group of young friends meeting up to  an older couple out for a romantic date night.   Would absolutely recommend this place, a must try if you are in the area.
author: Crystal B.

description:
Last Thursday a large group of us (8 people) were in the neighborhood determining what to eat and I put in a passionate vote for the Ethiopian restaurant we had just passed. I love Ethiopian cuisine after my experiences working as a waitress for an excellent quality Ethiopian restaurant for 2+ years in Colorado (Nyala's Ethiopian cuisine). 

It was very late 9:30pm and a lot of places were closing but luckily the New Eritrea Restaurant was open. There was only one other couple at the bar at that time and so we expected quality service. But the food took a long time to prepare (30+ min) and they were unapologetic about this. 

We ordered a vegetarian combo for two which included 6 dishes. My favorite was the Okra. We also ordered Kilwa (sautéed beef), Kitffo (spicy rare beef), Zebhi Dorho (marinated chicken drumstick stew), and Kilwa Begee (lamb stew). The best, by far, was the Kitffo which was served with farmers cheese and collard greens. It was pipping hot and very flavorful. 

My main disappointment was the injera. You were charged extra when ordering more and it wasn't very fresh. I am used to softer injera with a spongy texture - this injera was at least a day or two old which caused it to dry out and become become brittle. The Injera at the bottom of the plate was the worst. Normally my favorite part is to eat the injera at the end which has absorbed all the sauces and spices - But the stale injera deflated this pleasure completely.

So overall, while I love to eat Ethiopian food and really enjoyed the Kitffo, the slow service and stale injera but a damper on the experience.
author: Nina E.

description:
I went here when I was teen and have never came back. I love all types of food, and I mean ALL. 

I came with my father because he had come here before and I wanted to try something new. 

We ordered a platter with that sponge like bread and the meat. I was confused when no utensils came out but I guess you use your hands to wrap the bread and the meat. When I first tasted the bread I just remember this sour taste and I immediately spit out my food. I thought this would taste like Naan but it was this strange weird fermented taste. The meat was edible to me but I just could not take the taste of that bread out of my mouth! 

Ethiopian food just isn't for me.
author: Daniel S.

description: Food is to die for, Staff was so kind and accommodating, Ambience was very good. Go, eat, live!
author: Monica G.

description:
I liked this place so much the first time, i even brought my parents here.

Eritrean food is so unlike any other cuisine, and yet fairly reminiscent of other cuisines (almost like a mix of moroccan, indian, and mediterranean altogether)

love the lentils. so good. injera is surprisingly sour, but not in a off-putting way. all the food is served on top of an injera, giving a very family meal vibe. however, would not try the tej again, was not that interesting.

service is attentive and sincere.
author: Ben T.

description: Food was okay.  My fiancé who is Eritrean and I went here to grab dinner.  While the service was great and the people were really friend, the food did not taste authentic.  We had the Chicken Dorho with vegetables.
author: Steve S.

description:
I love Ethiopian/Eritrean food. My Ethiopian roommates in college got me hooked with their homemade injera, and I had the good fortune to live very near the heart of Ethiopian/Eritrean food in Seattle for years. 

Sadly, since moving to SF almost a year ago, my BF and I have only eaten Ethiopian on our short trips home to Seattle, when we without fail will head to Meskel for their fantastic bottomless injera, wonderful farmer's cheese, and all of our favorite meat and veggie dishes.

That said, I am so glad that we finally decided to test the waters in SF at New Eritrea in Inner Sunset. The ambiance is warm and cozy, the service was great, and the prices were about what I expect for this kind of food (10-15$ a plate). They have a great selection of Ethiopian and African beers (Harar, St. George, Tusker), and  I also  tried their Ethiopian honey wine. Probably not my thing, but reasonably priced and generously poured.

We decided to order and split the veggie sampler platter, and the 3 meat platter. Everything was delicious and well spiced, and this is one of the few times when I went back for a second helping of lamb (which I generally don't like).  My favorite dishes were the spicy chicken drumstick (I miss the hardboiled egg and cheese that I'm used to with this dish, however) and the carrot and potato veggie dish. 

New Eritrea still can't compare to my 5 star fave Meskel, but we will definitely be back and probably take friends. Living in Inner Richmond and working in the Sunset this is a convenient and tasty dinner/drink option.
author: M. K.

description:
My roommate was telling me about this place and how delicious it was, I was apprehensive in trying such food, but I said why not. 

I ordered a chicken plate and it was well seasoned and just delicious. I've gone since multiple times and have tried the veggie combo which is also amazing and a beef dish which I wasn't so excited about it was too rough and hard to eat. I do recommend the chicken that was the best! 

the only draw back is the service is a little slow and it takes a while for you to get your food but besides that it was a good experience.
author: Veronica V.

description:
I love their Kilwa (beef)...spicy and full of onion, tomatoes, garlic.  for $11.  I get some bread and a small salad.  Omnomnom.  I had enough for two meals.  Seriously.  I'm eating the second portion right now for lunch.  (I like Zigni as well...omnomnom, not as spicy but great flavors.)

As always, service is super friendly!!  I love it here, and I always feel at home.  Music rocks too!  Trust me, it makes you feel so relaxed and happy to be here.

I'm going to have to try their honey wine....some day.
author: Fannie S.

description:
This was only my second time eating Ethiopian food, so I don't claim to be an expert on this particular kind of food; but from a "I like tasty food" perspective, the food was great.  We ate a combination of things (veggie plate, lamb and beef) and all of it was just the right level of spicy and tender.

I was also really pleased with the service here.  There were two waiters who made sure we were taken care of the entire time.  The place is clean, has nice ambiance and in a good location.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Terra D.

description:
There's a particular kind of dining experience I look for whenever Ethiopian is on the menu. I like my Ethiopian restaurant to feel like a clean, red-lit dive. A spot where I can throw back a cold one while chowing on some fresh injera. A place that won't skimp on quality eats and  manages to feel equally like a bar as it does a restaurant.

New Eritrea offers just this experience and with ample space to boot, I just wish I could move next door.
author: Monica S.

description:
Had dinner here last night and came away that this is one of the best deals for the money one can get in San Fran - a good dinner for two, with attentive service (they even threw in an extra dish for free), in a nice environment, for under $25.  Wow.

Not the best, nicest, whatever, I've ever had/seen/experienced.  But for the price, I loved this place.  Note - they even have a full bar.
author: David A.

description:
This place is a short walk from the CA Academy of Sciences, so it makes a great drinks-and-dinner stop after the Academy closes.

It's pretty non-descript looking on the outside, but don't let that slow you down.  It's a great place.  It has a full bar, with tables across the room and in a solarium out back.  Nice atmosphere.

I'm not an expert on Ethiopian or Eretrean food, but this food was great!  The entrees are like very thick stews of various types.  My wife and I had the meat sampler (3 different dishes (beef, lamb, chicken) and a lentil (vegetarian) dish.  All were quite different, with very different types of spices, and every one was delicious.  All of the meats were tender and juicy.  The spices were complex and warm-to-hot. We could not pick a favorite from among the four selections.  We both thought that the Ethiopian beer went very well with all the entrees.

For newbies, the experience can be a little different.  The entrees are served on one big pizza-pan, with the entrees distributed around.  You get a piece of Ethioian bread, a very spongy 16" diameter pancake, and you tear off pieces of the bread to grap and scoop the thick stews.  It's a little weird at first, but you quickly get into the spirit and it's fun!  And about the time that you think that you see the end of the food, you notice that the entrees were served on top of another piece of bread (on the pizza pan) which has soaked up all the remaining sauces and goodness.  It's the best part!

I'd recommend this place to anybody and everybody (unless they have a serious hangup about eating with their fingers).  It's an interesting experience, nice people, nice atmosphere, reasonable price, and best of all, great food!
author: Gary D.

description:
A table of five ladies talking about the hot men of San Francisco ordered the following:

- House Sampler-Vegetarian Combo for two: all pretty flavorful and delicious
- Shrimp Kilwa (Shrimp sauteed with onion, tomatoes, garlic seasoned red pepper sauce and olive oil): We were able to select the spicy level and we chose "medium" and it was pretty spicy so consider yourselves warned
- Meat combination for one: the chicken dish was delicious and, well, it's just nice to have a sampling of the different meats and spices
- Kitffo (Beef; Tartar of finely chopped lean flank steak, mixed with seasoned clarified butter accompanied with homemade yogurt and mitmita): DELICIOUS! Sure, the thought of eating raw beef is a little scary, but I'm still alive and it tasted really good.
- A bottle of honey wine - it was too sweet at times, but when it's still cold, it can be light and delicious.

Overall, a great dining experience. The service was attentive, but not overly so, which is perfect. All in all, we paid $22/per person, which is not bad for the amount of food and drinks we had.

I honestly hate eating with my hands when it involves overly moist foods (nachos are OK because you have that crisp part that you hold, y'know?), but the bathroom had plenty of soap for before and after the meal so all is well in the world.

Go. Eat. Enjoy!
author: Chung N.

description:
Oh, Assab, I was dreaming of you the whole time I was eating here.

I finished, but it wasn't the same.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/assab-eritrean-restaurant-san-francisco
author: Max L.

description:
Everywhere else we wanted to go was packed.  New Eritrea caught our eye as we were walking through the rain so we decided to give it a try.  

I've only had Ethiopian food once before, but I wasn't a fan.  I felt the texture was too liquidy--perfect for a senior citizen without teeth but not for my youthful incisors.  It was like eating Indian food put through a blender.  

My experiences at New Eritrea were a pleasant change!  The food here was much more flavorful with delicious chunks of meat and fluffy, spongy, bread. Everyone's plate smelled amazing and I drooled as my friends got their plates before me.  I definitely would love to come back to try the things they ordered. 

Boneless Chicken (#7):  This is chunks of chicken cooked in tons of spices and tomatoes.  This came with lentils and salad and big helpings of bread.  I couldn't finish the whole thing so I brought some home.  Very good!
author: Monika L.

description: Last time I was in San Francisco, I had some great Eritrean food. Unfortunately that place in Haight-Ashbury closed down. I wanted to introduce two girlfriends to the wonders of Ethiopia.  We ordered one of the sampler platters and some honey wine. It wasn't the best Ethiopian I have had but my friends were very happy with the food. The staff was friendly. My only complaint is that I wanted my friends to experience the ceremonial coffee as well and they refused to do it for us. I was told it was only for large groups. The Ethiopian restaurant my husband and I visit in Orlando Florida has never refused us the ceremonial coffee.
author: Leala V.

description: This is my favorite Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant in the United States.  The food is exceptionally fresh and delicious while the atmosphere is lively and attractive.  Unlike some Eritrean restaurants, this one caters to a diverse clientele and the service is fantastic.  I always go with my favorite dish (vegetarian combo) and because of the produce farms in the Bay Area, the ingredients seem to be fresher than similar restaurants in DC (where I now live). I highly recommend this place.  As an Eritrean myself, I know a good injera spot when I see one!
author: Hen T.

description:
I'll be honest- previous experiences with Eritrean and Ethiopian food have never really impressed me.  New Eritrea Restaurant has completely changed my opinion, making me a believer.

With this type of food, it's all about the spices.  This place has it right- whether you're in the mood for seafood, chicken, or beef dishes, everything is bursting with flavor, mostly from a skillful use of traditional spices.  Some of these spices I'm used to (cumin, curry) and other which I've never had before, but really enjoyed.  All dishes can be adjusted to heat preference and are served in the authentic Ethiopian style of using a huge communal dish and no silverware, just the spongy flat bread to scoop up the food.

Overall, great experience and really enjoyable food.  I'll definitely be back again.
author: Mike B.

description:
Of course I love an excuse (and even better, a social command) to get dirty.  In this case, that means eating with my hands, bringing out my not-so-inner three-year-old. 

Pretty standard Eritrean/Ethiopian food here.  (Compared with other American versions of the same.)  I do love the sambusas with that sauce that comes on the side.  Great spice if you ask for it.  Not my favorite honey wine, but good nonetheless, being honey wine and all.  Bathrooms are kinda shady, but what does a three-year-old care about that?  

This is an excellent place to bring vegetarian or vegan friends - though you have to watch out for the family-style presentation of course.

And did I mention you get to eat with your hands?
author: Ravena F.

description:
Hearty, healthy, beautifully spiced Ethiopian food. 

This is a solid joint for your Ethiopian cravings. If you are craving Ethiopian, don't ignore those cravings, this food is very sensual not only because you eat with your hands but because of its use of grounding and earthy ingredients like lentils, turmeric, curry, collards, roots, rhizomes and legumes. Very very good for your body mind and spirit. 

What makes New Eritrea stand out among the others is its heavenly injera. It is like eating air, sour dough air... the texture and flavor is divine and totally unique to this establishment. It must be the San Francisco air (and its diverse microorganisms!) that makes their fermented injera so incredibly tasty! Also they must use a nice quality teft flour. Of course they also use high quality spices, seasonings, and ingredients for all of their offerings. Don't fill up on the injera in your basket... save room for the very best part of the meal: the soggy injera underneath your various entrees!!!!

I enjoyed the veggie combo platter and the As Kiwla (spicy curried catfish). Absolutely delicious. I would write home about this one but instead I am writing to you.

I must recommend that you skip the tempting sounds of their sambusa appetizers as it is not much more than a lot of fried dough with a meager scrap of filling. I must also make note that the spicy curried lentil dish on the platter was oversalted, I love salt so this was actually a surprising pleasure for me. 

Also this is a beautiful and thoughtfully decorated/arranged restaurant ~ very good energy in there. I love this place!!

Oh yes my dining partner and I paid $32.50 for 2 lentil sambusas, 1 catfish, and 1 veggie platter ~ pretty standard for SF.
author: Libra J.

description: I love love love this place! Excellent service and delicious food. We always get the combo platter and the lamb kilwa. They are so nice and accommodating. A nice gem in the city!
author: D G.

description: Good flavor Ethiopian food. We ordered a meat sambusa and I would not recommend it. It was fried dough with no flavor filled with greasy greasy ground beef. Nothing special. For the main course we ordered a meat combination and Kilwa Dorho (boneless chicken). It was good flavors and tasty stuff. My only complaint is that the portions are a little smaller than I'd like. Other Ethiopian places have the same dishes but just more food. However, because you are constantly eating Injera (bread) you get full pretty quickly. I just like to have leftovers so I can enjoy it another day. Good place in the city.
author: Jeromy G.

description: Luckily my stomach is strong to eat this kind of food. But I think people get sick is because they didn't wash their hands properly before eating. I liked the meat dish, don't remember if it was lamb or goat, but not beef...enough spiciness to give you a kick in the mouth.  I forgot about the heat on my fingers and tried to take my contact lens our later that day, it was painful!
author: Troy V.

description: Finally Ethiopian food to rival the quality over in Oakland.  My palate is always guided by the meat and veggie combos.  What I love about the way the meal is served is not simply that I get to eat with my hands, but that it is a slow and subtle race to see who gets to eat more than their 50%.  Of course, I always win.
author: Jeremy G.

description: So good!! Thank you for your delicious food. There was diversity for meat eaters and vegetarians, hearty portions and a full bar if you are interested. I over heard the table next to us impressed with their extensive beer list. I must say I didn't check out the selection. Highly recommend this place and supporting the beautiful and hospitable family who owns it.
author: Austin S.

description:
Since my husband is obsessed with Ethiopian/Eritrean food, I've had my fair share of it.  I am NOT one of these people who will give this cuisine a low rating because I don't like it.  In fact...I love it.  One of the things that I usually love about it is that, unlike most Thai and Indian restaurants, they don't use 4 gallons of oil to make your meal.  This is the first place I've been to where oil was a real problem.  I was glad we walked the 3 miles from BART to get there because there was just THAT much oil.  In fact, we could've taken the oil left on our plates home in a to-go box and I could've used it to cook for the rest of the week.

Aside from that; the service is great, the atmosphere is great, and I love the glass ceiling in the back.  Yay for Tej!  The taste of the food was average (we ordered the veg combo).  I was excited to see the okra because that's one dish you don't usually get...  I've had much better Ethiopian food in San Jose and Berkeley...but this place wasn't the worst I've had either.
author: PrincessPeac H.

description:
First timer at Ethiopian food and I'm definitely coming back!

My party of six arrived on a Friday evening for dinner and was seated quickly at a semi-secluded table near the front window. It was perfect since we hadn't seen one another for quite some time and had much to catch up on. 

The waitress was welcoming and answered several questions we had regarding the menu. My only complaint was that she rarely checked in with us and my friend had to bring our bottles up to the bar for more water. 

FOOD

For appetizers we ordered SAMBUSAS to share. We had two types of filling, meat and veggie, both of which tasted the same to me. The shell was a bit too deep fried for my taste. 

I chose the #11-MEAT COMBINATION for my entree since I wanted to try a little bit of everything. It came with beef, chicken, lamb, and the salad. Everything was decently spiced and we were also given extra injera (flat bread). Pending on your appetite, sharing might be a good idea since none of us were able to finish everything from our dish. 
______

Overall, good experience.
author: L W.

description:
The inside of this place surprised me. From the outside, it looks like it may be a tiny little hole in the wall, but on the inside, it's actually quite big and well decorated. 

Honey wine was excellent. Be prepared for lots of sweetness though!

Food was fun. We had a decent sized group and decided to go family style. Everything was served on a gigantic platter. Using hands to pick up food and having to reach around everyone took some getting used to as did actually picking up the food.

Tiramisu was alright and the actual food portion of the meal was very tasty. The only downer was with what you pay, you kind of expect more food.
author: Lily K.

description: Hands down the best Ethiopian food I've had in the city, and I've tried them all. The flavors are wonderful, the portions are generous, and the folks who run the place are so nice and welcoming. I love chatting with them when I come to pick up my order. I always get the veggie combo platter. It's amazing. They also have a really nice bar if you want to have a chill conversation over a glass of honey wine.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
I wish service were a bit faster, but I imagine they are just cooking everything fresh because the food is quite amazing. 

There was nothing not-wonderful about everything I put in my mouth.
author: Catt G.

description:
Fantastic food, excellent value.

2 Dinners, apps, a bottle of wine and generous tip was $60. The meat combination was especially good. It came with lamb, beef and chicken. Just the right amount of spices, and big soft pieces of injera. The meat was tender and not greasy.

This is a great place to linger over a meal, and we weren't rushed at all. The owners run a clean restaurant and they are quite nice.

Will will definitely eat here again.
author: Monarch B.

description:
Wife came to visit and wanted sushi. Hotei was closed, Ebisu was packed, i refuse to go to Kiki (i just don't understand the slanted windows), Jimisan sucks, and she refuses to go to Kazu (she had an allergic reaction to a salad after not specifying she didn't want shrimp). Basically, that eliminated all our sushi options in the immediate area.

I suggested Ethiopian, and she concurred it would be a nice change of pace. We got here and it wasn't all that busy, so we were seated right away. We debated over what to get (i wanted more meat, she wanted more vegetables), but ultimately settled on the meat combo and the vegetable combo--the come with 5 sample dishes each--and an appetizer. All the food came rather quickly, and we were very pleased with the speed of delivery and quality of the food. I really liked the chick peas and collard greens, as well as the very moist chicken and the beef.

This wasn't our first time having Ethiopian, but i definitely suggest the two combo dishes for anyone going for the first time. They serve it on a giant plate with what looks like a large spongy crepe that tastes like sourdough. You take pieces of the "crepe" and use it to pick up the meat/vegetables in front of you.

I definitely want to go back, as i was really happy with the food and the speedy service. And the waiter was quite nice and was on top of things.
author: Phuong M.

description:
I really like Ethiopian from Zeni in San Jose, and Eritrean food from Assab in SF, or Fin Fin in Berkeley. I've had Ethiopian and Eritrean food in many places around the US. Its one of my top 5 favorite foods.

I am sorry to say I didn't like the food that I had at New Eritrea Restaurant & Bar. Maybe people have different baselines for what they think good Ethiopian/Eritrean food should taste like. Or maybe we picked dishes that aren't the restaurant's best. But from my taste horizon, this was not very good compared to what I've had at other similar restaruants.

We had what is kind of my standard set of dishes. At New Eritrea they have a Veggie Sampler where you get what would have been a nice set of 5 veggie dishes if they had tasted as good as they sounded. When it came out, it was anti-climatic. It didn't even look appetizing. 

The Vegetarian Allicha, normally one of my favorites had an orange sheen to it and was almost all very large pieces of potato with almost no cabbage. It tasted bland and well, to potato-y.

The rest of the veggie sampler were also missing the usual charge I get from this kind of food. The  Alicha-Ater (pureed Chickpeas) was ok as was the Hamli (Collard greens and spinach) and Okra. But the Tumtumo (pureed lentils) was pasty and somewhat tasteless and Shiro (split peas) was also nothing to write about.

The injera was thin and with nothing to say for itself ether.

We also got the New Eritrea Special which is made from "Tenderized boneless chicken mixed with mushrooms sauteed with onion, tomatoes, garlic and authentic Eritrean spices". Sounds great but it wasn't. 

Service was generally fine and friendly, but I go to restaurants mainly for the food. 

This is the second time I've been here and I was reminded that the last time I said that I wouldn't come back. Well, it hasn't changed and now maybe I'll remember not to come back...
author: Robert B.

description:
AMAZING FOOD!!!!! 

It's very similar to Indian food, so if you like that, you'll definitely love Eritrean Food.  Definitely a place that any Local should try out as well as take out-of-towners to.
author: Mili S.

description: If you want to try a mix of different foods grab the meat combo and the veggie combo to share! Everything* here is tasty. *Don't know about the seafood, yet to try...but everything else* The collard greens dish is probably my favorite...with the lentils in close competition.
author: Alize A.

description: Just had dinner at the New Eritrea.  Great food, great service.  For those folks squeemish about eating with their hands; forks are available.  We had both the beef and lamb dishes.  It was difficult to figure which was which.  The lamb was mild and not at all lamby and melt in your mouth tender.   Our entire party enjoyed themselves.
author: Hank Z.

description:
Good place for Ethiopian food. My family went there with my mom who is the only person in our family who can't take anything spicy and the staff was so helpful and accommodating. They offered to put it on a separate plate too. The staff also provided a lot of great recommendations too. 

The biggest issue is not their fault but parking is such a pain there at the Inner Sunset area!!!
author: Joe Y.

description: Great food. Staff was wonderful. Steamed Milk and honey was excellent. Oakra was amazing!
author: Daniel B.

description: Good food.  Service was okay for a Friday night.  Every time I go to Ethiopian food, I always order the vegetarian combo plate and I recommend you do the same!  This one did not disappoint.
author: Daisy A.

description: You cannot beat this place when it comes to Eritrean, African food. I am pretty sure I grazed my way through the entire beef, lamb and chicken entrees here. The entrees and any single appetizer are more than enough food for two. Your mileage may vary. They are served with injera bread (flat bread with a slight vinegar flavor) used to pick up meat and veggies from a large communal plate. Right hand only people. Never had a bad meal here and went on a spree where we walked by the place nightly and went here once a week for a nice relaxing dinner. No hurry, no rush, very good service and food.
author: Rob K.

description:
Excellent food and the honey wine is to die for. Be aware serious wine drinkers...this wine is very sweet but goes well with food here.

Ordered the house sampler, which is all 6 vegetarian options. absolutely delicious and enough for 2 people: 

Tumtumo -Lentil beans pureed/simmered with tomatoes, onion, herbs.
Hamli-Collard greens and spinach
Vegetarian Allicha-mixture of potatoes, carrots, cabbage and garlic 
Alicha-Ater-Chickpea pureed and simmered in onion, garlic 
Okra-with fresh tomatoes, onions
Shiro-split peas, tomatoes and onions

It's served in a large platter on top of injera bread, which is a porous, spongy flat bread with the slightest sour taste. it's almost resembles a really large flat crumpet. really tasty. There is also a meat combo with beef, chicken, and lamb. The sampler is about $24, a great reasonablly priced way to try a little of everything.

Service was super friendly. Will definitely be back.
author: Maria M.

description: Best preparation of okra I've ever had. The lamb was sublime. Some of the starchy veg curries are rather bland, but placed against the more zingy tomato based curries, they work. Slightly under-staffed, but I'll forgive it if they can stay open. I don't drink coffee, so I've no idea how well they prepare it.
author: sarita b.

description: Good try for ethiopian cuisine. .decent service n are quick..neither extraordinary nor bad .. ate the veg combo... would recommend the one with okra if u r looking for a spicy one..all the lentils are bland ..
author: Vamsi E.

description: Ate here for my second time the other day for my birthday. Absolutely delicious and perfect for vegetarians. Love the calm casual ambience of this place! Loved it both times I've been here. My entire family enjoyed the food as well. Will definitely be coming back.
author: Nicole C.

description:
Definitely something different.

The injera bread was sour and sponge-like.  The meat combo platter was excruciatingly spicy. The service was very attentive even though there was only one waiter.

I liked it, would return.
author: Mimi P.

description:
This was my second time at this restaurant and everything was fabulous from beginning to end.  The challenge is finding parking, but once in the restaurant the food and service erased all memory of the parking challenge.  We were on a limited time frame (due to the parking challenge) but the staff took care of our order and the food arrived promptly, giving us more than enough time to enjoy and savor the meal.
We had the vegetable combo and a mushroom dish that was to die for!  Everything was excellent.  I would highly recommend this restaurant if you're in the Sunset District and have a hankering for Ethiopian!
author: Debbie N.

description:
"I'm so pro black I don't even pick the cotton out of aspirin bottles!"
Well....kinda. Being Arabic I have a close connection to the African Culture. Egypt, Morocco, Tunisia, they all rock that African Culture and that includes food. 

First off aesthetically this place was amazing. Dim lighting, candle lit table, and soft tone music really set the tone for a romantic evening...or in my case an romantic outing with my best buds.

The Service here was unmatched. Small things like a helpful suggestion on what to order, constant checking in to see if everything is okay, and the revolutionary idea of bringing a pitcher of water and leaving it at our table rather than scurrying to the kitchen every time someone needs water. Sadly service like this is a rarefied occurrence these days.

Finally let me get to the food and drinks. Obviously if you are coming to New Eritrea Restaurant & Bar you are basically putting yourself out there to try something new. I've read several reviews were people say, "The food was to bizarre and eccentric for me." Well OF COURSE IT IS, it is ETHIOPIAN FOOD!  That is like me going to a House of Prime Rib and complaining, "Ohh this food was too Prime Ribbery!" That being said the food for the most part was great. We ordered several meat dishes (no homo) and not only was the meat tender and juicy but the sauce was really mouthwatering. So many flavors in the sauce, it felt like the sauce was injected with food anabolic steroids, which in other words injected with super flavor!

My only complaint for the food was what they called bread. This bread which resembled more of the padding they put on the floor at Chuck E. Cheese, was definitely not my cup of tea. Not only was the look unappealing but it tasted like a Scotch-Brite Sponge. 

At the end of the day New Eritrea Restaurant & Bar was a pleasant and delicious surprise. Beautifully decorated, amazing service, and scrumpt-dilli-umcious food, what more can you ask for. You know what they say about East African cuisine, East African cuisine is like a restaurant where everything is good except the bread, EVERYTHING IS GOOD....EXCEPT THE BREAD!
author: Judd H.

description: I am always happy eating here. The food is great and worth a try if you've never had Eritrean/Ethiopian. That said, it is a unique flavor and serving style so go in with an open mind.  My wife didn't like it at first, but now she loves it.  Maybe the sour spongey bread is an acquired taste?
author: J M.

description: I love this restaurant. The owners are wonderful and warm. They also pay very close attention to my and my sons allergies. And incidentally the food is delicious.
author: Hackey S.

description:
This kind of cuisine was new to me, but I am now a fan.  You get to eat with your fingers!  What's not to like about that?

This was a nice place nestled among the trendy-but-unpretentious restaurants of Upper Sunset.  Service was efficient but subdued.  Food was really tasty for my palette... somewhat like a blend of Middle Eastern and Indian but something unique.  Various sizes of tables, not too busy on a Saturday night.  Had the vegetarian platter sampler, all good, and excellent pairing with the Honey Wine.

I'm going back here again.  INJERA!  INJERA! INJERA!
author: S W.

description: I ordered the veggie and meat combo to have a chance to try a little of everything. The yellow lentils had a bit of a smoky (burned) taste. The chicken was definitely the best tasting of the meat choices given. Overall it was just  ok
author: Joel Z.

description: This is a great place to eat - it has a cozy ambience and the food is great! Each time we've visited their staff is very friendly and willing to recommend or accommodate your requests. We've taken guests to eat at this restaurant and they've always liked the food. I would recommend going here, you don't always need a reservation but on a Saturday its a good idea to make one.
author: Lotika G.

description:
I was never a big fan of Ethiopian food, despite my overall gustatory adventurousness (e.g. I had fried okra and pickled quail eggs for lunch today), but this place has turned me around. 

I haven't had any dishes I didn't really care for here. I find everything very flavorful and I can't guess how it's made, so that's always the sign of a winner in my books. I usually get the veggie combo. Their collard greens are probably the best way to cook that tricky veggie; I actually come back just because I'm in the mood for those. Really, I get cravings for their collard greens; when does that ever happen! And I also love the lentil dishes, so amazing.

I've had their meat too, being a huge fan of eating animals, and it's tasty. Just that the veggie dishes here are good enough that I don't miss meat, so I usually just go veggie.

Try the Ethiopian beers or honey wine, they're quite good. The beers aren't like typical light colonial-style pilsners. They're heftier and kind of sweet, very nice. 

Also, for the gluten intolerant, their injera does contain a small amount of wheat (I asked because I wanted to bring my mom here and she can't have gluten) but if you call in advance they can make the injera entirely with teft for a gluten-free meal.

One last thing: I don't usually rate on service because it has so much to do with the particular server you get and nothing to do with the quality of the food or the overall experience unless you're faced with total incompetence, BUT, at New Eritrea the waiter is always super attentive and fast. Also friendly without being in your face. We've had a few nice chats. He recognized me every time after the first time I'd been there, so it always feels like we're appreciated and that puts me in a good mood.
author: Aaron G.

description:
I love trying out new foods and my palette for new tastes seems endlessly expansive. My classmates and I were invited out for lovely evening of Eritrean food which I will sum up in a few words for those of us with little time - eating at New Eritrea was like going home to your parents house and they've prepared a banquet in your honor that they've been stewing all day.

First, the alcohol, because really how else can you begin to taste the food if you don't have a good drink to pair with it? I recommend having a nice amber beer or a honey wine. I had both and they were really great with the food. They have several beers on tap and some imports at their fully stocked bar.
