First, for appetizers we had these samosa like things come out alongside some spicy chili paste. Add just a little paste to your samosa (it's filled with lentils) and so tasty. I think they're either lightly fried or baked because they were very light.

For dinner a huge platter came out with an array of options (all the veggie favorites and all the meat favorites). The vegetarian options were delicious - lentils, chickpeas, another veggie puree, carrots and cabbage, all steaming hot and so tasty (watch your fingers guys!). The injera bread was very nice, not too sour. I have a hard time ranking the meat options. The chicken curry was divine, the lamb curry was great, but the beef tibsie was incredible. I couldn't get enough of the latter but they were all very good, just the right temperate (hot!) and wonderful to share.

The service was lovely, such nice staff, very attentive. We never had to wonder if they would bring more water bottles for the table (even though they were incredibly busy). Also, one of our friends crashed into a glass door by accident (watch the glass wall everyone!) and the staff were so attentive of him even though he was fine and it was totally his fault he walked into it as he missed seeing the wood frame.

Emergencies aside, the food was excellent and I will certainly go back with my adventurous food friends. I already love spicy ethiopian, indian and thai foods. You'll love it if you're the adventurous spice loving type with a taste for international food. Best enjoyed with a good local or international beer.
author: Sari S.

description: if u want a new taste try this place out.  Such sweet workers as well. Even though they were under staffed when we were there, they never panicked, complained or made a fuss.  They were always smiling and pleasant.  I would recommend you to take a bottle of honey wine, it is sooooooo good!!!!! The experience of using your hands while eating is very similar to Filipino tradition, so I felt at home.  The tastes of new spices tingle in your taste buds and strong aromas of new curries and other foods just make u salivate each time a plate comes by.  Enjoyed it a lot.
author: Richard G.

description:
I had no idea this stretch of Irving was chuck full of charming cafes and coffee shops. I needed a place for a dinner party and  it had to be Eritrean or Ethiopian. Since I have tried Assab, Massawa, and Club Waziema on numerous occasions, I thought it was about time to give New Eritrea a go! 

The staff was so nice when I made the reservation (and when I changed it... twice). They were very accommodating, setting up one rectangular large table in the back half of the restaurant. The restaurant has a great feel as you walk in. The lighting and curved bar welcome you, along with the delicious smells of authentic Eritrean dishes. 

We sat down and immediately ordered pitchers of beer and a few bottles of wine. There South African Cab was not bad for a screw-off top, and only set us back $22. Eating this type of food is always so enjoyable because there is inevitably someone who is a first timer (making it much more exciting). Adding to newcomers in your party, the wonderful spices, large quantities of food, and family style service each make this genre of food a special experience. 

The food was good and everyone left more than full. I tried out the veggie combo which was good, although I wish the salad and potato stew were cut a bit small for easier eating. From my carnivorous friends I heard the  beef cubes were the best, followed by the lamb. Try as much as possible. 

Service, was good and not brother some. The reason for the three starts is simply because there are some exquisite Eritrean/Ethiopian places in the SF area. I am also learning that there are some really amazing places in LA (thank goodness).

Good food and very, very reasonable. 12 guests, 2 pitchers of beer, 2 bottles of wine = $330 (w/T&T). 

Great for groups and parties.
author: Theresa T.

description:
Yummy yummy in my tummy!  Sambosa (like an empanada) appetizer was delicious but super oily.  Goren-goren and something like tartare were great (top 2 on right side of menu).  Tej (honey wine) fabulous!  $40 bucks for:
1 appetizer, 2 main dishes and 2 glasses of honey wine and a diet coke.
author: Christina L.

description:
I took a friend here to eat because we both really wanted some Ethiopian food.  We went on a weekday evening and the place was quiet, just a few other couples and families eating.  

We ordered one of the lamb dishes and a veggie dish and the two of us were stuffed by the end with some leftover.  The food comes out on one big piece of that yummy lemony bread and each person gets a bowl of the bread.  No utensils of course!  Just your fingers and the bread.  The lamb was well done and the veggies were a mash of greens.  Solid.    

The service was very laid back, similar to European experiences.  They only stopped by once to check on food  and never refilled my water.  I thought the price was a little high, compared to Ethiopian I've eaten in other cities, but I guess it's San Francisco.
author: May N.

description:
I think I've been spoiled by Ethiopean food in Berkeley because I didn't really take to this place.  The food wasn't as flavorful as other Ethiopean I've had, and the "bread" was soft and spongier than others.  Made it difficult to eat with.

The caveat was that I took this to go, so maybe that had an impact?  But I used to live literally around the corner and it took me all of 2 minutes to pick it up and walk back...
author: Ken L.

description:
I cant say Ive experienced better since this was my first time eating Ethiopian food. The style of eating was quite different as you each get a piece of injera "a giant sour dough tasting pancake" that you are supposed to break off with your hands to scoop some of the stews that you ordered. We ordered the beef, lamb, and vegetable combo. The lamb was a kinda chewy, the beef was decent, and the vegetables had a different sour flavoring. Be prepared to use napkins as this family style of eating can get messy. Each dish was a little pricey (average $12 each plate) in my opinion for the kind of food we were eating. They had one plasma tv by the bar. 

Bottomline: The service was good but I probably wont be back here as this unique type of food and way of eating isnt quite my cup of tea.
author: Robert Y.

description: Maybe it was due to the fact that it was a long day and I was hungry, but the dinner here was great!  The vegetarian sampler was not the best I've had, but still highly palatable.  Beer on tap for me and honey wine for my friend.
author: Ling W.

description:
Whilst a young and idealistic student, I spent several months working for an NGO in Nairobi, Kenya.  I lived with a Kenyan family in a far-from-affluent neighborhood and worked miles away on a heavily fortified street, across from the Israeli embassy.  

The city lived up to its pejorative moniker, "Nai-robbery," as did my neighborhood, South-C, to its ("South Central," naturally).  I watched three men with anachronistic rifles burglarize a neighboring home and a young couple divested of possessions at knife-point.  I was repeatedly accosted by unseemly fille de joie and targeted by skillful larcenists.

And yet, I loved Nairobi. The verdancy of the city, vibrancy of its nightlife, each unique storyline that followed the fade in of daybreak.  

And of course, the incredible cuisine.  

Some of my most poignant memories from Kenya are of the people I met, conversations I enjoyed, and authentic food and drink I savored in the lush courtyard of a local Ethiopian restaurant.  For successfully transporting me there with its delightfully taciturn service, unrefined yet lively decor, deliciously nostalgic Kenyan beer and savory, authentic, yet reasonably-priced shiro (a traditional dish made of chickpeas, onions and tomatoes), ingera, and asa kilwa (catfish sauteed with onions, tomatoes, garlic, red pepper sauce and olive oil), New Eritrea Restaurant and Bar deserves five stars.
author: Savvy S.

description: Love.  This is a go to spot for us.  We usually have cocktails and the veggie + meat platter for variety.  The owners are super friendly.  And, after lots of trial & error, this is the best Ethiopian food we've found in the city.
author: C E.

description: I was looking for Ethiopian food on the peninsula and found this little gem. Had a great dinner with four adults and two kids. The staff was friendly and helpful throughout with a simple, unaffected style. We shared a vegetable sampler and an excellent chicken dish. The injera (flatbread) was superb - tangy,  spongy, chewy. Portions were generous. Prices were more than reasonable. This was quite a ways from our home but we'll be back!
author: Benjamin C.

description: Very friendly, welcoming place with quite good food and a nice bar to sit at if you are not with a group.  Try the honey wine, the Eritrean beers, the Eritrean liquor... good stuff!  Easy access via public transport, in the middle of a great neighborhood of cafes, restaurants, and bars near Golden Gate Park.. The staff are very friendly, I have been here a few times, sometimes by myself, and they were always happy to chat.  Anyways, if you have not tried Eritrean or Ethiopian food (pretty much the same, they are different countries for political reasons), it is good, healthy stuff!
author: Mark N.

description: Food and service was good! They need to stock Drambuie, otherwise, it got a highest rating from us.
author: Anne S.

description: I'm new to Ethiopian food, but dang this place is great. The food is tasty and has generous portions, and I love injera bread so much.
author: Trisha K.

description:
You must try this place!  I've always been a fan of richly spiced ethnic foods (like Indian, Thai, Afghani, etc.), and this place does not disappoint.  It's totally a fun and satisfying dining experience.

You eat with your hands, family-style.  The entrees come on a large platter on top of a large injera ("bread") and you also get your own injera to tear into pieces to pick up the entrees.  The vegetarian/vegan dishes are really good--very tasty and filling.  But if you're into meat, which I am, you must try the "Gored Gored," which is a dish with cubes of tenderloin tips served rare in a spicy sauce.   There hasn't been a dish there that I haven't just absolutely loved. The food can be real spicy, so hotheads rejoice!  Or, you can ask them to adjust the spiciness if you have a delicate palate.  (I just called you a wimp under my breath.)

They have a fabulous Ethiopian stout called Hakim which I highly recommend with your food.  We also tried the Pinotage, a red wine from South Africa, and that was wonderful as well.  

The staff and service was great!  This is the place you'd expect San Francisco to have:  a local family-run restaurant in a quaint neighborhood serving up mouth-watering food at reasonable prices.
author: Beth K.

description:
After reading some 2 and 3-year-old reviews saying this place had gluten-free injera, I called New Eritrea this week to ask if that was still the case. "No, there is a teff shortage, so we are using some wheat flour now," the man told me. (Sad face). "But you can have it with rice if you want." OOoh. 

So, that prompted our visit to the restaurant last night. It was my first time having Ethiopian food, although I've wanted to try it for years. My date and I ordered the meat sampler and the vegetarian sampler, so we had 7 dishes to try. The chicken -- a huge, tender drumstick -- was astoundingly good. We also particularly liked the buttery potatoes and the spicy lentils, but everything was wonderful. He had a glass of the stout and I had the honey wine -- delicious. 

We came in at about 8pm and the place was empty except for a few people at the bar. As we ate, more and more diners came in. Even so, it was reasonably quiet -- we could actually hear each other talk! -- and there was some soft music playing. In addition, the service was great and our food and drink arrived quickly.
author: Beth W.

description:
This was my first Ethiopian cuisine experience. I loved it. New Eritrea has a warm ambiance & an intimate feel. Definitely a good place to bring close friends or for an icebreaker. All the entrees are set in one huge dish and everyone shares. Utensils are accessible but need to be asked. I personally don't like eating with my hands unless its a burger or fries but this was a good experience because the food was more than worth getting my fingers dirty. 

We ordered Gored Gored (beef), Zebhi Dorho (chicken), and the Kilwa Begee (lamb). My favorite was the Gored Gored, the beef was so tender and it was the spiciest out of the three and I'm a big fan of spicy food. We washed all of this down with Honey Wine (Tej). I'm also not a big fan of wine but this was a delicious, sweet treat to balance out all the flavorful meat dishes.
author: Kris B.

description: i love getting take-out here. the vegetarian combo is super yummy, and seems very healthy.
author: L. Y.

description: My friends and I came here last night for our first Ethiopian food experience, I enjoyed it a lot! The friendly staff makes your experience so much more! The honey wine is a must! I order a veggie Sambusa for an appetizer and the vegetarian Allicha! Both great choices for veggies like me! I really enjoyed my experience here and will be coming back for the Ethiopian fix!
author: Kim D.

description: This place is legit.  Fantastic food, great service--staff is great, and the decor... well interesting to say-the-least.   I stop here fairly often and will continue to do so.  Great bar if you are only out drinking.
author: Johnny C.

description:
One of my most favorite restaurants!  It's the only place I have had ethiopian food, but I can't imagine it getting better than this!  Can I just say..injjjjjjjjjjjjjeraaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaah!    I can't get enough of their "bread", which looks like a cross between a tortilla and a sponge!  However..it tastes like sourdough...mmm.  Lamb is what I usually order when out, since I never make it at home; and have always been quite satisfied here.  I actually get the meat sampler...which is so good.  

My nephew and niece MUST eat here every summer when they visit from Denmark..as there isn't anything like this over there.  The people here are also soooooooooo nice; and I have been seated instantly.

If you are eating family style with someone who likes it spicy and you do not....you may order it mild while they bring your friend a small container of a spicy paste!  My friend could not get enough of it!
The prices are soooooooo reasonable as well...a must eat!
author: Delicious B.

description: I don't have much experience with Ethiopian food but, I know how good food taste like. I came here a hand full of times and each times was a pleasant experience. I've had their meat combo and my favorite was the lamp. It's seasoned to perfection and the portions are huge. I had enough left over for lunch the next day. The service is good too. The staff are super friendly.
author: Luna C.

description:
I went here again in August 2011.  Christina really likes this place.  We had the vegetarian combo again.  I really need to try the meat combo next time.

Also tried the seasoned raw ground up lamb with some kind of mild cheese.  It had a distinctive flavor that I never experienced before.  It was good but only in an appetizer quantity.  A whole bowl of it is just too much.

I did not smell bad old sponge odor this time.  

I would come back here.
author: Rabbit L.

description:
GF and I were waiting in line at San Tung down the block but we were both hungry and not up for the super long wait so we took a random stroll and ended up at New Eritrea.  Neither of us had tried Eritrean food so we were feeling cautiously adventurous.

The first table we sat at smelled funky, like mildewy homelessness (sorry for the un-PCness here) so we asked to be re-seated.

We ordered the veggie sampler for two which came out in like 2 minutes (almost as fast as a bowl of pho anywhere) so we both dived in.

The food was good - we had no idea what to expect, but if you had told me I was at an Ethiopian restaurant, I wouldn't have flinched... the food is nearly identical... I'll probably upset some people with that comment, and for that I apologize for my ignorance.

The platter was just enough food to fill us both up and there were enough flavors to make it interesting.  The service was quick and friendly, and the place was buzzing - nearly packed.  

I would come back again.
author: Ricky S.

description:
It was my first time trying African cuisine.  Food was good. Service was awsome.  I didnt have to wait long for the food despite there was only one waiter and the restaurant was 85% full with customers.  

Sanitary is my number #1 thing to look at in a restaurant.  Their utensils were clean (no lip stick stains or fingerprints), the restroom was decent.  

The only thing is parking sucks there.  So be patient! And wash your hands before eating. Enjoy!!
author: Kris L.

description: Can you locate Eritrea on a map? Yea... I sure hell can't either! But at least i know Africa is not a country and I'm willing to try new cuisines from different places. New Eritrea is a little place in the Inner Sunset that offers a wide range of curries served on a large plate. You eat with your hands and everything is eaten with a purple crepe that tastes like sour dough. The place might seem a little off when you first walk in because it feels more like an Irish pub. But the food comes and you are quickly transported to a different place. We ordered the boneless chicken, lamb, and potato curry. Each dish had it's own unique taste. The spices were really different and unlike anything I've tasted before. Our server was also very attentive, really knowledgeable about the menu, and brought lots of napkins. It's also really fun eating with your hands, great place to take the kids. Just be sure to wash those hands well before you leave. *sniffs fingers*
author: Charlie L.

description: Awesome food awesome service!!! Genuinely nice hard working people serving here !! Great local gem. I have taken my mom,sister, bff, n bf here they all loved it. If u want the best Ethiopian food look no further u have arrived.
author: Annie B.

description:
Felt compelled to write a review while I'm eating next day leftovers.  The food is just as good if not better than when I got it yesterday... the spices have had time to mingle and meld into something extra tasty. 

Anyway I've been going here for years (this is my go to place in the neighborhood for takeout) and I love it.  I get my favorites - rare kitfo with the house cheese and tumtumo - and they're amazing every time.  All the food I've had here is great and the service has been very good the times that I've eaten at the restaurant.
author: Marina O.

description:
A platter for 4 can feed 6.
One bottle of honey wine may not be enough for all 6.
If you love your food spicy and like to share, New Eritrea is where you should go. 
The veggie combo - on point.
author: Judy L.

description:
I went here a few years ago, and somehow it didn't make much of an impression on me. Well, times have changed (or, let's face it, I was hungrier). Everything we had was very tasty, and I think I'd get it all again. For three people, we ordered lentil sambusas (so, so good - how can you improve on lentils? Put them in a wrapper and deep fry them!! Had a nice little spicy kick, too), kilwa (beef dish - good, but my least favorite - the beef was a touch too chewy for me, but the unlisted chickpeas that came with it were wonderful), zebhi doro (great, two drums fyi) and the vegetarian combo (tumtumo (lentils), hummai (greens and spinach - normally not my favorite, but fantastic) alicha (I remember this being bland years ago but it was delicious this time) and aucha ater (I love chickpeas)). I like meat and everything, but I can easily see having a strictly vegetarian (vegan, even, apparently!) meal here.

This was enough food for 5 people (judging that 2 of the original three had it as leftovers).

We got takeout; it was easy to order over the phone and the food was ready promptly.

*Important note: their website says they're not open on Monday. But, as yelp correctly lists, they actually are.
author: Lisa K.

description: Plenty of vegetarian options! My favorites are the vegetable sambusa and the vegetable allicha. Good for big groups and the owner is really nice!
author: Mo A.

description:
Delicious food. Favorite dish was definitely the Kilwa Borho. Amazing chicken dish with so many spices and good quality meat. Loved the experience. Was thankful to be with a friend born in Eritrea so he did most of the ordering but honestly a delicious meal. 

The service was great too, and I'm sure if we didn't have our friends guidance they would have been more than happy to help. Warm smiles, spicy food, and great options. Would love to go back if I'm in that area again.

Also, if you order tea make sure and ask them to spice it up. They have some mixture of cardamom, cinnamon and cloves that will make the tea a bit more interesting. 
 
Enjoy!
author: Ami D.

description: I love Ethiopian/Eritrean food, and New Eritrea Restaurant & Bar does the cuisine justice. I've been here twice now and I've been quite satisfied both times. The one dish that distinguishes this place from the other similar restaurants in the area is the Shrimp Kilwa. I'd never had seafood Ethiopian/Eritrean style before, but I liked it quite a bit. I always order a vegetarian combo every time I go to an Ethiopian/Eritrean place so that I get lots of variety, and this place's combo is among the best. I'll be back.
author: Adam B.

description: Second visit to this lovely Inner Sunset gem.  The food is amazing!  The folks that work here are super sweet.  Everything we have tried on the menu is incredible.  Such good flavors and so much to choose from. Only wish we had something like this at home!
author: Stu O.

description:
This place is definitely vegan friendly! Everything under their vegetarian section of their menu is labeled 100% Vegan and it includes over 7 options!

I was super excited to get Ethiopian food because i had it a long time ago and thought it was awesome! It was definitely as good as i remembered! The staff was also very friendly and had some great suggestions.

My roommate and i ordered the House sampler - Vegetarian combo (platter for 2 for $23.50). It is served on a large platter and has a little bit of everything. I'm not quite sure of the name of the sponge-like flat bread but it is amazing! We finished every last bit of it!

We asked our server which beer was his favorite and he was happy to give us suggestions. My roommate and I both had an Ethiopian beer called Meta Lager ($4) and enjoyed it! I am definitely going back very soon! I have been craving it all week!
author: Anthony H.

description:
I love New Eritrea. I have been coming here, consistently, for maybe the past 10 years. my parents and I called a meal at this restaurant the litmus test for potential boyfriends: if they like it, they're for sure in! each time I eat at New Eritrea, I feel well taken care of, my tummy nearly bursts, my palate sings, and I leave VERY happy. 

the servers are genuinely sweet and attentive. they smile. they answer questions, fill water. this makes me very happy. I always feel welcomed [although I'm sure by now that the manager knows my face ...]

I always start the meal off with veggie and lentil sambusas with the absolutely delectable chili paste - delicious little fried pastries with spicy sauce never disappoint!! have eaten practically everything on the menu [the veggie combo is my personal please-all favorite] and absolutely nothing disappoints. when you say you want a dish spicy, you get a spicy dish. each dish is subtly different, even sans spice.

this restaurant has a full bar [always a plus!] and his spacious enough to seat a large party. I love the back room, and the large table by the front window.

a warning to those who like Ethiopian food: this is Eritrean, and therefore slightly different. there's still injera, and some of the meat dishes are similar, but do not expect a meal you would get at any other Ethiopian restaurant in the city [this is a GOOD thing!] parking is tricky in the Sunset, so walk, take public transport, or carpool - I promise, it will be worth it!!
author: Rachel W.

description: Hands down my favorite restaurant of all time. Service is topnotch. You cant go wrong with any chix or vegetarian dish and the honey wine is amazing
author: B B.

description: This place is a heaven for vegetarians. Its one of the few places in city i revisit more often. I have tried their veg combo and liked most of it but my fav is Kantisha (spicy!!) and the Shiro. Food tastes fresh and homely. Definitely my top spot.
author: D T.

description: A lot of people have strong opinions about their favorite Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurant in the Bay Area.  The good news is that we have a lot of good Ethiopian to choose from!  For me it comes down to Enssaro in Oakland and this place.  While Enssaro has greater refinement and richness of flavors, their sambusa is simply okay.  But New Eritrea has two great vegetarian sambusas to choose from, and this excellent earthy chili paste that comes with it that's stunning, not quite like anything I've had other places (though I haven't tried the sambusa at Assab yet...).  I always get the veggie combo platter and add mushrooms to it and am very full and happy in the end.
author: Moshe Q.

description: We came here for my birthday on a whim after visiting the Academy of Science.  We're used to trying new places and having a mix of pleasant and unpleasant experiences and this was definitely on the pleasant side.  The food was well made and tasty, the service was friendly and attentive, and if we lived closer we would definitely come back.
author: Sheila P.

description:
This place was delicious! I left full as hell and it hit every nook and cranny in my body. 

The experience itself was amazing; eating family style with our hands was different.  Basically we all ordered dishes, veggies, meat, and I forgot what that raw meat dish was, but it was SOOOO good. When it came out, it was all on a huge platter and we all had this sourdough spongy crepe/bread to scoop our food with. IT WAS TO DIEE FOR!

and of course the honey wine was superb. im not a big wine drinker, i can barely enjoy it, but this wine was real nice and tasty.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED, WARNING THOUGH, you will leave smelly.
author: Tam T.

description:
AWESOME! Loved the unique atmosphere and chance to try out a new cuisine. There was an eclectic mix of people which made people watching very fun. It wasn't too crowded for a Saturday night, but be forewarned that parking in this area is tough.

The food was great. Try the appetizers! The plates of food were HUGE... 2 plates was way too much for our party of 2. The plates are basically huge piles of meat, served with this delicious chickpea hummus mash, and spongey bread that you eat with your hands. This was my first Ethiopean restaurant experience and I've been inspired to seek out more!
author: Alissa B.

description:
Like everywhere else in SF, it took some time to find parking. Residential street or metered parking is around here. No lots. 

My BF and I got in around 6/630ish on a Friday. The place was completely empty, but it wasn't till we got our food when the place started to fill up.

Drinks: 
Meta (Ethiopian beer) - pretty good. Sweet version of a hef. 
Teja (Honey wine) - yummy! Really sweet white wine. 

Food:
Sambusa (Meat appetizer) - one per person. Deep fried wonton warp with ground beef inside. Size of a small envelop. 

Meat sampler - Chicken, Beef and Lamb. The chicken was my fav.

Gored Gored (Beef) - The server said it'd be spicy, but i thought it was more on the mild side. BF liked it over all.

Nice experience. Will Def. be back for me. =)
author: Joeleen C.

description: I ate here on Friday March 10th and got massively sick for the whole weekend! I kept throwing up for 3 days because of this place. I will definitely *not* be back. :( 4 days later and I'm still feeling ill from it!
author: Hula H.

description:
Great food, great service. The staff has that authentic Eritrean hospitality that you can't help but be charmed by.

Definitely try the vegetarian sampler plate. It's Delish and enough for two (unless you're a sumo wrestler, in which case, order the meat sampler, too). Add a glass of honey wine and you'll be in heaven!
author: S Z.

description:
Can I just say I love eating with my hands? And making a mess? 

I recommend trying the vegetarian options...we did half veg, half chicken but I'm going to be real nit-picky and say the chicken could have used more flavor or at least be smothered in a nice sauce. Try the paprika-laden chili paste if you're into spicy food...definitely is good.

For the portions, this is decently priced Ethiopian food, especially considering it's in the city (I usually hit up the places in East Bay). 

P.S. Make sure you ration your single piece of injera!! Or else you may very well be stuck with the soggy one on the main plate ;)
author: Sony M.

description:
I needed a good low-key dinner location for a friend's last evening in town before she returned home to NYC. As you might know, Manhattanites are notoriously hard to impress food-wise; I opted for New Eritrea b/c of the consistently good reviews here on Yelp and ... to be honest ... its convenient access from MUNI's N-Judah and 44-O'Shaughnessy transit lines.

I went to college at Cal-Berkeley and lived just down the street for 2 years from Blue Nile, which will forever dominate my expectations of good Ethiopian & Eritrean food. I must say, New Eritrea did *not* disappoint. The portions were perfectly sized, and the staff were very accommodating with the amazingly high amount of water I consume with food ... as well as the amazingly high amount of injera I require when inhaling full plates of family style dinner. (For the uninitiated, INJERA is the unleaven sour-bread that forms the traditional vehicle for consumption of meals in northeastern Africa.)

My buddy and I split an appetizer; she had two glasses of merlot, I had one glass of tej [honey wine... think mead but lighter], and we each had one entree. Total cost, including my *three* extra pieces of injera, plus generous tip, was $60.

Final note: the staff working here typifies exactly what I have experienced in every Ethiopian or Eritrean restaurant from Berkeley to Oakland to SF to San Diego: flawlessly courteous, genuinely concerned for the patron's enjoyment of the dining experience, more than willing to check in on the progress of your meal but un-intrusive overall, and -- most importantly -- genuinely appreciative of your business. Coming from a part of the world which has suffered so much, I am continually amazed by the generosity of spirit in people who have come to America from Somalia, Ethiopia, Eritrea, and Djibouti. Kudos.

My only concern -- and it's a minor one since I travel with hand-sanitizer wherever I go -- is that I'd've appreciated a kleenwipe with the check; I recognize that this is my American obsession with germs so I don't penalize the restaurant for not offering it... this is just a "word to the wise" for any germaphobes who try food from this part of the world: wash your hands before you order dinner!
author: Ronald-Philip T.

description:
Came to this place after visiting Assab Eritrean Restaurant in the same week. Assab is more hole-in-the wally, New Eritrea is more spacious and first-datey, I know you like my adjectives.

I feel comfortable reviewing this restaurant after only one visit because we got the meat combo and veggie combo, so we managed to hit 7 dishes in one go. (Nice!) Amount was perfect for a guy + girl, actually I might've eaten more than the guy, but moving onto more important things:

Of the 7 dishes, my favorites were:
- Tumtum (pureed lentils)
- Alicha-Ater (pureed chickpeas)
- Zigni (lean beef) 

These had good spices and unique flavor and whatnot. The other ones were kinda bland and not worth returning for.

We also had beer, an Ethiopian Meta lager, and a Kenyan Tusker lager, both of which kinda tasted like "normal," "everyday" beers to me, but I'm not a beer connoisseur and don't feel like my beer opinions deserve to not be in quotation marks.
author: cecilia y.

description:
First time trying Ethiopian food, loved it. 

Shrimp Kilwa, Shrimp sauteed with onion, tomatoes, garlic seasoned red pepper sauce and olive oil & injera.

Not bland at all and had just the right amount of spicy heat. I hate food so spicy you can't enjoy it. I'm not a big salad guy but the dressing coupled with the main course had great taste to it.  

I must say the staff is VERY friendly, probably one of the friendliest staff I have met. After dinner the owner (I believe) asked how my meal was and we spent a few minutes talking about travelling. When was the last time you received this type attention at a restaurant?? 

Customer service is a lost art these days and other places should pick up some tips from this establishment. 

BTW they do have utensils, just have to ask.

Warning - go with an appetite, the food is plenty and filling. 

Enjoy!
author: Reggie R.

description: YUMMY! I love it. We ordered the veggie platter w/ the flat bread, and it was plenty of food for two people to share. Soooo goood!!!  Plus eating food with my hands pretty much rocks. We also ordered their version of samosas, but I probably wouldn't order them again- they were super greasy. But the rest of the food was delish. Other perks were the super friendly server, and the fact that this place is right in my hood.
author: Sonya D.

description:
This was my first experience with Ethiopian food, so it is hard to make any sort of comparisons food-wise, but I'll give it a shot. I really enjoyed this place. The service is really friendly and fast, the restaurant is large with plenty of seating, a full bar and in a fairly decent area for parking.

I loved the injera bread/pancake. It looks like a flat sponge, but has a sharp sourdough flavor. It's pretty different from other flat breads. We ordered a meat combo and a veggie combo, in order to try as many things as possible. To be honest, I expected a lot more exotic flavors, but it was very middle eastern and normal. The lamb dish was good, the beef tasted like chile con carne, and the chicken was tender. The vegetables were mainly comprised of lentils. Overall, great flavor and fun to try new things. I'm not really a fan of eating with your hands, but whatev - it's fun!
author: Amanda D.

description: Pretty good fare and excellent prices - this restaurant was a breath of relief compared to many cramped restaurants in the city. The prices are very reasonable, the food was tasty, and the service friendly and quick. The meat combination was spiced just right, and the waiter gave me a generous portion of honey wine to taste for free, which was nice. I would return again to this pleasant spot for a bite to eat. :-)
author: Elizabeth W.

description: The service and food was so yummy.  I ordered the vegetarian platter for 2 and shrimp with GF bread.  Addicted and definitely coming back!
author: Mia G.

description:
I just dined at New Eritrea for the first time, so I'll limit myself to 4 stars for now. Also, it has been years since I've eaten at an Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant, so I cannot compare the food to other Horn of Africa restaurants. For the same reason, finding New Eritrea was a blessing; this is a wonderful cuisine that deserves more popularity.

I've been meaning to come here for a while. Finally I didn't have something that had to be used or go bad, and so I gave Puffle  (my Labrador) her bowl of food and slipped out while she wasn't paying attention to anything but chowing down.

The menu has six vegan dishes, plus a combination of the first four. I had the combination, and it was very tasty. The four were served on top of injera (a spongy, moist, tangy bread made of teff flour), with an extra piece of injera served on the side. There are no utensils, so you scoop up the stew-like dishes with pieces of injera. I was out of practice, and had to order an extra bit of injera to finish my plate, and I used three napkins. Presumably one gets better at this with practice. But when I was done, my plate looked as if Puffle had been there to lick it.

Unfortunately New Eritrea is only open for dinner, and they have no outdoor seating, which is why Puffle had to stay at home. Still, it is fun to have this African cuisine so nearby. I'll go again.
author: Earl K.

description:
My best friends and I had dinner there last week. Super yummy. The dining room have a large skylight which made the room very airy. Service was good and the place was well lit and clean. I loved the vegetarian combo and cubed lamb. We had our meal family style ; my favorite! I am thankful the favors were strong and not 'watered down' for the masses. 

Definitely will go back with more friends. Parking might be tricky, so i suggest carpooling.
author: May T.

description: We've come here for years and love the food, the honey wine, and the friendly staff. Great for groups, we often bring guests here and they always leave happy (even the vegetarians can fill up on tasty, spicy eats). Our favorites are the zigni and the asa kilwa - hands down the best fish dish I've had in years.
author: t k.

description:
delicious.  we came here as a big group with very little organization and they were patient with us and provided us with great service (though a little slow at times).

we started with 3 different kinds of sambusas.  they were good, but nothing special- they were pretty greasy but delicious when you were as hungry as we were.  i had the meat combination for dinner and was definitely not let down.  you get a LOT of food and a lots of injera to enjoy with it.  for the price, it is really a great value and a nice place to catch up with friends.
author: Lisa C.

description: Great setting, great food, delicioso wine. Finger licking good, literally. Nice stop in restaurant off a busy area. Sometimes getting away from all of the hustle of Irving is much better.
author: Betty B.

description:
I'm not even going to pretend to be cultured or pretentious enough to use the phrase injera bread because while I know exactly what it is now, I did not know until I just read it on this chick's review below me. Now that that's out of the way, I liked this place although I did have some qualms with its bright lighting - I need soft, yellow light to look fuckable can I say soft or would that be inappropriate? Also, they really need to do something about the exterior because it kind of looks like less of a restaurant and more of a random little shit shack. Or, like what you'd expect a restaurant to look like in Eritrea (whatever, you didn't even know where Eritrea was until you Google mapped it).

I went here a couple nights ago with a pretty big group of like 10 or so, and we sat in the back room. I ordered a Harar beer (it's Eritrian, too!) because I can't interact with humans while sober (jk friends I like you guys!). That beer was very good, and got me a bit tips after just one. Best part of sitting in the back happened when some guy walked into the glass separator between the back room and the bar area and the ENTIRE restaurant started laughing at him. It felt like being in a movie. The waiter then placed a few blue post-it notes to alert people that there was glass that cannot be walked through.

The food came out on a big platter with 8 piles of brightly colored goo (I didn't order it so I don't know what it was). I only ate the vegetarian stuff and felt like an assole for having to ask people to dip first in the vegetarian stuff and then go to meat, and not the other way around. It was tantamount to asking people at the dinner table to please wipe front to back. Continuing with the culturally insensitive, bathroom theme, the way to eat here is to use the INJERA bread to grab the gooey stuff and just TRY not to have the image of scooping up baby poo with a diaper and placing it in your mouth. The injera bread was okay but it seems like if you're going to use it to replace forks, spoons, napkins, and plates, it should be awesome. However, I've had it at a different Eritrean restaurant and it was much better here. So it may be physically impossible to make it taste any better. The food was very, very delicious despite everything I've said.

And I can't not mention this but the whole time I've been writing this, I can see someone else's review saying the food here is "Americanized" BUT, it's still good and I'm going to give myself an aneurysm by repeatedly saying to myself "What in the actual fuck? Seriously? What in the fuck?" The word Americanized generally seems to mean "made more delicious and awesome." Really, dude, unless you are from Eritrea, have been to Eritrea (congratulations, you're either Eritrean or rich enough to afford that plane ticket) or have had an Eritrean person make Eritrean food for you, please make sure to alert me if we ever meet in the world that you are the guy who said this so I can waste no time speaking to you.
author: Joe T.

description:
Dear N.E.,

I am by no means an expert in Ethiopian nor Eritrean cuisine.  However, I ate lots of warm, yummy food of this nature when I lived in chilly Chicago, and now that I'm in SF I'm glad to have you to satisfy this need.  Your service is always friendly and attentive, and your gored-gored dish--one I can't recall trying previously--is simply magnificent.  I never leave you unsatisfied.

Your Friend,
Erin
author: Erin M.

description:
I left feeling so happy and warm inside! So much so, I changed my plans from going out, to staying in.  There was no need to paint the town red because I was contempt and with a full belly.

I shared the vegetarian platter for three.  Seems like the platter's are where it's at. I  Also had steamed milk and honey---BAAM! After a comforting meal like that; the world could have ended for all I cared.

The flavors are subtle and never overpowering which to me, means that the food is prepared in its purest form. Some associate strong flavors with the quality of food.  To me, strong, salty, tangy flavors either mean there's some extra butter, oil, salt, or msg added to it--no thanks.

Anyway, one of the best eats I've had in a while. Did I mention, no silverware. Word.
author: Mennlay A.

description:
I don't write many reviews. I've been a bad, bad Yelper. I've taken the advice and not returned the favor. That stops this year. Right here. Right now.

I lived in East Africa for about 4 years and ate my fair share of Ethiopian and Eritrean food while there. New Eritrea is as good as the best, and better than most of what I found in Kenya. It is hands down the best I've found in SF. And that was even take-away. I can only imagine, and will experience soon how good it is in-house.

The staff was super friendly, I took the waiter's advice and got a meat-combo, the Gored Gored, and a Hamli. All were superbly flavored and it is great to see that they do not shy away from the heat.

And holy crap! They have Tusker while you wait at their comfortable bar. Be still, this mzungu's beating heart.
author: kai k.

description:
4.5/4 stars.  I've had Ethiopian food before - Merkato in Little Ethiopia in LA and once somewhere in Oakland / Berkeley - and I can say quite honestly that New Eritrea is the best of the bunch.

My friend and I both ordered the meat combination (chicken, beef, lamb) for about $11; the sauces and spices weren't overpowering for my palette - just right to preserve the richness of the Ethiopian flavor.  I think my favorite from the combo was the beef, but the chicken and lamb were also very tasty.  

I would recommend to anyone who's coming here for the first time to get a combo plate just to sample the variety on the menu.

We also ordered the honey wine, which was potent but lacked the sweetness that I was expecting...I suppose I was expecting a dessert-wine richness to it.  Didn't bother me as I got a quick buzz, which makes eating Ethiopian food with that sponge bread and your hands even more interesting...

One of my instant favorite restaurants in the Inner Sunset.  Would come back in a heartbeat - great food, friendly service, and there was no wait for us on a Friday evening at 7:30 PM.
author: Michael P.

description:
The people who work here are awesome. I came in here with Ashley D. for drinks one night, and the place looked cool enough to come back for dinner.

We had no idea what to expect, and in hindsight we probably didn't need to order two entrees. We were served one giant platter with each side being our respective choices, and then extra flatbread to eat it with. 

The food was great, although if someone in your party is sensitive to spicy foods, "mind" in Eritrean might be a little misleading.

They also had some really good African beers.

If it's your first time, I'd recommend getting some appetizers and split one entree (for two people).
author: Ryan M.

description:
If it was '91, and i were in the business of ferrying a decommissioned Antonov AN-8 (and its cargo of dubious nature) from Luqa (for customs reasons) to Asmara (for financial reasons), i would probably be inclined to make at least one stop, between origin and destination because, AN-8 has a range that's slightly more than 1,700 nautical miles, but the distance in between our points is slightly more than 1,800 nautical miles (and we have no aux. fuel tanks). The trip would taken anywhere between just under 7, and a bit over 9 hours (depending on prevailing wind conditions). Even though we'd stop somewhere and probably get some snacks and drinks, we'd still be pretty hungry when we got there. And if I talked to my associates who have done this trip, or lets say read something about local cuisine, somewhere, i would've been likely to learn that i'm likely to get some goat or camel as a representation of the "local flavor". And i may have gotten goat. And i may have even liked it, after all i would have just spent like 8 hours flying a plane.

But its not, and i weren't. And so i didn't. Instead i went to New Eritrea, just to find that they dont serve goat (though really it didnt matter b/c i wanted to check the place out anyway - which i did).  Ordered appetizers in the form of veggie sambusas, with interesting salty spread (2). And veggie combo, consisting of:
collard greens and spinach
potatos carrots and other stuff
purreed chickpeas
and pureed lentils . Presented with an injera, and on an injera, which is a sort of Eritrean crepe, which double as utensils, and plate.
All of these were different (hence interesting) than most generic CA food, but not notably better. And i was pretty happy i got to get into my car and drive home in 4.5 minutes, instead of catching a plane and flying home for 11 hours.
author: Oleg H.

description:
lentil sambusa: lentils are nice and healthy until it's put in a fried egg roll wrap = YUM!
zebhi dorho chicken: spiced right and taste decent.
vegetarian combo: decent and very healthy
bread wrap: tastes like sourdough
it's a place that you gotta try once. although it's not my type of cuisine so i'd visit once in a long while.
author: NY Y.

description: Nice food! Sambosa fantastic... We opted for chicken plate, very sumptuous and tasty! Will visit again ...!
author: Mandar S.

description: so i hadn't been to this place in many many years. Went last night and had a great surprise.....there were 3 of us....we shared a large combo plate....with lamb, beef, chicken, veg platter....with drinks and an extra dish, without tip $60 bucks....what a fine time....the service was attentive and a quite atmosphere.....will return for sure...check this place out ...you won't be disappointed.... the servings we very generous .....
author: David R.

description:
I am new to Eritrean cuisine and now it's all I want to eat. 

-Genuine and attentive staff
-FOOD (family style, delicious, & exotically seasoned!)--Appetizer: Lentil Sambusa with a tasty spicy sauce; Entrées: meat combination (beef, chicken, and lamb), vegetarian combination (pureed lentil beans, collard greens and spinach, potato/carrot/cabbage combo, and chickpea puree) all served on a giant injera base and with an additional injera per entrée. Drink: Honey wine! (An interesting yet happy medium between a dessert wine and a white wine with a sweet and malty aftertaste)
-Lots of options for your vegetarian and vegan friends.
-Best part: You get to EAT WITH YOUR HANDS! 
-Basically the ULTIMATE FIRST DATE SPOT: if you can sit down with someone and enjoy an exotic, family style meal with unconventional flavors, eat with your hands and get a little messy, but still enjoy yourself & your company, then you are pretty much meant to be. 
-Looking forward to my next Eritrean meal!
author: Briana F.

description:
Probably the best Eritrean food this side of the city, and by far one of my favorite places to go when you just can't make up your mind what you want to do for dinner. This place always hits the spot. I have only ever ordered off their vegetarian menu and can say without a doubt that it is all delicious (okay I haven't had the spinach dish, but given their track record... I'm sure it's great).

This is the kind of place where you want to go with a few people, for a few reasons, one being more people are always better, but also so you can try as many dishes at once. The variety is really what makes this place great. Nothing is ever too spicy to have me flagging down the waiter for more water, but always spicy enough to keep things interesting. If you're feeling up to the gut busting dinner it will be, order some appetizers. I always forget them, but they deserve just as much attention. 

Overall, I like that this place always appears busy (unlike some other Eritrean restaurants in the area) and that the service is pretty quick. the decor isn't the greatest, I wouldn't go here on a date, but it's a great place to warm yourself up on a cold winter day with some delicious food and close friends.
author: Allyson S.

description:
This was my 3rd Ethiopian food experience and by FAR the best!

Absolutely no need for a reservation, the place was totally empty on a Tuesday evening. The place looks like a bar that was built in the 80's then frozen and opened back up again a few decades later. All of the decor is super out of style, but very clean and in great condition. There is even a poinsettia wreath (BTW it was June when I went) over one of the doorways.

There was one guy working, but the service was not slow and he was super friendly.

Anyway on to the food...

We ordered the House Sampler-Vegetarian Combo for two and the Kilwa Dorho (chicken) and of course it came with Injera (spongy sourdough bread). All of the dishes had a ton of flavor and were delicious. We couldn't finish all of the food and had a lot left over.

The Harar Lager beer (Ethiopian beer) was delicious, tasted sweet almost like a hef.

Overall everything was wonderful and I can't wait to go back!
author: Elaine S.

description: We positively love this place. Comfy and warm inside, lovely staff, delicious, scrumptious food. Best Eritrean / Ethiopian place in town.
author: Liat W.

description: Fantastic! Possibly the best Eritrean/Ethiopian food I've had outside of Africa itself. Shared the veggie platter with one friend. The portion was more than generous and the quality and freshness definitely were top. The waitress was very friendly and the service was quick. Will definitely return. Unusually good value for price in San Francisco.
author: S M.

description:
The in-JER-ah here is denser than I prefer but still good. You can order the mushroom dish spicy and it's very flavorful, my favorite dish here. 

Portions at New Eritrea are huge, I suggest going family style or at least bringing a friend to split a single dish with. 

The traditional coffee (which is close to espresso, recommended!) takes forever to be made so you may as well order it along with your food even if you're planning to drink it after the meal. Unless you're aiming to extend a date and WANT to wait around forever for the hyper stuff to show up =)
author: jizzie b.

description:
New Eritrea is a great spot to go with a group. Ethiopian food was made for sharing!

My friends and I shared two platters: one vegetarian and one meat. Our server, who was also the chef, put together an assortment for us that was fantastic. However, out of the meats the Zebhi Doro was my favorite. It's chicken drumsticks with a ton of flavor. The Hamli was my favorite vegetable which was a very flavorful mix of sauteed greens. The bread is really yummy but be careful not to eat to much because it tends to expand in your tummy.

If you like spicy food, Ethiopian is the right cuisine. We ordered everything spicy, but the spices totally did not take over the flavor. Also, it's not the kind of spicy that burns your mouth for 3 hours, it's more like a quick spiciness that gives just the right amount of kick :)

Service was very friendly, but also slow. Don't go here with a group if you are in a hurry. They could have been understaffed that night and fortunately the friendliness made up for the long stretches of no server. 

The prices are pretty cheap. We had leftovers and ordered wine. The total was about $24/person with tip.
author: Kandace K.

description: I enjoy Ethiopian food and this restaurant didn't disappoint.  My only complaint would be that the duruwat (spelling?) was chicken on the bone so you didn't get much meat- the sauce was delicious.
author: Christy L.

description:
Trying a new cuisine for the first time always complicates reviewing a new restaurant. How does one distinguish the "cuisine" from the "place"? Turned out this wasn't a problem with New Eritrea Restaurant & Bar, because both were great.

Ethiopian food is most distinctive not by what goes into your mouth, but how you get it there. There are no utensils (something my fellow diner could have warned me about before I asked where the forks were...), instead you use a thin spongy flat bread to scoop up delightful bits of meat and vegetable, and then eat the whole mess. Sort of like making dozens of tiny wraps.

My party split one vegi-combo and one-meat combo, which the staff was nice enough to put on a single large plate for a family style experience. More than enough food for the two of us and allowed for the sampling of four different vegi dishes and three meat dishes. I was a bit nervous, during the experience, that I would run out of bread -- and thus be forced to use my bare hands to eat -- but it turned out we left bread on the plate, so don't worry about it. Just be conscience of your bread to food ratio and you'll do fine.

As a final note, the ambiance of the location was really lovely. Extensive wood paneling, local art and music, and a very friendly waiter really made the place comfortable with a bit of a post-colonial vibe (as my fellow diner described it). Total bill, with tip, came to just under $30 without drinks, so it's not exactly cheep eats, but still very good value.
author: Sean K.

description:
came here for friends birthdays.  gave each birthday girl a free bottle of honey wine.  i personally didnt like it cause it tasted like beer with lots of honey but to each his own.  

the novelty of communal eating with your hands is always great fun!  just make sure you go with sanitary people cause they will all eventually fondle the food that will go into your mouth.
author: Paran Y.

description:
I've had Ethiopian before, but not Eritrean. I'd spent a week long vacation roadtripping through northern CA and we'd had Ethiopian on the first night. We decided this would be an excellent way to bookend our vacation on our last night in San Francisco. We went for dinner and shared the House Special Vegetarian Combo, featuring all 6 vegetarian dishes for 2 people for $23.50. It was delicious! We both ended up too full but thoroughly satisfied.

I also recommend the Tusker beer from Kenya which I'd never seen anywhere else. 

We did notice that they advertise being open until 10:30pm but had their closed sign out when we left at 9:50pm, so if it's getting late, I'd call ahead.
author: Laura B.

description:
DISCLAIMER: "I have never had ethiopian food before, so the perspective of this review is from someone very traditional. think hamburgers and hot dogs."

I'm a hamburgers and hot dogs kind of guy, what can i say? It's just how I was raised. I like my food simple, tasty, and common....very...very...common. So when I was told that some friends are getting together one evening to eat some Ethiopian food, the first thing I thought was, "What is Ethiopian food?".

We sit down and take a gander at the menu, yeah I was lost. I didn't even attempt to make a failed attempt to seem cultured, I was just straight up lost. And this is with an english translation underneath each menu item describing the contents, I seriously had never imagined some of the combination they had. And as much as I hate to say it, I was skeptical. 

We ordered a ton of different things, ranging from brown mush to spicy beef. This way whoever wanted what, would have an opportunity to try something new. This is when I was thrown off, like way off. The food came in a fairly large platter (think large pizza pan) and it was spread out in sections (beef, green mush, brown mush, chicken, lettuce, yellow mush) underneath was a spongey material (like a pizza). Then came a separate order of spongey material, then some napkins. I wondered to myself "hey, where are the utensils" yeah, nothing. You had to use the sponge to pick up the food and make little "taco's" as i called them to myself as part of my inner monologue. And this was dinner. 

The food had a unique yet somewhat familiar flavor to it, but what I didn't really like was how incredibly greasy the beef was. Seriously, grease city. The experience itself is deserving of the 3 stars i'm giving it, but the food, yeah it just doesn't sit well with me. Like i said before, give me a hamburger or a hot dog and i'm set. 

Tips and Pointers:
-Come with a big group of Ethiopian food virgins, it's funny
-Try the honey wine
-Try everything

[APPROVED] (for the adventurous)
author: Eric T.

description: Great food, succulent! Been many times and enjoyed a number of the dishes. Wish they had desert items, but there's a great gelato place at 9th and Judah a short walk away.
author: Omar M.

description: I wish this place got more business. Decor is outdated and I'm guessing that's why. The food is great. The bathroom at first glance looks a little gross but it is just old. But it's clean.
author: J P.

description: A small group of us went to New Eritrea for dinner after spending the day around the Inner Sunset area. This was my first time eating Ethiopian food, so take my review with a grain of salt, but the vegetarian platter we ordered came out with a heap of tasty dishes. I couldn't have told you which dish was which, but for the most part, the food was quite flavorful. We also got plenty of the soft bread to pick up and eat the bread, although it should be noted that eating in this manner was quite messy. Overall, a lot of good food in the platters!
author: Jeremy H.

description:
My love of Ethiopian food knows no bounds, and began during my college years spent in DC. If you know DC then you know there are a million Ethiopian restaurants to choose from, and if you know SF, you know that there are...not.  My first few experiences with eating Ethiopian here were not so hot (Axiom, I'm looking at you), and I'd almost given up on finding someplace worthy. Enter New Eritrea.

Their house sampler vegetarian combo is near-perfect (and also vegan, if you're into that sort of thing), with six different dishes served on a platter of injera. Lentils, collard greens, okra, chickpeas, potatoes/cabbage and split peas, all cooked and spiced a little differently.  Their injera is fantastic, and once you pair this all with a glass or two of Tej (a sweet and delicious honey wine), you're on your way. 

The service here is perfect, in my humble opinion. Not rushed, not intrusive, but attentive in a way that you're not left wanting for anything. The restaurant itself feels a little random and dive-y, but in the best way possible. There may be Christmas lights and lots of random decorations, but it's dark and cozy and warm, and the bartender is usually playing some Ethiopian jazz. Really, it's one of my favorite places to go in the Inner Sunset.
author: heather c.

description:
Place is open late, staff is attentive, food is delicious - what more could you ask for?  

For 2 people, we got the kitfo and the vegetarian combo and extra injera (don't know if one piece + piece food is on is enough for most people but I just really like it).  Maybe it's b/c we only got one meat dish but I did not feel the food was excessively spicy
author: Scarlet H.

description: Shared the usual with my friend: meat combo and veggie combo. Ask to do family style on one platter. Meat combo comes with beef in a spiced tomato sauce, lamb curry, and chicken leg braised in a spiced tomato sauce. The lamb and chicken were good, but the beef this time was so gritty, the way meat gets when it has been cooked too long and feels like sand on the tongue.The veggie combo has changed over the 20 years I have been coming here. This one has a green veggie which I think is spinach and two different kinds of lentils, very gritty and bland. It used to come with a mushroom that was one of my favorites. You now have to order the mushrooms as a separate entree. We used to be stuffed after sharing the two combos, but portions have really shrunk. We were still hungry after this time. Oh, and to aid in digestion of all the spice, ask for the yogurt. I think it is homemade. Very tasty and complements all the sauces very well. It used to come standard on the platter, but that changed over ten years ago and you now have to ask for it.
author: Carrie W.

description: Flavorful food to satisfy your cravings for Ethiopian/Eritrean, but certainly not the best Ethiopian food I've had. Though the service is friendly and the atmosphere relaxed, New Eritrea's entree and injera portions are fairly modest and the entrees are average (even if you ask for more injera, the extra portions are also modest). The mixed vegetarian platter was somewhat unremarkable, but the zigni (squares of lean beef simmered in red pepper sauce) was tasty, but somewhat tough.
author: Chris T.

description:
Came today to try ethiopian food for the first time. Ordered three dishes 
-kilwa (beef)
-meat combination
-shrimp kilwa
for three people and decided to try the bread instead of eating white rice all the time.
Do not get it unless you like a soft dark looking sour sponge bread. Besides that the meat was alright. The three dishes were put into this circular platter and after a while I was unable to tell which meat was what but the meats were pretty good. Very strong flavoring and spices in the meat and not enough bread or rice so I would suggest getting extra. 
Overall it is a fun experience to go eat with your hands and get dirty. The restaurant is nice enough as well as the waiter. Took a little longer to get the food though unlike asian restaurants I am used to going to. 
The total came out to be around 45 including tax so I would come again and order less some time as a fun activity but not to get full.
author: Victor X.

description:
I'm good with my hands. Or so I'm told.

When I was required to eat with my hands at New Eritrea, I totally mastered that situation. 

I got the meat sampler with chicken, lamb and beef, each in a different spiced sauce. I also tried the vegetarian sampler, which came with lentils, potatoes and collard greens. The collard greens were my favorite part of the meal --- delicious! The chicken and beef were very good too. The lamb and potatoes were a bit bland. It was all served with this spongy bread (called INJERA).

With no fork in sight, I took that spongy flat bread and showed it who's boss. I scooped up the Eritrean food with the injera (it's all in the wrist) and put it right in my mouth. 

And yes, I swallowed.



*WARNING - INJERA, like a sponge, seriously expands in IN JER stomach! I was pretty full when I left New Eritrea, but by the time I got home I could barely move. Eat with caution.*
author: Kathryn T.

description:
food: 4/5
service: 5/5
decor/cleanliness: 4/5

3 stars overall because there are better Eritrean/Ethiopian in the bay area. Will come back again, but not very often.

Came here for dinner with a fairly large group. There was only a 5 minute wait. the server was very nice and was even knowledgeable about the unique beers/wines available. For people who haven't been to an Ethiopian/eritrean restaurant before, there are no utensils and everything you order is put on one large plate. Underneath the food is a big piece of bread similar to pancake and you rip pieces of it to hold your food. Definitely not a place for germaphobes since everything is shared and double dipped. This is family style so most dishes are either only meat or only vegetables, you share everything after. I thought the food was very filling and fresh. I think this is the best place in SF with this type of food, but it doesnt measure up to restaurants in ethiopian town in southern california or others in the bay area. Despite that, I will definitely be coming back here the next time I am in SF and craving eritrean food.
author: Cecile S.

description:
In the Eritrean/Ethiopean Eating Olympics, a new record was set! Now, if Ethiopean marathon runners come to mind, you would be way off. This was a bunch of crazy-hungry (feel free to change that hyphen to a comma) Yelpers...so we were sprintin'! In no less than 15 minutes time, we blazed through:

- The standard romaine lettuce, cucumber salad: doesn't really impact my rating, but I didn't care for the dressing which was like that bottled Kraft Italian crap.

- #16 Okra: sauteed with tomatoes, onions, and spices. They intentionally cook their okra lightly so as to keep it firm, not mushy and super slimy. But since I'm weird, I actually prefer my okra to be mushy and slimy.

- #17 Vegetarian Allicha: a yellow, seasoned mixture of potatoes, carrots, cauliflower, and possibly some other veggies. Other Yelpers  have found this to be bland, but I quite enjoyed the subtle flavor  and the way that this worked very well with the melt-in-your-mouth texture of the veggies.

- #19 Kantisha: sliced button mushrooms sauteed with onions, tomatoes, and the more Ethiopean spices. We ordered this as medium spicy, but I found it on the mild side...alright, but I think I'd skip it next time to try out something more interesting or traditional like lentils or split peas.

...and of course, the MEAT!

- #7 Kilwa Borho: white meat chicken cooked in a tomato based sauce, which we ordered as medium spicy. Again, the spiciness wasn't all there, but this was still quite tasty. I'm partial to dark meat, so I will probably try the #8 (marinated drumsticks) next time.

- #12 Gored-gored: OMG. It was tenderloin steak tips that straight up tasted like BUTTER. Not beef taste with a butter sauce. It was as if the beef and butter were one in artery-clogging harmony. I raved about this like a madwoman, but others thought that the butter taste was too much. Wimps.

We scarfed this all down with the generous helpings of injera bread provided (2 per person). This is some of the best injera I have ever had - subtly tart and riding the delicate line between spongy and firmness in texture. But beware - that stuff really does expand in your stomach, and you'll be feelin' it long after the meal is over.

But wait, the race wasn't over yet. We knew we still had some eating left in us, so decided to order some meat sambusas, which are like the Eritrean/Ethiopean answer to the empanada. The outer layer was chewy and crispy, with yummy seasoned ground meat inside - even better with the tomato paste-ish condiment. Though they were good at the time, I wasn't so impressed that I would order them again. 

Perhaps it was the sweet nectar of the 13% alcohol honey wine. Perhaps it was invokation of the Filipino idiom to "galit-galit muna," in short, "Shut up, and let's eat now." But we tore through that meal like we were running for gold. We were athletes fully into the game,with much of the meal spent grunting, groaning (think Sharapova...yeah, she's tennis. It's still sports, only a minor mixed metaphor), and one word calls out to the food. "Beef." "Potatoes." "Chicken." Alas, the moment went by too fast. When I return, I will have to slow myself down to a jog so that I can fully take in the tastes and smells...and hopefully not end up with indigestion the rest of the night.
author: Steph P.

description:
THE BEST INJERA EVER. 

Ok - I'm not the most authoritative figure on eritrean/ethiopian cuisine, but I've had some bad ones (anyone remember Blue "Vile") where the stews were one-sour-note, and the injera heavy, soggy, just gross, yick.
New Eritrea's is almost white, dry to the touch, fluffy, only slightly sour...the perfect accompaniment to their many tasty veggie and meat stews. My current favorites are the mushroom stew, the boiled greens, and their beef (sirloin? something uber tender) cube stew. 

Just a bit off the main Inner Sunset path, this un-pricey place is never too packed, a guaranteed no fuss, no muss, good meal.
author: CINDY K.

description:
I love Ethiopian and Eritrean food. I'll admit it. I'm happy to actively search for it. There aren't a whole lot of choices for it near home. So when we spotted this restaurant when driving home from eating in this area, we groaned and made a mental note to remember it for our next trip. We were back this weekend to visit the new Natural History Museum in the park and remembered our mental note. This place is very close to the park and in a neighborhood of restaurants and shops. 

The place was busy but not packed fairly early on a Friday night. 

New Eritrea is on the edge of the Irving Street food district. Walk until you think you've looked at all your choices and you'll see it about 1/2 a block up. That's too bad because they are quite good. 

Someone mentioned issues with parking. We've been to this area twice now and always found street parking quite easily. You may have to walk a couple or three streets. The spots turn over fairly quickly. 

The place is fairly large with two dinning areas and a full bar. It's not fancy but it isn't downscale either. Sort of homey, reasonable for a date where you aren't trying to impress with romance. Perfect for talking to your companions. 

Food is primarily the typical stuff you see on Ethopian/Eritrean Menus. There were a couple of dishes marked New Eritrean but we didn't try them. We had the smaller of the vegetarian samplers and a meat dish. The veggie sampler came with 4 choices, each quite nice. I don't believe I'd encountered the spinach one before. The potato dish was quite yummy. Everything was good. The meat dish, while not spicy hot, was pepper hot. A nice touch.

The Injera (bread) was a bit more sour than I've had at other restaurants. I quite like this variety. 

We ordered the Ethiopian stout. It's the mildest stout I've ever tasted. If you like dark beers but not stout, give this one a try. I'm definitely looking out for it. Water came in a traditional water bottle (think 1920's America) which kept the water very cold. 

Service was very prompt and attentive. The bill was a bit more than the normal Ethiopian at $25 for 2, including alcohol. Hardly expensive for a nice and very filling meal.
author: Alyson A.

description:
Tonight, I finally saw more than half the tables filled at New Eritrea, and it hit me that if I want this place to stick around, I had better try to spread the word.

There is a great selection of meaty and meatless delights, and the combo platters let you try a little of this and a little of that.  I love that the beef entrees traverse the spectrum from tartar to rare (and some of that well-done stuff too if that's what you're into), and the Samusas are a great start, but be careful because the main courses are copious.  Average price of a meal (without drinks and apps) is under ten dollars.

I have eaten just about everything on the menu and have never found anything I didn't like.  I even like the okra, and I DON"T LIKE OKRA. Tej (Ethiopian honey wine) by the carafe is a good deal, and the cold sweetness is a great balance to the savory, spicy food.  They carry Ethiopian and Eritrean beers, but I wouldn't recommend them.

The folks running the restaurant are kind and welcoming and the food comes fast and hot.  The restaurant is long and narrow, the main dining room dominated by a gorgeous wood bar that is tragically underutilized, and the tables are pretty standard, except for the shaved and painted animal skins sandwiched under Plexiglas.  I think they're cute, but some vegetarians I have dined with found them less than appetizing.

I will always cherish the night I took my three (female) roommates here and while buzzed and bored following dinner, I utilized the Tej cork, candle, and wall length mirrors to give myself a dashing charcoal mustache, and then proceeded to talk all three of my lovely companions into impromptu facial hair which they wore proudly out for ice cream.
author: Quinn S.

description:
This was the first time I ever had Ethiopian food, the flavor just blew me away.  I plan on coming back often.

I came here for dinner with my boyfriend (VERY NICE PLACE FOR A DATE! dim-lighting, quiet, comfortable, pleasant decorations, clean), I got a vegetarian combo plate and (I believe) he got the lamb (or perhaps a meat combo plate?).  The portions were huge.  I ate my leftovers for breakfast the next day (still delicious after sitting in the fridge over night), boyfriend devoured all of his food.  The honey wine is nice, a little too sweet for me but it leaves you with this nice, warm buzzed feeling comparable to drinking Chartreuse (and THAT is some good stuff).

There was only one server working when we went but he was excellent!  So friendly, helpful, and timely.  

My advice to you, plan ahead and bring extra money so you can leave your server a fat tip.  Also, try out the honey wine.
author: Melissa C.

description: Delicious and gigantic platters for sharing. If you call ahead (around lunch time) they will make Gluten Free 100% Teff Injera for you. Yummmmm!
author: Corinna M.

description:
Like many of the reviewers I've never had Ethiopian before (always thought of it as a New York thing for some reason).  So I don't have much to compare it to...except Indian food, to which it bears a striking resmblance.  Lots of lentils, and curry-esque piles of saucy diced veggies and meats (PS, the veggie combo platter is a great place to start for the undecided or uninitiated).  Thing is, I found the dishes blander than their Indian equivalents, and the spongy bread, while intriguing, just isn't the same as Hot Buttered Naan (but then, not much on this Earth is).  At least they're not afraid to make Americans eat with their hands (that's how they eat in India too, but you'd never know from the restaurants here).  

Don't forget the honey wine either.  And speaking of wine, the beautiful but under-utilized bar here makes New Eritrea a great place to kick off an Inner Sunset pub crawl (yes, there is such a thing).
author: Wes M.

description:
Maybe Your New Favorite Restaurant!

Looking for a place to take that awesome new hottie on a first date?  Want to nearly guarantee your chances of getting laid?  I'd say you have about a 100% chance of getting laid after taking a first date here.*  (see disclaimer below)

If you haven't been here before, you should seriously ask yourself why the hell you haven't checked it out yet.  This is one of the raddest restaurants in the Inner Sunset.  It will be OK - you don't need to be scared of the strange Eritrean restaurant any more.  I am your friend, and I will talk you through this:

So why is this place so rad?  The food is tremendous, they offer a nice selection of "unusual" drinks, and the service is way above average in terms of attentiveness and friendliness.  Even better because the vast majority of the rice and potato eating crowd in the neighborhood is far to dull to try something different - you won't need  a reservation.

When dining for two your orders are brought out on a round circular dish similar to a pizza pan.  A slice of Ethiopian/Eritrean bread called injera is laid down first and both entrees are served on the injera and split down the center.  If you haven't been before I suggest ordering the Kitfo (a steak tartar that I usually order rare, but is also available raw) and either the vegetable combination or the mushroom dish.  Remember, if you aren't wierd you'll probably be sharing your entree with your date - so this way you get the best meat entree and a vegetable dish to compliment it.  

To compliment these excellent selections for your entrees (the Kitfo?  Nice choice man!)  I'd suggest to you that the honey wine OR the ethiopian stout or porter will pare up naturally.  If you or your super-hot (and by now impressed) date like sweet wines - the honey wine is the way to go.  Besides, this is the only way to absolutely insure that you will get laid afterwards... so take notes: Kitfo, Vegetable combo or Mushrooms, honey wine or porter or stout. 

Ok, you're doing good so far.  

Next thing you need to know is that you eat Ethiopian/Eritrean food with your hands - no utensils.  Now this might seem scary at first, but trust me - it makes eating out just a little more fun - just remember to be a decent person and wash your hands after you go to the bathroom: you and your date will have plenty of time afterwards to make "direct" genital to mouth contact if you choose to - so for now, be a gentleman and wash your damn hands.

Ok, by now you and your date have completely enjoyed your meal.  The Kitfo has been completely cleaned out.  The injera is nearly decimated.  Your date is feeling slightly intoxicated by your awesomeness (with help from the honey wine), and now can't wait to get you home where she can rip off your clothes.  I'm going to let you figure out this next part by yourself.  I will, however, wish you good luck!  No need to thank me.

* Only applies to first dates.  Results may vary.  Also, I could think of about three hundred places that are better for taking a date if you are looking to bring on that "sexy" feeling.  Really, this review was just a lot of hyperbole ;)
author: Matthew H.

description: Delicious!  Had a spicy lamb dish with the vegetable combo.  Plenty for two people.
author: Dan C.

description:
Came here last night with a group of hot chicks.  

Food - delicious

Service - Excellent and quick

Aftermath - last night I was stuffed but fine...this morning I woke up feeling like utter death, not a good thing when I have to wake up at 5:45 in the morning to get my ass to work by 7.  My fault though...I won't blame the restaurant, just wanted to share.
