What impressed me the most, besides the amazing honey wine served to us, was the staff.  You walk in and you're immediately greeted by friendly smiles and people who genuinely want to serve you.  What a change from the last few places I've been to recently, where I've been made to feel like a second class citizen (cough...Toaster Oven...cough).  I would return simply to see the smiles again.
author: Daniela L.

description:
Awesome Ethiopian food!!  I've only been to two in the city, but I would say this is the best.

A wife and husband run the rather large restaurant.  You have to make sure you speak clearly because I'm not sure if htey understood everything we said... either way, they were full of smiles!

Drive down the street a little to Andronica's if you can't find parking.

The Reed's rootbeer is a bonus too!!
author: Peter G.

description:
I had never eaten Ethiopian food before I ate here. Honestly, I was kind of puzzled as to what Ethiopian food was exactly. I didn't think there was food in Ethiopia, based on all of the "Feed The Kids" commercials I saw everyday as a kid. 

Bad joke. I digress.

New Eritrea has really turned me on and opened me up to Ethiopian food in a really positive way. I am really glad that we decided to try something new and different to us. Our food here was delicious and flavorful. Everyone at the table shared the food family-style and we got to eat with our hands. All essential elements for a damn good meal in my book.

We started off with the beef sambosas (I love deep fried anything, no matter what country the food comes from). Then we all split a lamb (?), beef (#13-spicy) and chicken (#7) dish. The lentils and chicken were my favorite.

I have to say for this neck of the woods in the city, New Eritrea is my new favorite place to eat at. Super yummy yum yum. I nearly had to be rolled away from the dinner table.
author: Kathleen N.

description:
First off, there seems to be some confusion about Ethiopian vs. Eritrean cuisine. They're very similar but not identical. The textures, the seasonings, the overall flavor experience of Eritrean food is different. Suffice to say, if you've had Ethiopian food before and then try Eritrean, you'll see what I mean.

Now to the restaurant in question: New Eritrea is not bad at all. It just failed to truly stand out in my book. Nothing really to complain about but nothing to rave about either. One major plus: the food was not at all greasy, which is sometimes a problem with this type of cuisine. That said, we had the vegetarian sampler, so that might've had something to do with it.
author: Julia D.

description: The best Ethiopian/Eritrean food we've been able to find in the Bay Area.  There seems to be a lack of good Ethiopian restaurants around here, and none (that we've found) on the Peninsula.  It's worth a trip, but finding parking can be a drag.  My husband says their honey wine is rough with a bite, but goes down smooth after the first glass.  Their injera isn't the best we've had (is sourdough injera authentic?  I don't know), but everything else is.
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place has a good blend of authentic americanized ethiopian. It is as spicy/authentic as you desire. The injera (flat bread) is really good and and the food is amazing. This is a great place for a date. Service with a big bright smile. The alcohol us also well priced.
author: Erran A.

description: The food was okay, but definitely not the best I've had.  The sambusa was pretty greasy and sort of skimpy on the filling.  The lamb was ok, a little bland, especially considering we ordered it spicy.  The potato/carrots/cabbage was mostly potatoes and really nothing special.  The service was very friendly and I liked the atmosphere.  It's not going to be my go-to spot though.
author: J K.

description: Not my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the Bay, nor the tastiest (sup, Ensarro), but fairly solid none the less. If you happen to be in the hood and want Ethiopian, check 'em out.
author: Sara J.

description:
You know that old friend from high school that you've been meaning to get together with for the past 5  years but somehow keep flaking on? And how when you finally do go to meet her, you're nervous that she will have changed, that you'll have nothing to talk about, that it will be..awkward? But then she doesn't disappoint, everything is as it was, and you stlil have plenty in common. 

New Eritrea is that old friend, and when i walked in the other night after years away, i breathed a happy sigh of relief and settled into my comfortable surroundings. 

New Eritrea hasn't changed much over the years. The well-worn menus are limited but extremely delicious. The veggie combo plate is a steal at $10, and the meat combo plate is only $10.50. I was also glad to note that they don't put their clarified butter in ANY of the veggie dishes, which makes ordering easier for the vegan or dairy-allergic among us. despite the warnings of other reviews, i ordered one of the lighter eritrean beers and I thought it was delicious. 

The service is wonderful considering there is sometimes only one person serving all of the dinner patrons and anyone sitting at the lovely and tragically underused bar. Even if you never knew New Eritrea years ago, this restaurant will welcome you with open arms, make you feel right at home, not make fun of you if you mispronounce Eritrea (didn't even know this was a possibility until i witnessed it on my last visit here), and serve you delicious food at extremely reasonable prices. a great spot for a low-key weeknight dinner, or a festive friday night affair that makes use of the full-service bar. either way, New Eritrea will not disappoint.

update: ok, now that i've been eating eritrean food for a few more years, i have to say that the injera at new eritrea is really pretty bad. it's unfortunate, b/c the rest of the food is tasty, but without good injera it's all kind of ruined.
author: Jessica C.

description: Great food. We got the veggie and lentil samosas, the meat combo, and the veggie combo. Everything was very flavorful and well made. My only gripe is with the service. On a crowded Saturday night, they had only 2 people manning the restaurant. The wait times were a little too long for an Ethiopian restaurant. Grab a drink or two at the bar while you're waiting for your food :)
author: Mustansir M.

description:
The food here was good.  Really good.  It just took forever for us to get it.  This was strange because the place was nearly empty, and it didn't seem like we ordered anything complicated.

I'd definitely come back, and actually, I really want to come back.  My initial experience was ruined by someone in our party.  He was just annoying and couldn't stop talking about how much money he made and how it didn't make economic sense for him to drop off his own dry cleaning because, well, his time was worth more than that of the assistant his law firm had hired to drop off lawyers' dry cleaning.  It was especially annoying because at the table with him were three people who work at nonprofits.

Anyway, I'm dinging this place a star because of the slow service and the decor.  It's not really decor.  It's kind of a bar, except that there are interesting things on the walls, except that it's kind of a bar.  It's also a lot like your friend from grade school's living room.
author: John S.

description:
It def was not MY idea to eat here, but lo and behold...I actually liked it!  I wanted to be able to try a little of everything so we started out with the samosas, or at least that's what I think they were called.  Tried the veggie and meat and both were tasty.  Then we had a veggie combo plate and a meat combo plate.  I loved the chicken and the lentils and the potatoes.  I was surprisingly okay with eating most of it with my hands.  Although I did pilfer the small spoon they gave us to scoop up the sauce for our samosas.  I can't be left without any utensils!

As for the restaurant, it was roomy, and had a full bar, and the servers (the few that were there) were very friendly and very willing to explain the items on the menu and even offer up some suggestions.

One thing though...this is NOT, I repeat NOT a good place to come with lots of people.  Not in my mind anyway.  I can't imagine eating with your hands and then sharing those same plates of food with anyone other than...let's say my mom, or a boyfriend or my brother.  Only because I am so crazy about germs and I know my mom is like me, and as for my brother, well, I'm always asking him if he has washed his hands.  So I know what I know what I'm working/eating with.  Otherwise I would freak out!  No bueno.

P.S.  Not too big on the bread they serve.  Too porous and couldn't really soak my eats up!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
After living in Berkeley and the Inner Sunset, I don't think I can survive living more than 10 minutes away from an Ethiopian restaurant ... thank goodness for New Eritrea!  If you've never had Ethiopia - its not just great food with new and unique flavors - but its a culinary experience.   For me - it satisfies my childhood craving to eat with my hands and throw the utensils away! 

So, New Eritrea - my roommates and I eat here pretty regularly, usually for takeout, since we live around the corner.  If you dine in - the service is good and prompt.  If you pick up - the service is lightening fast.  

Our favorite is to order one of the two vegetarian combos. One includes okra, which I'm not a fan of, but you can ask to swap out anything with double of another.  The injira is good - a bit more vinegary than some places, but still a nice balance with the food.  The chickpeas are super tasty, but sometimes over pureed - good thing the Injira is such a great way to eat food!  

We've tried a couple of the meat dishes and are usually very pleased.  The chicken and lamb dishes are nice and tender.  The only disappointment I've had was with the beef kitfo - flank steak chopped to ground beef consistency with too much oil for my taste.  That being said - for the number of times we've eaten here - the place as a whole is definitely a favorite!

A word of warning about Injira - don't eat it with beer!  As a spongy bread, it will expand with the carbonation!  Not a pleasant feeling on a full stomach :)
author: Lisa B.

description:
This was my first experience eating Ethiopian and Eritrean food, and oh my holy hell IT WAS GOOD.  Our waiter was very nice and made some great recommendations.  Not to mention he patiently explained how to eat the food by scooping it up with the flatbread.  The experience of actually eating the food was fun in and of itself.  It's like we got to play with our food and no one yelled at us for it.

We tried the meat combination platter which consisted of zigni, zebhi dorho, and allicha bagee.  All were delicious and just the right amount of spiciness for my tastes.  My favorite was the zigni...the sauce was so good!  We also ordered the meat sambusa (meat eggroll) and the tumtumo (purred lentil beans) and loved both of those as well.

Unrelated to the food, halfway through our dinner an angry drunk came stumbling into the restaurant screaming obscenities at everyone.  Something to the effect of, "Where's your fucking maestro motherfucker!"  Uhhhh...what??

Our waiter handled him really well and called the cops.  As we were walking along Irving after our meal, we spotted him on the street being questioned by cops with his girlfriend sobbing next to him and one of his flip flops in the middle of the road.  Gotta love Friday nights.

ANYWAY.  To summarize my long novel of a review, I highly recommend New Eritrea and will definitely be returning.

If you've read this far along, I give you 5 stars.
author: Christine C.

description:
New Eritrea was my fist Ethiopian food experience. When I told my family (my lineage is boring and white) I was going there they made jokes about only bread and water being on the menu (because Ethiopians are skinny... get it? I know what you are thinking, but as far as I know no one in my family is mentally retarded). 

To be honest I did not even know Eritrea existed until I went to this restaurant. The food was excellent and so were the Kenyan and Ethiopian beers. That soppy pancake-bread soaked in dinner's juices mix at the end of the meal was heaven.

Overall a fun dining experience. Thank you Eritrea for making delicious food, good luck with your civil war!
author: Justin H.

description: OMG I forgot to write a review for this place!  Several friends and I have been here and even though we ordered a completely vegetarian dish... the food was super amazing.  I LOVED it!!  The arrangement of beans and vegetables and along with the yummy bread made our mouths water!  The service is really nice too!  They actually seem to take pride in their food!  This is so yummy... I'll go back again when I have money! =)
author: John H.

description:
We came prepared to have deliciousness served a little better and faster than Assab. And this was exactly what we got! Now - don't get me wrong, I LOVE Assab but they are closed on Sundays and usually entail a long anticipated wait to get your dish. So we chose New Eritrea. 

Yes the service is alot better. The smiles are still there, but we never had to ask for water or more napkins. We did have to order yogurt sauce as the dish we got didn't come with it. We got our check in a timely manner even tho all the serving and waiting was provided by one guy. 

We order the veggie sambusas, meat combo, veggie combo, and the new eritrean chicken special, for three peeps. It was the perfect amount of food for under $40. We also noted that the hot pepper kick that makes us sweat beads and reach for tissues wasn't as bad here, so we could have easily gone without the yogurt sauce.

The decor was dimly lit, romanty, and we sat in the back that has the glass ceiling. The front has a basket weave themed bar, that I'm sure could accomodate larger groups than Assab could.

Gosh, I'm sorry New Eritrea that you get compared so much but there aren't many places like you. I hope to see you again! 

Always, 
Danielly

P.S. I think its sad seeing how yelpers here say samosas instead of sambusas. Its like saying Eritrean is like Ethiopian. Which is like going to a Cambodian restaurant and saying, 'OMG! I never had Vietnamese!" 
Retards.
author: Danielly A.

description:
This is a GREAT hidden gem tucked away in the 9th & Irving 'hood.  The staff here is so amazingly friendly, you'll feel right at ease once you step through the front door, even if you're apprehensive about giving Eritrean a try.  If you're unsure of what to order, definitely take the lead from your waiter, that's what we did.  We ended up getting a vegetable dish and a lamb dish and thought it was so jam-packed with flavor and spices and oomph!

To complement our dishes, we sipped on some Eritrean-style coffee all throughout our meal and man, talk about full-bodied goodness of wonderment!!  That coffee was uber-strong and packed a flavor punch!  (I just got a vision of the red Kool-Aid Pitcher bursting through a brick wall, saying "Oh yeaaahhh!", only instead of holding a pitcher of the red stuff, he's toting a carafe of New Eritrea brewed coffee.  Deee-lish!)

Swing by this place the next time you find yourself in the Inner Sunset and don't be intimidated you if you're a Eritrean food novice.
author: Katie C.

description:
We were looking for snacks one night before going to the Friday night De  Young Museum bash .... late as usual in the misty mist of 9th and Irving. My vegetarian aunt likes to restaurant shop, looking at about 10 before deciding to go back and read the menus of a couple. For some reason this makes me insane. I should be more patient with my dear Aunt. But anyway, we walked pretty far down Irving from 9th (well 3 or 4 blocks) and found this place. I put my foot down. The bar looked so welcoming, and the colors were bright and inviting. 

I got the most popular dish (the menu said), which was chicken with barbeque-like sauce. It was two chicken legs arranged side by side with a huge - where did they get that chicken?? - hard boiled egg between them. Have you ever had a warm hard boiled egg with barbecue sauce? It's actually not half bad... at all. The sauce is truly amazing and goes wonderfully with the spongy all purpose use-as-a-napkin-or-any-utensil bread which lines the plates and fills the basket they bring to your table. It's actually like a massive crepe. This is making me hungry.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Love this place!  Always start out with a bottle of honey wine, usually get another.  So tasty and perfect for the spicy meat dishes.  The veg sampler is a good mild dish to simmer your tongue down.  I actually love that when you ask for spicy, you get spicy, unlike at most Indian joints where you order lamb vindaloo for the jalapeno sauce and it's not spicy because you happen to have ass-white coloring.

Service is always sweet and lovely.  

This spot is just one of many that make my neighborhood badass.
author: Staci M.

description: I just still love this place... it makes Assab look like cafeteria food (and service)... I had my birthday dinner her on Saturday and they went out of their way to be accommodating and made me feel special. They can seat up to I think 30 and they do it with a smile...
author: Angela M.

description:
I have had Ethiopian food several times, but never Eritrean. To tell the truth, I don't think I have enough knowledge of their respective dishes to discern between the two. 
The vegetarian sampler platter was awesome. I recommend this especially for someone who has never had this type of food because you get a little of everything.
I ate there on a Sunday evening and the place was dead. Whats up with that- they have a full service bar! I learned from another reviewer that these are the only importers of the Eritrean king of beers in the US and now I wish I'd tried some. 
Bottom line: more people should come here. I'd hate to see a good place like this have to close its doors.

*edit* Thanks Yelp spell check
author: Andrew B.

description:
Have been coming here on and off for years and think its the best Ethiopian/Eritrean food Ive had in the city.  My friend I came with is an expert, lived in the region and says this is the only place that she thinks serves the real deal.  I'm buying it.

The Injera is the best in the city.  That, when it comes down to it, is what makes this food so special and sets this restaurant apart.  It has a certain sourdough-like tang that is missing from other imitation injera.  Has something to do with the grains used and how they make it. 

The staff is friendly and helpful.  The space is open, light and airy and they have decorated it with photos and crafts from Eritrea.  Never had a problem finding a table - infact it usually seems pretty empty.  Everything Ive tried is good.   Last night it was veggie sambusas to start, and then chicken and lamb served family style on the injera bread with salad, lentils and cream.  Washed down with a Harrar beer.

Go on, get your hands dirty.
author: Brad C.

description:
This is the birth place where I broke free and started traveling the food path less traveled, and it has made all the difference. One of my cousins took me here over 15 years ago and I had no idea what to expect. It was my first time eating Eritrean/Ethiopian. After all these years of having had it all over the country, this is by far one of my favorites.

The proportions here are great and vegetarian friendly. It's a place that lets the food speak for itself. I owe a lot to this place and to my cousin for taking me here, because I've been branching out towards other ethnic foods ever since. Had I had a bad experience here, I still would be eating at the Olive Garden or something.
author: Steve Y.

description: The food was amazing especially with the Honey Wine.  The wine made the food smooth.
author: Melody B.

description:
First time having Ethiopian food. J and I shared the spicy kilwa (beef) and the veggie combo. The kilwas was really yummy, but super oily. Trying to eat it with only a thin piece of injera between my fingers and the oil was difficult. Of the veggies, J and I agreed that the hamli (collard greens) and shiro (split peas) were the best. The potato dish was cold when it was served to us, and the lentil (or was it chickpea) puree was bland and lacked texture.

The injera was definitely something I had never experienced before. Its super thin, spongy, and slightly sour. Overall, I think the meal would've been better if the bread was more like naan than how it was. I'd be willing to give New Eritrea another try-- next time with more meat!
author: Susanna W.

description:
Highly addictive! I'm not sure what it is, but the next day we were all craving a second trip back.  The prices are about the lowest anywhere around, you get a huge amount, everything's really fresh tasting and just the right blend of yummy + healthy feeling.  Everyone gets their own basket/plate of spongy crepes that taste the perfect amount sour (like buttermilk or yogurt was used in them, maybe?) There's a vegetarian menu and meat platters.  The hot pasty red spice that they serve with the appetizer somosa thingies is awesome.  It's family owned from what I could gather, and the owner (also the server) was really sweet.  We learned some Eritrean history - and found out he's the only US importer for the Eritrean national beer they serve.

From first impression, its kinda like Indian food in the textures and serving style of the dishes (without the rice).  Doesn't taste like Indian though - just resembles it a little in form.  I'd recommend this place to anyone.  It's surprising how un-busy it is.  And it was nice to see a glimpse of a country that i now wish i knew more about.
author: Today Y.

description:
I've checked out all the "Habessha" restaurants in the Bay Area and this is one of the best.
 
My Ethiopian friends did not believe my judgment
since I am a "fereng". I made another trip with their company and they confirmed it is good even by their lofty standards.

This place epitomizes family-owned and run.  The bartender, waiters, and chefs are all siblings.  The exceptional service and warmth will helplessly make you a regular customer.

Make sure to try the Ethiopian Harrar or the Eritrean Asmara beer. They will compliment the spicy food.  Want something stronger?  There's Eritrean zambouka that will rival anything from Greece.  Addis, an Ethiopian tea, is my favorite non-alcoholic drink.

This is the best Ethiopian food outside of Little Ethiopia in Oakland.  Definitely the best Ethiopian food from an Eritrean restaurant.
author: Stephen W.

description:
I wouldn't call myself experienced in Ethiopian, but I have been to other places and this one is just...nicer.  It is very inviting and cozy, although when I went it wasn't busy at all (but it was a Monday night and apparently that is a new addition to their schedule). They have a full bar, if that is what you want, and the atmosphere is friendly. They leave you water in a fun jug and the staff don't seem to begrudge your presence. There is quite a lot of space, so I wouldn't worry about coming on a busy night.

Their injara was delicious, the Kilwa [beef/tomatoes] was delicious, and the vegetarian Alicha was fab. My friends had a lamb dish that looked and smelled yummy, but I don't eat lamb and I forget what it was called...so try some lamb!

Overall, great place. I'll definitely be going back!
author: Rachel B.

description: What a wonderful place. The food is out of this world and every time we go there we are treated like family. The first time I went there was right after I got back from a two week trip to Ethiopia and I had to have some good Ethiopian grub. Can't wait to go back.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
Sampler Sampler Sampler Platter. Dig in with a good technique and friend or someone you'd like to get to know better quickly.

The open spaces and light coastal African vibe are complimented by the friendly people who made this their life.
author: River W.

description: Four stars? Really? Maybe it's just not my type of food but I find the taste of food barely palatable.  From the dirt tasting lentils to the weird spongey bread, I just didn't enjoy it.
author: Remus L.

description:
I am very surprised that this place doesn't get that much attention.  Every time we have gone, we've had more than 4 people in our party and the owners are _always_ happy to find seating for us.  Service is relatively quick and I have yet to see one of the servers with nothing less than a smile.

The food is great.  So far we have yet to venture outside of the typical platters.  However, I don't see a reason to yet as it's always very good and filling.
author: Chris M.

description:
You learn something new everyday, yesterday I learned that I really like Ethiopian Food. This place is great. A must have is the vegetarian combination dish. The Injira (light pancake-esque bread) was a little bland, but meshed well with the potent flavors of the various veggie and chicken dishes we ordered (and acted as a cool spoon-sponge). The ginger ale is also honey flavored and really tasty.  
The outdoor/indoor patio has mirrors on the walls, a ceiling of glass, and plants hanging all over which all lead to a cool effect of eating outside but being indoors, although some may be distracted by all those mirrors. Service was great and they also offer forks for those of you less inclined to eat with your hands (no matter me). 4 stars because I was impressed and had no complaints! enjoy.
author: Jordan V.

description: Mmmm, mmmm good.  Besides the great food and service I also, really liked the Ethiopian Stout they have, totally different then any other stout I've ever had, sweet and refreshing!
author: Y S.

description: Great food, good value.  This first experience with Eritrean/Ethiopian cuisine did not disappoint.  Service was super friendly and efficient, despite the fact that it was a 2-man show in the front with just the host and a server who doubled as bartender.  Our party of four opted for an interactive family style meal with all of our entrees (meat combo, veggie combo, zilwa, and gored gored) served on a large platter lined with injera.  I'm no Eritrean connoisseur, but I found every dish to be flavorful and quite tasty.  The gored gored was especially spicy (yum!) and the lamb had a nice flavor, but was perhaps a little overcooked.  The flavors and spices pack a strong punch and are reminiscent of Indian food, so this stuff is not for the faint of heart (or stomach), but it's good.  We'll be back.
author: Liz N.

description:
This was so cool!  

A friend once described Ethiopian food as spicy meats and veggies with delicious sauces and a pancake-like bread that is "so soft that you want to use it as a pillow."  Of course, I thought he was crazy.. until I ate at New Eritrea a couple of months ago.  It's all true!

The food was very yummy, although a little spicier than what I'm normally comfortable with (I'm a wuss though).  I have extensive food allergies, and they were very nice and helpful about it.  I can't eat beans, so I thought there would be nothing on the menu for me, but the server gave me some great suggestions and information.

Fun place to go with a group of friends.
author: Gabby A.

description:
A nice, quiet place to take a date or family, especially when other places are a zoo. It is family owned and operated, with the space being well organized and clean. The service has always been prompt, helpful, and personable. 
 
The food comes out quickly, and is of a consistent quality. I have not tried Ethiopian food elsewhere, so I cannot compare authenticity or flavors, but I enjoyed the sampler of everything and have come back for more. 
 
It can be very filling and rich, so if you're looking to go out dancing, etc. after it may not be the right place for you. Try the Ethiopian beers too, they are quite good and have a distinctive flavor!
author: Aaron C.

description:
I'm always open to trying new food and last night I found my new hot spot.  When you walk in right away you feel relaxed and you know your in company of good people.  The atmosphere and lighting were just to my likes.  It had a nice bar with the cool tube lights behind it that reflected off the mirrors on each wall.  Then the lights were a rose tint so I did not feel like i was in My cube at work, this is very important to me because i hate the restaurants where your eating with your cell phone next to your food so you can see what your eating, I mean that an exaggeration, but u know what I mean.

So my friend that I went with has been there a few times so he suggested that we get the samples of both the veggie and meat.  Great choice because man did I love them all and I usually hate spinach but that was good too.  The lamb was amazing the chicken ooh man.  There are no words to express how wonderful it all was.  Ooh and I left out the best part... well 2 best parts, 1. they brought  a craft of water to the table, i loved this because i drink A LOT of WATER, especially with spicy foods, there was only one but ya.  
And the coolest thing, NO SILVER WEAR!! you eat all of your food with this spongy like pita like soft bready thing... sounds weird but tastes great.  And its fun, i never thought id enjoy eating with my hands so much.  But I did.

Also the staff was very nice and speedy.  Great service. Amazing food and a great place to try out if you want to explore the other side of the world without leaving your own city!
author: Megan L.

description:
Excellent Ethiopian.  I'd have this tied with Rassala's.  If you want something more upscale with live jazz, head to Rassala's.  If you want something more neighborhoody and warm, head here.  

New Eritrea has a full bar, a wide selection of good teas, excellent food, great prices, and super friendly staff.  Like always, we ordered the veggie combo and the meat combo.  But we decided to make a substitution.  We added in Shiro (I think that was the name -- it was red lentil).  We thought it was something different than what came out.  What came out was totally pureed Shiro (think soup), and it had a funky taste.  We just ate around it.

Stick with their pairings and avoid the Shiro!!!
author: S J.

description:
Oh yes. Oh my god YES.

Very excellent service, amazing tasting food, wonderful middle-of-the-road (not fancy) establishment. I cannot wait to go back!!!
author: Stumbalina b.

description: New Eritrea is a gem for the Inner Sunset and a good value for the money. While it doesn't match up as well to the Eritrean and Ethiopian eateries in Oakland, New Eritrea is wonderful if you're in the neighborhood or  don't feel like crossing the Bay Bridge or spending a lot of money. Service is attentive without being overbearing and dishes are satisfying.
author: Grayson E.

description:
Yay for an open-minded mom who doesn't mind being dragged to a birthday dinner way out in the city to eat food she's never tried before with her gay vegan son.
This is only my second time trying Ethiopian and definitely my favorite of the two. The potatoes and lentils were both excellent - the potatoes had a great buttery taste and the lentils really added some spice to the meal.
The injera was just spongy enough and not too sour, but still with a nice flavor, plus it is absolutely the greatest utensil/dinnerware ever invented.
Service was friendly, but certainly not doting. I found myself craving more Allicha within 24 hours.
author: Christopher D.

description:
This place is rad and its close to home, excellent! 

The interior of the restaurant is unique and relaxing. The music chill and the wait staff attentive and also chill.

The food was delicious. Eat here and you won't be disappointed unless of course you don't like Ethiopian food and hate America.
author: Sam T.

description:
OK, I'm NOT an Ethiopian food fan - that was before I ate here.  As with everything, I decided to give it another chance and thank goodness for that.  

The app:  My favorite was the beef eggroll appetizer.  It was so good we ordered another one!
The food: The food (some of it cooked in butter... YUM) was delicious.  We had the chicken, the beef and the veggie platter.  ALL were so delicious and tasty.
The bread:  ehh... let's just say I'm not a spongy bread person.  But I was hungry.  The food was tasty enough to cover for the bread
The wine:  I had the African Pinotage to accompany my dinner.  It was delicious and went well with the tasty food!  The rest had the honey wine - very sweet - almost like a muscat.  They loved it.

Other notes:
- Make sure you wash your hands!  It's finger food!
- Parking is tough, so allocate plenty of time for that!
author: Nutmeg Y.

description: The hubby and I tried this place on a Friday night and they have an impressive full bar with very helpful and friendly staff.  Injera bread was a bit too sour for my taste.  All food came really quick and loved the sample of the veggie & meat combos.  It might not look like a lot of food, but that crepe bread really makes you full!  Also tried the honey wine, it was OK, though I'm not a drinker.  I would definitely go back, though its not something I'd crave week over week.
author: Julie W.

description:
I like eating with my hands...WHEN MY NAILS ARE NOT LONG.  After I left the restaurant, I found a mini fifth helping under my nails.  
Very friendly service and quiet atmosphere.  Good food, but to be frankly honest I don't have too many Eritrea Restaurants to compare with.  My absolute favorite Eritrea Restaurant is in Portland.
author: Lisa L.

description: Tastiest Ethiopian in the city! The owner is always so friendly and you'll never have to wait for a table. Great comfort food for rainy days (or for when you just feel like stuffing your face!)
author: Maria Y.

description:
really like this place. haven't been in a while but if you're into eritrean food, definitely come here. of course its not like there are a million eritrean restaurants in the neighborhood, let alone the city, but this really is a great spot. 

i think you definitely have to be into the flavors, type of food, but personally, i think its delicious. go with a group, much more fun that way. and wash your hands before you start.
author: Georgia W.

description:
This place was my first time eating with my hands. Kinda strange at first, but the crepe-type bread stuff (injira?) made it not so messy.  Whatever, I am not a foodie and found it sooo tasty. Had some lean beef plate (altho you should share, if you're a spicy eater and someone else isn't, better to not share).
The honey wine was super sweet and a great drink to add to the meal. I'm usually a water-only type of person, but am glad we splurged on the wine.  
Don't be wary of the inside because of what you see the outside look like during the day. Inside its all nice and spacious with cozy lights and friendly waiters.  I do think Matt is right in saying this is a great date spot.
author: Anna O.

description:
I personally like this place for a variety of reasons; DELICIOUS, authentic Ethiopian food, within walking distance from my house, reasonably priced (2 can eat for just a little over $20 if you just order the entrees... which are generously portioned and will make you full) and pretty attentive service.  

That being said, let me just say that, for most people, Ethiopian food is an acquired taste.  Please note:

1) If you don't like the taste of sourdough bread, you probably won't like most Ethiopian food - their stews are almost always served inside a large round crepe made of injera that tastes like the inside of a sourdough loaf.  

2) If touching your food/eating with no utensils freaks you out, you are a wuss & hypochondriac, and this place probably isn't for you.  There are no utensils - you rip off pieces of the injera crepe and dip it in the stew.  

3) Lighting in the restaurant is dim, which some people find sexy, and others find horrifying or claims it gives them migraines.  So, if you need bright ass lighting, should probably go somewhere else.

That aside, don't hate on the food just because it's not what you're used to.  The servers are nice (usually the owners will serve you themselves) and their mint tea is very refreshing.

Why only 4 stars?  This place only opens for dinner... 5 pm or after most days. Pooh...
author: Catherine C.

description: This is one of the best restaurants I have EVER been to!!!  It's not fancy at all, but it's spacious, the staff is SUPER nice, and the selection is great.  This was my first time eating Eritrean food and it was absolutely amazing - flavorful, spicy, fresh, filling, and quite traditional.  I would absolutely recommend it to everyone and anyone!
author: Amy P.

description:
It was interesting.... 

I've never had eritrean food so this surprised me. I do believe it's something everyone should try and like other's have said, you either like it, or you don't. 

I've never tasted anything like it. So if you're all up for adventure, go for it.
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
If you have a hankering for Eritrean or Ethiopian, or you THINK you have a hankering, but have never tried it and want something new--then this is your place.  I say this because New Eritrea is a great restaurant to ease a newbie into this bold culinary realm.  Thats not to say that New Eritrea lacks authenticity, like one of those places that falls between what it should be and what the owners think people would want.  Like P.F. Changs or something.  This is NOT the case here.

Whether you have a favorite Eretrian dish, or know nothing about it, getting the vegetable AND meat combo dishes is really the best way to sample the plethora of their offerings.  Everything I have sampled has had good, deep, rounded flavor, and their injerea bread is just perfectly tart and springy.  I am especially fond of that pureed squash dish and cubed lamb stew, of course.

I'll be back again.
author: Thomas M.

description:
I am so glad my roommate and I decided to come here. We wanted to try somewhere new in the Sunset and settled on New Eritrea. 

The atmosphere was relaxing and the waiter gave a great recommendation. 

The Ethiopian spices were strong, but as fans of Indian food, we were impressed with the flavors. We were hesitant at first about eating with our hands, but part of enjoying the food is experiencing a different culture. This may be something to consider if you are going on a first date. 

The portions were slightly larger than expected, but that just meant we left with happily full bellies. 

 I would suggest not ordering the lentil sambusa because it was filled sparingly and on the greasy side.Overall the main meal was delicious . We ordered two chicken dinners which both had tender meat and vegetables. I especially enjoyed the dish with mushrooms and tomatoes.
author: Brittany B.

description:
So, now that we've been here a couple of times, I wanted to ensure that the service and quality were consistent... they were.  I am a HUGE fan of kitfo (leb leb (rare))... and I have tried almost every Ethiopian restaurant in the South Bay and now I'm moving my way up the peninsula.  I know that Eritrean food isn't necessarily "Ethiopian" food, but it's pretty darn close. The kitfo was a little bit spicier than the others I have tried, but definitely hit the spot.  It was great! They did serve it in a bowl, and I would have preferred that they just slid it off onto the injera like they do at other restaurants, but this is no big deal, because I scooped it all myself.  

The water bottles that they provide at first are pretty nifty than having to wait for the server each time your glass goes empty.  Also, the service was great! We had the same server twice and he was very friendly and definitely checked up on us.  One thing I did notice was that the injera wasn't as thick as I'm used to.  It was almost crepe like.. even perhaps a little bit thinner and it tore pretty easily when scooping up food, but if you're watching your carbs, you might actually consider the thinner injera a blessing... but come on, who really goes out for Ethiopian/Eritrean when you're on a diet? 

There is a fixed "meat combo" of 3 items, so you get the same things over and over... I would prefer the "pick 3", but... overall things were great. As Ah-nold says, "I'll be back!"

Bottom line: good food, great atmosphere, great service.
author: Buck T.

description:
YUM!  

A friend of mine convinced me to go all the way out to the foggy Sunset for dinner, and gave me the choice of vegan/raw food or New Eritrea. And am I ever glad with my choice.  The food was yummy, and all, and that's great, but the best part was the service.

They waitstaff was friendly and helpful, but not intrusive.  My friend and I sat there for 2 1/2 hours, the place closed without us noticing, and they said nothing.  They just let us talk and brought us more water.  

So, great place for a casual weekday dinner!  

Ohh, and apparently the veggie stuff is vegan too!
author: Bianca P.

description:
I stumbled across this place on a whim because I needed to kill some time in the Sunset. Saw it on Yelp and thought I'd try it out because I wasn't in the mood for Chinese food. 

This place blew me away from the beginning. Great atmosphere, nice fully stocked bar, clean, friendly service, obvious care in keeping the place up, good prices, great food with large portions, good music. I can't think of many more things that I would look for in a restaurant! 

Probably the only thing that it could improve on is the parking, which isn't in their control. One other thing I didn't check out, was the bathroom. Judging from the cleanliness of the dinning area, I'm sure it was fine. 

This place truly has it all. Right down to the proprietor's lovely 23 month old daughter Abigail - I highly recommend Eritrea Restaurant and Bar.
author: Morgan F.

description: The owner is really friendly and the food is really great. Eating with your hands is the best part. The bread they serve with your dish is not too sour or soft. I have been going here for a long time now and don't ever plan on stopping.
author: Michael T.

description:
My BF and I stumbled into this place after he refused to wait for a table at Pomelo (mistake we paid dearly for). The portions where very small for the asking price, highly over priced. Later we would appreciate the small portions since the food was God awful. You know a place is not good if you have the feeling of wanting to throw up right after. It seemed like a fun idea to use our finger as silverware except for the fact the stench of the food was still there 3 days later. My BF said he felt he had given a gloveless proctology exam, every time he caught a whiff of his hand. 
Maybe ...we just don't like Ethiopian cusine ...God knows!!
author: Sandra M.

description:
Good eats. I've had Ethiopian several times before at other good restaurants and this place held its own.  We went on a Thursday night around 8 and it wasn't too crowded, but wasn't empty either. Maybe it was the deceptively large and spacious accomodations-much more so than other Ethiopian places I've been to.   The atmosphere was nice, with soft lighting.  Service was excellent, even with just two staff (that we saw).  Our food came out quickly, too.

For four girls and a guy (last time I checked), we ordered the kilwa (beef), asa kilwa (fish), New Eritrea Special (chicken), and Vegetarian Combo for 2, which is a sampler of all six of their vegetarian plates.  Given the generous amounts of injera (savory flatbread), we were all quite full at the end. There was even a bit of leftover, sauce-enriched injera ("Injera: The Flavor-Saver")  The damages?  Only $16/person incl tax and tip (but not drinks).  Not bad at all.   I will definetely go there again, since it's the closest Ethiopian to my place.  

For the newbie:
** You'll want to wash your hands before and after the meal.
** The food is deceptively filling, especially when you consider that you're eating the injera it's sitting on.
** Get extra napkins!  (see first tip)
author: Chris A.

description: My husband and I love coming here for dinner! The people that work here are lovely and the food is  delicious every time. The price is very, very reasonable (the vegetarian platter for two is around $25) and they have a full bar if you are in the mood. Nothing pretentious or unnecessary with the decor. Some may not like the TV on in the background (I normally do not) but somehow it makes me feel like I am about to get food cooked by someone's mom.... In a good way! I really can't decide what my favorite dish is here, and love that they have so much variety! I truly feel that this restaurant deserves 5 stars for the combination of the delicious food and truly warm staff. Compared to my last experience at a fine dining restaurant that will go unnamed (where I spend about 15 times the amount I would here) I am beginning to realize that simple, fresh and honest food is what really makes me happy. Plus I would eat here every week if I had the time. Once a month will have to do for now.
author: Brigid S.

description:
This food is not a bastardized or watered down version of real Eritrean food. It's the real deal.

The inside is surprisingly nice and spacious. By the looks of the outside, you would just expect your typical hole-in-the-wall with just a few tables.

Considering the amount of food you get, it's cheap. You can feed 3-4 people easily for $50. Vegetarian options available, which is great, and a great spot for spicy food lovers.

The wait staff are very friendly and accomodating.

I will keep coming back here!
author: Courtney S.

description:
My wife and I came here on our first date, and I swear, the food tastes even better now than it did then. I especially recommend (my Eritrean fails me, so here's the description) the lamb dish with potatoes.

An added bonus is that pretty much everything is gluten free, so it's safe for celiacs (with the obvious exception of the beer and the somewhat less obvious exception of their appetizers made with an egg roll wrapper). They also have at least five dishes which are 100% vegan.
author: Dave M.

description: Not good if you've had good Ethiopian/Eritrean food before.  The sambusas were greasy, and the injera was too thick.  The okra and potato veggie dishes were tasty, but overall, this meal fell flat.
author: M B.

description:
I just want to make this review short as I am stuffed and sleepy from a well rounded meal.

The portions, and this is coming from an U.S. born mid-western boy, were large.  If you leave unsatisfied then I would say you might want to have your doctor check for parasites. 

The flavor of the food was incredible.  The spinach and okra especially, with hints of lime to increase the freshness of the dish.   

The price, for 3 dishes and two glasses of wine, 40 bucks isn't that bad. Next time, I'll try the apps but glad I didn't because we could barely finish what we had.

Thumbs up all around.
author: michael h.

description:
This place was...interesting. It was my first time trying Ethiopian food and I was ready to get down and dirty with the food.  I called earlier to reserve a table for 4 and when our party expanded to 6, the waiter was very generous and gave us the round table near the front.  

We ordered the Zigni (beef), the "all-time favorite" Zebhi Dorho (chicken), Kilwa Begee (lamb), another meat and the Vegetarian combo, and a bottle of Honey Wine.  We each got our own basket of injera to eat with our meal.  Our whole order came out on this HUGE platter to share.  It was amazing!  We were hesitant to eat without utensils...but we didn't want to offend the waiter by asking for some...so we dug in!

-The injera tasted too sour to me...almost as if it was going bad.  I sucked it up and ate it anyway.  
-Honey wine...once you put it in your mouth it tastes like pure honey, then you swallow and it tastes like pure alcohol.  It sounded so delightful on the menu...but definitely not on the tongue.
-Out of all the dishes we ordered, the lamb was the best. (It even beat the "all time favorite" chicken).

We each paid $15/person and left reasonably full.  (We had three guys, three girls.)  Overall, it was an interesting experience...but I guess my palate is not sophisticated enough for Ethiopian food.  During the whole meal, I was craving Indian food...so maybe next time, I'll just do that...
author: Helen V.

description:
Actually, more like 4.5 stars

It is not the best Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurant I've been to in the U.S., but it certainly is one of my favorites.

I'm what you call a "one-off" gal. Tried it, check it off, move on. Rarely do I eat at the same place frequently and when I do, well then it's real good.

I always get the veggie combo. I love the idea of having small servings of a variety of dishes rather than just one dish. This place has the sweetest waitstaff (I think they are the owners) who will substitute veggie dishes on the veggie combo. If you're like me and want to get your greens, order "Hamil" (collard greens simmered in spices). The Okra is fantastic as is the "Tumtumo" (lentils pureed and simmered in onions, tomatoes, garlic and spices) and "Shiro" (split peas, tomatoes, onions and spices).

This is the cleanest and nicest Eritrean restaurant in San Francisco and a wonderful part of the Inner Sunset dining scene.
author: O O.

description:
This is possibly my most favorite restaurant in the Bay Area. The kitchen rarely has an off night and the service is always super friendly and attentive. The food is incredibly flavorful and expertly seasoned AND a lot of bang for your buck. Get the Gored Gored or the Kitfo and it's the equivalent of getting a huge yummy steak for only 10 or 12 bucks. The Kitfo is my personal fave- raw or rare ground beef served in clarified butter with lots of excellent East African spices and a little yogurt on the side. Mmmmmmmm!!

If you are looking for some veggie options, the Shiro (spicy garbanzo puree) is tasty and the mushroom dish is divine- super spicy!

I personally think that Eritrean cuisine tends to be more flavorful (+ spicy!) and interesting than Ethiopian and New Eritrea is the most consistent and yummy Eritrean around (Assab is great too but not quite as consistent and the service there is always painfully slow). The music here is often great too- lots of fab Ethiopian (they often play discs from the Ethiopques series!) and East African stuff.

The only downside is that when they are busy, the food can take a while so be sure to get a cheap beer on tap and an appetizer to hold you over. The sometimes slow service is forgivable since damn, there is only one person in the kitchen cooking all that food!

I absolutely adore this place. The food is always so tasty that I eat until I'm about to explode, the servers are super sweet, the injera is always fresh and tangy and the ambiance is dark and cozy. It's great for parties too- my husband and I have held our last few birthdays there. Check it out!
author: miss m.

description:
I'm kicking myself that I haven't come here sooner....well I know why, parking stinks.  But since we're all familiar with that I will go on about the food.  
The food is great with a pleasant blend of spices.  It's nice that even with the meat dishes you don't come away feeling like you ate something really heavy and bad for you.  You leave full, but not feeling guilty.  On the night I was there, service was prompt and friendly.  There were also quite a few customers.  I was happy to see that.  Anyhow, I will definately be going back and I will be bringing friends.
author: Kirsten F.

description:
Unlike many of the other reviewers on here (or at least the three I took time to read) I have had ethiopian before New Eritrea.

And this place definitely lived up to my expectations.  I'm a big Injira snob (the bread you eat all the yummy goodness with), and their Injira is great, not too tangy, but not too bland either.

If you're a first timer, I highly recommend the Vegetarian Combo (Hamil, Tumtumo and Veggie Allicha) and Kilwha Borho OR New Eritrean Special.

Also, the Eritrean beer is quite good.  That's something else you should try if you have couple extra bucks to spend!
author: Becca B.

description: Awesome! Shared the vegetarian house sampler and each of the six dishes was super good (well the potatoes were just potatoey). For $12 apiece, each of us left with full bellies and a new go to restaurant.
author: Diane R.

description:
Everytime I go to New Eritrea, I feel incredibly welcomed by the owners. None of the pretentious rubbish you experience at many SF foodie restaurants.

Love the kilwa begee and alicha begee (lamb dishes). Start of your meal with the lentil and meat sambusas smothered with a generous helping of the ginger-chili paste...you won't regret it.

If you're looking for a no frills, laid back, great food, great service type of place, check out New Eritrea.
author: Ijay J.

description:
The most schizophrenic interior that I've been to of any Ethiopian restaurant - a full size tavern taking up the entrance with a random skylight, some wicker decorations in an alcove in the wall, and mirrors placed unexpectedly throughout.  Tried the vegetarian, meat samplers along with the catfish, which was more than enough for 3 people.

Injera was well-prepared and the combinations had a nice diversity - chicken, lamb, beef, and a smattering of vegetables with a lettuce salad.  The catfish was my favorite - tender with a nice spicy kick.  Everything was a bit more sour than I was accustomed to, but tasty nonetheless.
author: Jeremy C.

description: This is only the second Eritrean restaurant I have ate at, so I don't have much to compare it too. But what I have had, I have tended not to like so much. Both times I had Eritrean food, I loved the first few bites, but soon after that the mix of spices becomes a tad bit had to stomach. Its not that their food is spicy- it is not- its just a "unique" mix of spices that don't seem to mesh together with the food. Its somewhat like Indian food, but nowhere as tasty. At New Eritrea. I had the raw steak "tifto?" Like I said, the first few bites were great, but finishing more than half of it became a choir. However I'm still going to give New Eritrea 4 stars for the unique experience and extremely friendly service. Our waitress truly made us feel welcomed.
author: David D.

description:
I love this place. Quaint,great atmosphere, friendly waitstaff, super reasonable and great food!  I've been here twice now and have really enjoyed both experiences. I love that they keep it real and make you use the bread to consume the food.  Great for a group or date night.
I recommend the veggie combo! Yum!  I'll be back!!
author: Melyss S.

description:
Went there for drinks at the bar to try the great variety of African beer (Tuskers from Kenya!)...while we were there, we had the lentil Samboas (aka Samosas) which I thought were pretty weak...more of a pancake than anything else (I have had many Samosas in my life!).

Friendly service - good vibe.
author: David H.

description:
This place was great! I came here two weeks ago for my second time, had the same server, same food. I still can't remember the names of everything we got because the eight of us just picked out 8 random dishes to share amongst the table. We had a lot of beef, chicken and lamb, and everything was cooked well! Full of flavor!

With everything that we ordered, dinner came out to be about $12 per person. Not bad, considering how much food we got. For those of you who've never eaten Eritrean food before, keep in mind that you don't eat with forks here! Instead, you have this spongy bread-type thing that tastes a little sour, but it's perfect for picking up the food. Delicious. I'd definitely go back again. :)
author: Melissa D.

description: It's been a long minute since I was last here. Couple of notable changes since my last review: the shrimp selection sucks now (as in... perhaps, frozen bagged shrimp instead of fresh ones) and the restaurant was actually pretty full. In all the dinners I've gone to there, only 3 tables or something would have customers. Last night most tables were occupied. Has the place finally gained attention? The service is still great, but why sacrifice the shrimp?!
author: Anio D.

description: I got the meat combo, it was incredible. Every single thing on that plate was great! I cant wait to come back. I had never had ethiopian food before but my eyes have been opened. The honey wine and ethipoian beer was a little weird to me, but i can see how others might like it! And best of all, GREAT PRICES!!!!
author: Nelson S.

description:
Delicious and the price is just right.

We go here often and really enjoy the food.  The service is great and the staff is always very friendly.  The restaurant is large enough that you never have to wait for a table and they can accommodate large groups.

If you enjoy a good beer, I recommend the Hakim Stout.  It is excellent and very difficult to find.
author: Ryan L.

description: Food was so yum. Eat with ur fingers and enjoy the spice!
author: Summer L.

description:
We'd never tried Eritrean before last week, and now we've eaten at at New Eritrea twice.  It is so delicious.  Very reasonably priced -- about $12.00 for a ton of food -- two pieces of Eritrean bread, one lining the plate and one to use as a utensil, salad, side of vegies and your choice of a main dish.  I had the #9 the first time (spicy - but not overwhemingly so) and it was delicious lamb.  The second time I tried the New Eritrean special which was chicken with mushrooms and onions which was also rather spicy, but mouth-watering nonetheless.  

They also make mean cup of coffee, to be honest, it's better than anything i've gotten at the countless coffee houses on Irving.  Plus as soon as you sit down, a full, corked, bottle of water appears in front of you, a nice classy touch.  They also have a fine assortment of draft beers and a full bar.  

The waiters were both extremely friendly and talkative, engaging my boyfriend in the level of spiciness that he could handle, they decided the mild would be the safest bet, and it was.  They were also helpful in directing us towards popular dishes - which was more important than you might imagine considering how clueless we were.  

We've decided that its our new favorite place, and we highly recommend it.
author: Lianna W.

description: First time trying Eritrean food. It was good! Reminded me a little of Indian food. Chicken and lamb were tasty as were the veggie dishes. I feel like the place was kind of a dive, but I was told by my friend that there are better places that are divey-er than this one. I'm not a huge fan now, but I still have more Eritrean places to try.
author: Alex M.

description: My husband and I have been here a handful of times now, and we always enjoy the food. We always grab a vegan mixed platter for two, and there is more than enough food to share. The selection is pretty typical for Ethiopian food, and is never too spicy to enjoy. My only complaint is that the injera is not nearly as flavorful as other places I have tried. I'm a big fan of the super vinegary taste of most injera I've had, and this place leaves more to be desired.  The best part about this place, though, is that they label their veggie selection as vegan. That alone will keep me coming back.
author: Marie D.

description:
Pros: Delicious Eritrean food, delightful service, friendly and comfortable atmosphere, a neighborhood joint, reasonably priced.

Cons: No bells and whistles - just delicious Eritrean food.
author: Jacob M.

description:
Make sure your hands are clean before you eat because at New Eritrea, you'll notice that the tables are without silverware! I've wanted to try this place, but was always put off because every time I passed by, it's been dark and empty.

I decided not to judge a book by it's cover and went in. I went on a weekday around 6:30ish and there were 2 other couples. Everything on the menu looked good and I ordered a beef and vegetarian dish. When the food came out, the dishes were presented on this huge pizza-looking pan, atop New Eritrea's injera. The injera was soft and spongy and eating with your hands brought me back to my childhood days.

Price was pretty reasonable as well.
author: Janel Y.

description:
This place and I have a long history, yes we do.  In fact, this is probably the first restaurant I ever remember being taken to when I was just a wee little kid and my mom was a hot MILF working at UCSF.  I remember being super excited to be actually encouraged to eat food with my hands, even if I didn't really have a conception back then that different cuisines were supposed to be eaten with different eating utensils (or lack thereof).   

Yesterday, I revisited New Eritrea.  I must say that the me now, and the me 15 years ago have to agree regarding this place.  The food is still delicious, and eating things with our hands is still exciting.  I ordered the Kilwa Begee, which was lamb covered in a delicious gravy/curry that was pleasantly spicy.  On the same piece of injera (bread/pancake) was also some sort of spinach side dish, that was similarly tasty.  My companions, who had never had Ethiopian food before, were similarly pleased.  Ian H ordered Kitffo, which I proceeded to steal pieces of.  I can certify that it tastes good.  Lily T, who claimed she was not hungry when we got here, changed her mind the moment her food came, rapidly devouring everything.  She ordered the meat combo, but asked for a side of Okra, which was gladly given by our super nice waitress.  Unfortunately, she was not able to enjoy all of it as I kept stealing it hang grab by hand grab.  Okra is generally one of my favorite vegetables, and this place certainly reinforced this feeling. 

So in conclusion, New Eritrea, I'll definitely come back.  And this time, I won't wait 15 years!!!
author: Leon K.

description:
So very tasty; as previous Yelpers have stated, the flatbread is quite tasty! It reminds me of a pancake or a crepe, but not as sweet. Eating with my hands was super fun; I want to do that more at other restaurants, although I guess then I'd get people staring at me, haha.

My walking buddy and I tried the Vegetarian Combo and the Gored Gored (rare beef tenderloin tips). Spice level was just right; everything was just very delicious. Will be coming back to this place in the future.
author: Helene K.

description:
The food is great.The staff is also friendly and helpful. They are just really slow. So when u go here make sure you are not in a hurry. Also be prepared to eat with your hand ... I am used to eating my hands .. and i tell you there is nothing like it. 

I think this place great. Try their honey wine only if you like sweet wine. Its good but its sweet. I will have to go back here to try some more
author: Amlan S.

description:
Loved it!  

It's so rare that my friends want to eat Eritrean or Ethiopian food, so I was super excited when a friend wanted to have a small birthday dinner at New Eritrea Restaurant and Bar.

New Eritrea has a great, homey atmosphere.  The long bar is good for eating alone, waiting for friends to arrive, or just to have an Ethiopian beer or honey wine.  The casual, dim lighting is also relaxing as well.  

We also enjoyed the service - didn't rush us, casual, and pretty attentive.  

Foodwise - I could not stop eating the beef on the meat combo or the lentils on the veggie platter.  We also ordered the shrimp, which was saucy and spicy.  

Looking forward to coming here again - and branching out to try other dishes not on the veggie or meat combo platters.
author: kim n.

description:
I'm used to Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurants having minimal decor.  But usually the table and chairs don't rock back and forth constantly.. . 

Slow sercive, tough to get water refils, and kinda bland flavors. . .

I'll go elswhere next time.
author: Sarah L.

description: I really liked this place.  Been here a couple times.  Great, tasty food.  Nice atmosphere.  good honey wine.  I'll go back.
author: Darren H.

description:
The food was good there, but nothing outstanding. We got the veggie plate for 2 and sampled all of the different veggies. Check out the split pea dish and the okra. They were good. I also had a meat sambusa (?) which was good. Maybe I should have gotten a meat dish to round things out. 

I don't dissuade anyone from eating here if they can find parking, but it took us 20 minutes of driving around before we finally found something.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
ok, i rarely leave negative reviews but i just had to here.

maybe i've been spoiled by the ethiopian food at zeni (saratoga) and queen of sheba (when it was open in santa clara), but i was not impressed. not only not impressed, but not satisfied.

injera. it was thin and dry (not spongey as it should be). who messes up injera?? the basic thing to the cuisine.

the beef was ok.
luckily, the spices of the vegetarian dishes were good.

maybe if you never been to good ethiopian/eriteran restaurants, then this place would seem decent to you. but coming from a person who loves this type of cuisine..this place was ok.
author: Vanae W.

description:
So... I'm a total eritrean food n00b; based on what little ethiopian food I've had before, I was really expecting not to like New Eritrea (but my boyfriend dragged me there).  We had #8 (chicken, onion, tomatos), which was good, but nothing really special and #11(beef tartar) which was really really good, particularly with the yogurt sauce. Steamed milk with honey is tasty, but about what you would expect.  We didn't like the honey wine, but my boyfriend liked what the ads touted as Eritrean King of Beers (honestly though, Eritrea didn't exist until 1987, so how much competition could there possibly be for the title?).  

Service staff was super nice. Decor is not fancy, although it sort of has a quirky appeal.  I found the fact that we were basically eating atop of some sort of animal hide (pressed underneath the table glass) somewhat amusing, vegetarians might not be so amused.
author: Jan C.

description:
I've eaten at practically all the Eritrean and Ethiopian restaurants in the City, and this one is by far the best. 

The food is spicy, savory, and absolutely delicious. 

Unlike other "ethnic" cuisines that I kind of get sick of (read Indian/ Pakistani, various other Asian (Thai, Chinese), etc.) and never want to see again, I eat here at least once a week. I've been coming to this restaurant for years, and it's consistently fabulous.

I highly recommend this place.
author: Akasha A.

description:
Eritrean/Ethiopian cuisine is unfamiliar to me but New Eritrea has made me a fan.  My friends and I came here last night to feed before the Killers concert and we left very happily sated to dance our pants off.

We ordered the meat (chicken, beef and lamb) and vegetarian (potatoes, lentils and collard greens) samplers, along with the okra and the steak tartare dish (shockingly buttery).  This feast arrived on a large platter with some salad, yogurt and a spicy pepper mix.  We each then received a  spongy crepelike bread that we tore off in pieces to manhandle the food.  And manhandle we did.  How could we not?  The food was perfectly spiced, comforting, and just really delicious.

Oh, er, to help the digestion, we had a bottle of the Tej honey wine.  It seemed too sweet when we first drank it without food, but then when the food came, it really was the perfect pairing of sweet and savory.

Thanks to the owner/manager/waiter who was swamped with a packed house (good business).  We were hurrying him along so that we wouldn't be late for the concert and he was very patient and accommodating.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
Me & hubby already had our dinner today but we're still craving for something that's not too heavy . Then we got a parking right in front of this restaurant & luckily we stepped in without thinking twice.

The restaurant had a delightful ambiance, I also love the music they played.
We got Kilwa Dorho (boneless chicken sauteed with special spices), liked it so much. 
Service was great, the owner was so friendly. He got such a cute & pretty little daughter =)

Would definitely be back here anytime soon to get the fish, & shrimp (^_^)
author: Natalie S.

description: come for the friendly faces, leave w/ imminent diarrhea... also use their bathroom pre-meal to complete the authentic experience (read: dysentery).
author: Stephan T.

description:
The plain white front hid inside quite a nice bar and lovely designed interiors.  It has a very nice and welcoming ambiance.  The staff was friendly and quite helpful.  Who knew the restaurant has been here since around 1999?!  I would definitely come back to dine with friends who like places that have atmosphere that aren't dives or cafeteria-like.  They also have a pretty interesting and wide selection of drink - even beer imported from Eritrea.  

As for the food: the Kilwa Begee, a spicey lamb dish and the marinated chicken drumsticks Zebhi Dorho are my two favorites.   I do think their meat dishes far excel over their weaker vegetarian ones that somehow lack the flavor or end up too spicy for my tastes.  Also, when I had their vegetarian potato dish, again the potatoes were undercooked and crunchy just like at Axums.  I do like their appetizers of sambusas. 

I do think the restaurant has been overlooked but I also think they can do with improving their vegetarian items.  They do well with their meat dishes.  I am giving it 3.5 stars
author: Animal K.

description:
Good food, friendly service. Ethiopian/Eritrean food has been fairly similar  everywhere I've gone. That honey wine though, I did not enjoy it!
This place is good and easy if you want some basic Ethiopian food - however, I like Club Waziema's (on Divisadero) food a bit better, but the service here was way superior
author: Madeline S.

description: I love the restaurant! The waiter is super cool & nice. He comes by and ask if me and my friends are okay and if we need more bread. He also talked to us. Great costumer service and yummy food.
author: Cindy C.

description: This is a real gem. Genuine Eritrean fare, friendy staff and a comfortable environment. Yes, there is a big bar - thre detritus of some long dead sports bar is my guess - but I've seen one customer seated at it and him with a beer. You owe it to yourself if you are looking for new tastes to give this a try the #7 and #9 are very tasty and the vegetarian fare is outstanding too.
author: Jim U.

description: I love Ethiopian food and New Eritrea is so yummy. I highly recommend the lamb, fish, and kitfo. I crave New Eritrea and I end up here about once every two weeks.
author: tina p.

description: Friendly service and excellent spicey seafood selections make this restaurant unique.  The honey wine and injeera are great as well.  Darker lighting and improved ambience/art would enhance the total experience.
author: Neil F.

description: Disclaimer: I don't like Eithiopian or Eritrean food due to the sour mushiness.  This place was pretty good as that type of cuisine goes. There's some weird, interesting, but not good drinks on the menu. The fish was the best mush of all.
author: Joseph C.

description: Best Ethiopian place in town. So many vegan options, so flavorful. My carnivorous friends order vegan here and love it.
author: Jena H.

description:
I love the glass ceiling in the back of the restaurant.  What a great place to sit down on a beautiful day and eat some delicious Ethiopian / Eritrean / East African food.

Also, they have some really funny little signs in the hallway to the bathroom, with little slogans like, "New Eritrea Restaurant.  It's in the sunset, which is far away, like Africa."
author: Joshua E.

description:
My girlfriend decided to choose this spot as something new for the day.. we did eat at Asaab on Geary so there is something we could compare to...

Upon walking in, the place reminded me of a bar that has just been converted to an Eritrean restaurant..nonetheless we were seated and took a look at the menu. I'm familiar with samusas so we ordered the meat one and was surprised that 2 3x3 samusas were given for $3.75 i believe... [i thought thered be like 4 or something]. I do admit though that the samusas were good.

Anywhoo, my girl decided to get the meat variety [$11] where as I got the boneless lamb. Our plate arrived and there was a lot on that one piece of that spongy slightly sour tortilla-like bread.

We're newbies so I had no shame of asking for forks just in case but we did get a hang of eating it with just our hands.. but about the taste, it was well rounded... there was enough spices and flavor to make you keep eating so I was truly satisfied. 

Eritrean food is not for everyone.. the taste of the bread alone can either pull you to eat more or just pass.. but those looking to try it, I recommend this place for sure.

I'm coming back to try something different and definitely smaller [that variety plate was friggin too huge for one person!]
author: JJ C.

description:
I was very happy with this place, especially since I was told there is no good Ethiopian food in SF.  So yeah, I know Eritrea is not Ethiopia (any more), but the cuisines are very similar.
I went here with a few friends, all who were incredibly hungry. The food came very quick, and I don't think anything on the platter was not tasty.  We got the gored gored beef (raw) which was spot on delish.  The new Eritrean special chicken was also very tasty.  besides that we got the meat variety plate and the veggies all plate.  now i saw plate, but really it's all one giant platter with the food served on their injera in their own spots.  
The injera (sort of like a spongy naan or a softer dosa or not really like either of those just go try it) here was fantastic.  I've been to many places where the food is good but bad injera has ruined the meal.  

The steamed milk with honey was very tasty (so i heard i didn't get it) and the coffee was perfect.

I'd gladly go back here again and again.  in fact I'm already planning another outing here.
author: Andrew r.

description: This is a difficult review to write. The restaurant  itself is gorgeous.... particularly their full bar. And the service is fantastic. But this was my first experience with trying Ethiopian food. And it was not for me, nor my two friends who joined me. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't bad....but it was a little boring and $$$). I was also not a fan of the flat, rubbery, sourdough-like bread they accompanies the dishes instead of silverware. So If you're into Ethiopian food then you're all set because this place is wonderful. And I gave them 4 stars just for that. But as for Ethiopian food, I think I've had all I will ever need after this visit. I may go back just to enjoy the scenery and their happy hour though, It was a lot of fun trying a couple varieties of their hard-to-find Ethiopian beer.
author: Katie S.

description:
New Eritrea Restaurant is an experience. The food is delicious and offers people a unique and exotic cuisine that is out of the ordinary for everyday Americans. 

If you are looking for a new adventure in dinning give Ethiopian food a try. You will be delighted by the use of spices and the array of flavors.

Meter parking is available. Yet Irving Street is very busy and since New Eritrea is near 9th Ave and Irving, finding a parking space at peak hours, especially on a Friday or Saturday night is not easy. See web link for other reviews...

http://www.fudcourt.com/neweritrea.html
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Wonderful!  Nice family feel good home food.
My folks are from East Africa and are really impressed with the way they cook the meat here.
It also has a nice 50's cuba style bar, feels like your in a James Bond movie.
author: Ruby s.

description: my friend and i came here to try out something different. i think food here is good, ethiopian food somehow reminds me of indian food except without the crazy spices. i had a lamb and meat and a vegetarian dish. that was more than enough for 2 people, we ending up taking it home. i forgot what the meat dish is called that we ordered, the mild was already spicy so if your going to order a meat dish and if they ask for how spicy u want it, i think mild is a perfect spice. the lamb could have been cooked better though i think, it had the after taste, when lamb is prepared properly it doesn't have a strong after taste but other than that it was good. and you have to try the honey wine, it has an interesting flavor profile. if you wanna try something different, try this place out!
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
Came here with a friend couple weeks ago. First time I've heard about this place and my first time trying Ethiopian food. Ordered their meat combo dish which was pretty good, but the meat with the red sauce was a bit too spicy for me.

Overall, the atmosphere was good and the waiter was nice and friendly.
author: A R.

description:
For those who have never had Eritrean cuisine, try it first at New Eritrea.  For those who don't know, the food (usually some meat) is served with sides on top of a spongy bread similar in taste to sourdough but it's flat like a thick crape.  You don't eat with utensils, but you tear off the bread and us it to scoop up the food.

The portions are large and spicy (but not overwhelming) and it really is a feast to remember.  It's best if you come with a group and order different dishes to share.  I've had various dishes and liked them all.

Since it's rather unassuming from the outside (some people might think it's a dive or a "whole in the wall"), it has a quaint charm to it.  I've never seen it crowded which means service is prompt.  If you are tired of cheeseburgers, tacos, and other standard, American fare than give this one a try since it really won't be too far outside your comfort zone.
author: Brent V.

description:
This is probably one of my 3 favorite restaurants in SF. We use to live within walking distance.  I've gone there as: a pregnant & hungry customer;  as a customer bringing extended family; and now as a customer with a toddler.  They have great staff who I recognize when I walk in.  You never have to wait in line, like you do at similar restaurants in the Mission. It's casual and clean.  

The food will knock your socks off (and the African beers, too). Plus, eating with sour pancakes in your hands makes sampling new things easier.  The flavors are so unique. I am a picky  vegetable eater, and probably would never try collard greens or okra.....but they cook them in such amazing sauces.   You'd think you were eating something sinful!
author: Miss A.

description:
i've had better ethiopian in San Jose before. 

this place is not bad, everything tastes fine, but it was not in anyway superb. i felt that everything was super oily, really too much so. 

i liked the environment and the staff. the price was fine. 

just overall not too impressed by it.
author: Danielle A.

description: We ordered the meat sampler for two and a bottle of honey wine. While the food was decent (good portion for the two of us), I was somewhat concerned with the wine. The cork showed no sign of having been pushed in or pulled out of the bottle and the taste of the wine wasn't very flavourful.
