I'm somewhat suspicious they simply reuse the bottles with cheaper wines and place a cork on top for appearances.
author: Justin B.

description:
I used to live two blocks from Axum which turned me on to Ethiopian.  One night we ventured out to New Eritrea and have a very hard time going anywhere else.  Which says something considering you better have good parking Karma for the inner sunset.

Anyway, the service is top notch, the food is great.  We typically get a vegi and meat combo.  A couple of times we have gotten other things on the menu and they have been even better than the combo items.

Also their selection of Ethiopian beer and wine plus the full bar really put this place over the top.
author: Aberdo G.

description:
I had no idea what kind of food to expect when I walked in for dinner (I've never had Ethiopian before), but always game for something new and with prices you can't resist, I walked in.

The menu had much to offer with a variety of meat and vegetarian/vegan (all of the non-meat options are vegan) options and when the food was delivered I was happily surprised by the large dish both my food and my dinner date's was jointly served on.  I had some sort of garlic/potatoe dish and my date had the spicey spicey beef.  I was pleased with my dish, though my companion said his could have been more spicey.  

Great meal, great service, and we got out of there for just over $20!
author: Veronica B.

description:
This was my first African food experience. While I wasn't blown away, it was certainly good enough for me to come back and try again. They seemed set up to handle large parties well and would like to head back with a group  and then have a couple drinks the bar. 

This would also allow for sampling of a bit more of the selections to see if there was more variety in terms of flavor. We tried both the chicken and beef and one sauce kinda seemed like a spicier version of the other. Then again i could pretty much say the same for Chinese or Mexican.

Overall, pretty good food, but not as much variety as Moroccan places I've been and you get to eat with your hands there too.  Also it might be nice if they gave you cloth towels to wipe your hands with during the meal. I have been to restaurants where they did this and it made the whole process a lot less messy. (i'm a slob though, so that's just a personal request :-)
author: Adam G.

description: Great food. I was blown away at how friendly and kind the staff was. They were so helpful and made you feel genuinely welcome in their restaurant. The wine is great too! Definitely would recommend this place if you're in the mood for Ethiopian food!
author: Ashley M.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with this spot. My friend's family owns it and treated us to a wonderful evening here. The only thing I can't handle is the honey wine...just a little too strong for this gal. I will say that even as vegetarian I had a great meal. 

I highly recommend a visit to New Eritrea. Even if you aren't up for dinner, you can have a drink at their large bar. The atmosphere here is great and would be a nice place to take a date. The low reddish lighting is flattering :-) 

Enjoy!
author: Louis C.

description:
I take all of my out-of-town guests here at least once during their stay because the food here makes me "THE BEST HOST."  The service has always been friendly, although not always the quickest...but you step into a different and more relaxed mindset when you step foot here (e.g., there's usually one waiter who serves all the guests).

The food is OUTSTANDING.  I usually order the mixed plate meal for one, for about $11.  Although the menu offers only an all vegetarian or all meat mix, you can request the waiter to mix it up and put both in.  The food of course comes out on that warm and inviting sticky flat bread.  Make sure you try the warm milk with honey at least once!

As with most SF restaurants, parking in this residential/commercial neighborhood will be slightly a hassle....so plan accordingly.  There's usually no line so you can be seated quickly.
author: The Puppydawg ..

description: Randomly walked in when all the other restaurants down the street were closed...boy was I pleasantly surprised. I shared the Lamb curry dish with a friend and it was delish. I loved the flat bread!!! I seriously soaked up every last drop of curry on the plate.
author: Lyna N.

description: All the food is amazing!!! Friendly and prompt service. The stout beer is so smooth and sweet! I've tried other Eritrean/Ethiopian places and they were good, but this is my favorite.
author: Kerry H.

description:
I like checking out original places and exploring the unknown so I was really looking forward to go there, as I've never tried Eritrean cuisine.
I don't regret going there but I don't think I'll be coming back.
The decor wasn't bad but nothing special either. The waitress was very nice, not very efficient but it's OK - it's not a fast food :)
The food was fine, but not great.
We had vegetable sambusa as an appetizer and it was fried in deep oil, so not something I like.
For entree I had meat combination - I liked beef the best, my wife had veggie combination (actually we shared as it all came on a one huge plate which was cool) and the green thing (tasted a little like cabbage) was the best, other dishes from veggie mix were way to watery. 
The injera was sour as other posters have noted but I asked a friend from Etiopia and he said that's the way it should be.
I was also a little disappointed that they didn't have any original desserts. 
Also the toilets are a little obscure...
author: dgdh h.

description:
One of the best Eritrean/Ethiopian restaurants I have been to. 

The serving was ample to satisfy two hungry guys. The service was fast.

The food we've ordered was an exotically spicy combination of  vegetables - spinach and okra; and a succulent lamb stew. For the portions we got, including beverage -     the price was reasonable.  I am a stingy diner but when I get a sumptuous meal, I totally forget about my stinginess :-)

They have a good list of vegetable cuisine for vegetarians. 

For first time-diners, you eat with your  hands, using pieces of "injera" to pick up bites of entrées and side dishes.

I'm sad to hear about Sandra R's experience. Our palate sometimes needs to discover and appreciate the savor of international cuisines. And I would say that Ethiopian cuisine is a good example to diversify our palate and at the same time have that good sense of "family and friendship" in the dining table as you share the food from a common plate.
author: Mark Anthony M.

description: Giving this 3 stars, because while it was good, it really wasn't anything too great.  My wife ordered the kitfo raw, which was still cooked a little bit, and i ordered the vegetarian sampler.  The sampler came with a spinach tomato dish that tasted almost italian honestly, like a spinach pasta sauce.  The other parts of the sampler (yellow lentils, red lentils, and potato dishes) were good, but nothing terribly speical.  The yellow lentils were the best out of the bunch though.
author: Phil J.

description:
So i came here with an ex-boyfriend trying to make my self believe that I could handle doing the whole "friend" thing this early on. I thought eating with our hand would make it easier, I instantly orders a glass of Jamison on the rocks which startled that water at first but he knew well enough to keep them coming. Its not a full bar but its enough to keep an awkward girl happy. 
So the diner went fine, the waiter gave us a shot on the house and I could not stop eating the food. It was amazing. I recommend the dinner plate for two. Its more than enough food and its only about $22
author: Natalie S.

description: the pain I go through misjudging my limit on injera is more than offset by the tasty meats and veggie dishes brought out on the enormous family style platters.  I was just there last night with out of town guests.  It had been at least a year since my last visit and I was not disappointed.  appetizers are portioned right - as appetizers should be.  we had 6 items for 4 people and that was too much food.  I've never bothered with dessert here.  there's never any room.  my one complaint is the veggie dishes are (probably traditionally) prepared as mush.  I like them and all, but wouldn't mind some whole chickpeas with my chickpea concoction.
author: Jeremy B.

description: While I am not an East African foodie, I enjoyed my dinner here. The service was quick and reliable, the food was what it was advertised (meaning, when we ordered something spicy, it actually was). I am not familiar enough with EA food to know the all the nuances, but the menu seemed very similar to most of the Ethiopian restaurants that I have eaten at. That comparison in mind, the food here was pretty good.
author: Glen C.

description: Not terrible but nothing to write home about either. I had the vegetarian combo dinner. It comes with 4 items and tiff bread. Very small portions and the tif was white instead of the normal wheat. Will not be going back.
author: Peter F.

description: I jokingly made a comment to my friends about this restaurant being upscale in appearance but the mannerisms in which we ate the food here was "primitive". Dining at this Ethiopian establishment was definitely a unique, strange but fun experience, never having been forced (encouraged) to grab foods normally eaten with a proper utensil by hand with the injera flat bread. The entrees we ordered--their #7 kilwa dorho (chicken), #9 kilwa begee (lamb) and #13 kitffo (beef)--were not finger foods! My tongue's pain receptors were constantly being bombarded by the spices from the entrees and the vegetable and lentil sambusa appetizers. Portions were plentiful for three guys and the food was delicious, with overall taste similar to Indian food.
author: Cliff W.

description:
A big thanks to Matthew S. for suggesting this place :D


Make sure the people you eat with are clean and wash their hands! This goes out especially to those nasty ass guys who never wash their hands after holding their ding dongs when they pee. Serious. It's all about the clean jazz hands at this dining establishment...



There were 8 fabulous yelpers at dinner that night and while waiting for the whole party to show up, we started off with the meat something or other appetizers.  Ah yes, the fresh Eritrean hot pockets, as I shamelessly like to call them. Crunchy meat filled goodness.  Matthew S. suggested we begin the Friday night festivities with their honey wine.  A sweet sweet nectar.  Just the way I like it.  But I was also craving a stronger drink and Keane and I found our way to the bar and ordered a Kettel One and soda, to which the bartender/waiter replied, 'Oh I've never heard of that combination before'. 'Oh really, hmmm, that's strange. Well, I guess you learn something new everyday.' I started wandering off to look at pictures while he continued to make our drinks, and when I turned back around I saw him pouring Kahlua into two glasses! 'Oh No! I'm sorry, I said Kettel One, the vodka, and soda.'  He started laughing and said, 'Oh hahahhaa no wonder I thought it was such a strange drink!'  He then prepared the drinks the proper way but gave us the Kahlua and soda anyhoo - which turned out to be good! Tasted like a bubbly chocolate milk drink!

And then came time for us to order our entrees.  At first we weren't quite sure how to go about  ordering our meals.  Being major carnivores, we decided to get the meat combination platter and threw in a vegetarian dish just to mix things up. Ah yes. Meat. Meat meat meat. I very much enjoyed the beef dish, as it reminded me of my mother's home-cooked meals. No, she's not Eritrean, but I guess her cooking is? The chicken, well at least the sauce, was excellent! I don't think I ever got to really try the chicken because unfortunately I was sitting on the boys side of the table and the gobbled everything up. Bastards. The third type of meat was lamb, which I could care less about.  And the vegetable was a sauteed spinach mixed up in some flavorful sauce. I'm still craving that. Mmmmmm...

Oh and a big big plus - the waiters are always smiling and are so friendly!  Part of the eating experience is the emotional connection and smiles always make me happy!

Hurrah!
author: Aim E.

description: I am going 5 stars with New Eritrea.  I loved the food.  I loved the service.  My mouth waters every time I start to think about that combination plate.  I would really suggest this restaurant to anyone who loves food and doesn't mind eating with their fingers.  And really, if you mind, get over it.
author: Hayley W.

description: I came here on a Thursday night and it was frikking empty, and the emptiness combined with never having tried Eritrean food was a bit daunting. We got the vegetable sambusa which would have been good if it hadn't been oozing oil down my hand with each bite. After getting fed up with the noxious drip I held it over my plate and gave it a good squeezin'. We read that the chicken drumsticks were the best so we ordered that. I'm not sure if it was just cause I'm an Eritrean food noob or if the kitchen was having an off night, but the injera was painfully sour. There's a different between pleasantly tart and overwhelmingly vinegary.  At first I thought, "Hm, maybe they seasoned the chicken with vinegar." I tried the chicken alone, and it was delicious. I tried the chicken with injera, and all I could taste was sour. I found myself wishing for some good ol' naan bread to eat with instead.
author: Skye L.

description:
I had the meat combination with tea.

Atmosphere: around dinner time, it was a bit empty, but a few people staggered in later
Price: The prices were moderate and the portions were moderate as well.
Location: Its in a nice location...it was not hard finding parking and the meter limit is 1 hour...definitely enough time.
Overall: 4 stars...I would definitely dine here again.
author: Rose S.

description: This is a great place for a casual dinner with friends. The food is Eritrean, and not particularly any different from any other Eritrean restaurant. After a week of waiting in line for tables at various other restaurants, the no-wait dinner was quite refreshing. The beef tartare is the best dish we had. I also tried Eritrean wine for the first time, which is fruity and sweet.
author: Ellie P.

description:
my friend tony says that eritrean cuisine is indian food for decadent people who think there's a difference between eritrean and indian food.  i'm indian, and damn straight there's a difference!!!  however, i can't tell the difference between eritrean and ethiopian....

anyway, most of the fare consists of curried meat dishes (with a mix of middle easter/indian type spices) all served family style on a spongy flat bread (which, in my opinion, is what the meal is all about!).  last time i was here, i had some ground steak tartare in spicy curry with yoghurt sauce (which i highly recommend)....  i've also had the sampler meat platter that has a mix of chicken, beef, and lamb dishes.

i'm surprised new eritrea doesn't get more patronage (it's almost always empty although the staff is very nice and service is great).  the decor is sparse but tasteful, but something about the cheap chairs and plastic tables detracts from the ambience.  it appears as though they have a pretty well stocked bar, but i've never actually hit that up.

if you've never had ethiopian before, i'd highly recommend visiting new eritrea (particularly since i prefer it to both the blue nile in berkeley and massawa on haight).
author: Roshni R.

description: fun place to eat, we ordered medium spicy and it was pretty hot.  order mild spice unless you like spicy food.
author: pochini m.

description: Having had Ethiopian food (or Eritrean food) only in Seattle, and not liking it much there, I went here unwillingly.  I really enjoyed my meal, incuding the different sauces, the spongy bread, the eating with the hands.  It was remarkably fun.   Plus I learned about Eritrea!
author: Laurel B.

description: We went after helping a friend move. We were all starving and didn't want to go very far. Someone stated, "I just want a big plate of food." Someone else had been here and remembered that that is exactly what you get : a big plate of food that you eat with your hands, scooped up in a spongey pancake-like bread called Injeera. I had never had Ethiopean food and was sort of skeptical because I remembered my parents chastising me as a child with stories of the starving children in Ethiopia who would be happy to eat my soggy Cheerios. I overcame my fears and was pretty happy with the food here. It was very lentil, pea, and spice heavy and everything was absolutely delicious. I found myself running to the bathroom as soon as I got home but I hear that's normal. I liked it. I'd try Eritrean again.
author: Alyssa S.

description: When you have only a week left in SF, every meal feels like it should be significant.  I am glad one of those meals came from New Eritrea.  We had a spicy beef dish, balanced by a milder lentil dish - the injera was spongy and moist - heaven!  I don't think they have Ethiopian restaurants in Omaha, so this may be our last taste for a while...
author: Holly B.

description: Ethiopian is definitely not what i expect it to be. it's not bad. the spices are definitely spicy and i'm not quite use to the flat bread. it is a bit sour and not a great mix with the spiciness. Eating with ur hands is definitely fun but make sure you wash your hands really well before you touch your face or rub your eyes. the service is great.
author: Lynn P.

description: Do not only do yourself a favor but one for your friends-BRING THEM HERE!!  My best friend and I decided to try this place for the first time lastnight and it was GREAT. The service was good, but the food was outstanding. We had the vegetarian platter and the meat platter...mmmm. We had dinner @ 5:00 p.m and @ 9:00 I was still complaining about how full I was. The atmosphere was pretty cool but I could not be distracted long enough to check it out. Oh ya, we got the meat sambusas to start out...I think I may have dreamed about them lastnight...DELICIOUS!!!
author: LOVIN L.

description: Cozy Ethiopian place with great, yummy food where they make you feel like you're in their home.  Good wine, knowledgeable service, great food made for the American palate.  Would love to go back again with a date or with a friend.  Eating with your hands is fun.  Guessing which meat is which on a plate is a bit of an adventure, but most everything was very tasty.
author: Lauren J.

description: Just thinking about the meat sampler is making me hungry!  I've been here twice and am always impressed with the service and the food.  To be honest, I can't claim to be a judge of Eritrean cuisine, but it reminded me of the Filipino kamayan style of eating with my hands, except substitute the rice with bread.  Prices are reasonable, for two people you can get away with an appetizer and one course...all for less than $20 and a guaranteed full stomach.
author: Mark D.

description: Great food. Good service. Very clean and quiet environment.
author: Lan L.

description: Do yourself a favor and try some Honey Wine. It's a great way to start off here at this quiet, well-decorated Ethiopian restaurant. I've had almost everything on the menu here with no complaints. Highlights include the lentils, mixed vegetables, lamb, and sambusa. That flat bread is amazing, it's fermented and has a slightly sour taste, with a spongy stretchy texture that works really well to eat the entrees with. Try it if you like Indian food and are looking for something new.
author: Steven O.

description:
i've always had a great experience here. not good for take out because the injera gets soggy. they have a full bar and interesting decor. the chix sambusas (appetizers) are delicious. they come with spicy chile that he imports directly from eritrea. it's soooo good! i wish he would sell them as condiments. The beef kilwa and veggie sampler are also delicious. It's perfect amount of food. 

I think Wednesdays are the best. Perhaps its when they make new batches of these scrumptious dishes. Eritrean is a bit on the spicy side but you can ask for mild on some dishes. Go see Manny. We sit at the bar so we can chat with him. He's real nic... and he'll even show you pics of his baby girl and his soccer team back home which consists of all his brothers.
author: Bee F.

description: I love this place.  Good food, super friendly staff, and great prices.  Plus, for some reason it's never crowded.  Maybe they don't do enough marketing but they sure deserve a lot more business than they get.  I'm gonna take my friends there whenever I can from now on.  Enuff said :)
author: Virginia W.

description: Good injera. Good price. Nice atmosphere. Friendly and fast. Not greasy. Yup, would come again.
author: Jeremy W.

description: This was my second time eating Ethiopian food and I'm hooked.  This place had excellent friendly service and the food was yummy.    My friend and I ordered both the meat combination and the vegetarian combination.  I really liked their vegetarian one.  They were both around $12 and had three different items.  Very affordable!  It was also fun eating with my hands.
author: Sara H.

description: It was my boyfriend and my first time to try  Ethiopian food and we both loved this place! The guy explained to us the menu very well and food was great! We both love spicy food so this suited our taste! We had lentil sambusa for appetizer and combination meat and chicken for main entrée. Everything tasted good! The restaurant itself was very clean and staff was friendly and courteous. The only set back is parking. It took us 10 minutes to find parking around the area.
author: Natasha V.

description: I came here for a friend's birthday last week and I had a great time here.  We ordered a bunch of food to share family style, so I'm not totally clear on exactly what was ordered.  We did get a few meat platters as well as a vegetarian platter.  All of the dishes had bold, spicy flavors and were seasoned well.  The injera was nice and light yet satisfying.  The service here was fantastic as the staff was always available, friendly and accommodating, especially for one of my friends who has dietary issues.  The staff was super accommodating and made some nice recommendations with her needs in mind.  This was definitely one of the better Ethiopian places that I've been to, and though it's a little tough for me to get to, I wouldn't mind coming back.
author: Gary L.

description: Eritrean cuisine is okay. It's not something I can have everyday. The food is served over a very very sour cold pancake spongy bread. The spices reminded me of middle eastern and Indian food. I find that the meal can be better if I eat it with nann instead of their bread.
author: Helen L.

description: My husband, our friends and I really liked this place. It has a great ambiance and was a good value for the money. A couple of things on the vegetarian platter were a little bland, and it took awhile to get refills on water, but it was great overall.
author: Ramon E.

description: It was an interesting and fun experience eating here. Love the fact that you eat the food with your bare hands as opposed to using utensils. The flavors were definitely new to me.  The vegetarian platter felt more like an appetizer. For some reason I wasn't sated. But nonetheless, it was good. If you don't like sour food, you may not like the injera that comes with the dish.
author: Kit K.

description: If you don't like African food, you just haven't tried it. Ethiopian/Etitrean food is awesome, and New Eritrea is one of the best. I'd give it 5 stars if you could find a place to park. Try it!
author: Michael K.

description: Just came back, and had a wonderful experience. I have no idea what happened to SANDRA, but my meal was quite satisfying (and filling). Big portions for average price. Definitely going back.
author: Shun T.

description: Delicious flavors, and the Injera was spot on. Not to mention that they don't cut the original teff flour recipe with all purpose flour--an important factor for us gluten free types out there. We ordered a meat dish and a veggie dish. Since they weren't sure if one of us was a veg, they separated the dishes with lettuce, which was above and beyond the call of duty, especially for a food that is served in the spirit of Kubayaness--all together on the one plate. Everybody join hands and sing, now.
author: Sara B.

description: Perhaps my new favorite Ethiopian place in the city. Loved the vegetarian sampler. There were two of us and for $22 it absolutely was enough food. Menu says "hearty" and they were not kidding. Ambiance is OK, but with prices that low, and food that good, I definitely recommend.
author: Jason B.

description:
For those who have never had Ethiopian or East African food, you do get to eat with your hands.  The teffeh bread at New Eritrea is good, but it's hard to screw up.  We had a lamb dish and a chicken dish, both were delicious, and wonderfully spicy.  We also had sambusas (think a flat samosa).  

Service was good, the restaurant looks a lot nicer on the inside than outside.  There is a full bar if you are into that, they also have imported beer.

Definitely a good spot if you enjoy Ethiopian cuisine.
author: John B.

description: I wish there were half stars.  I would give this restraunt 3.5 stars.  My boyfriend and I live in the sunset so this walkable restraunt is perfect when we want to share a bottle of the honey wine with our meal.  We usually share the veggie combo for two.  It's priced around $25.  I like that there are two veggie options for sambusas.  Veggie or lentil.  Don't come here if u're in a rush.  It's a casual environment nothin fancy.
author: Sherri T.

description: I've been coming here for years... GREAT food (veggie combo, veggie sambusa & hot sauce!), and super nice staff.  LOVE IT!!!
author: Elle D.

description: This place was definitely good for a group.  I really enjoyed the food.  Service was not the best. It was fun, pretty good food and cheap.
author: Jaime C.

description:
I'm sorry...

I REALLY wanted to like this place... REALLY badly...

We frequent Cafe Ethiopia and always seem to enjoy the food.  I've eaten at a great place in Berkeley as well and so I had high hopes... 

So... We go in pretty early... Around 5:30 on a Thursday, and we were likely the first table of the day.  

The owner seemed very polite and was quick to give us a nice large cold bottle of water... I thought we were off to a great start...  We order the Veggie Combo and the Meat Combo...  Both of which are supposed to come with a salad.

When the food arrives, there are maybe 9-12 SMALL pieces of lettuce in the middle with a few pieces of tomato... I am assuming that their normal salads are more than 4-6 quarter sized pieces of lettuce, but whatever... I'm more excited about the meat/veggie dishes that are on the plate, than I am concerned that we got shafted in the salad category....

So I start with a veggie one... It's less than luke warm... I move on to the next...  hardly luke warm... the next one has COLD spots... COLD SPOTS.... It was luke warm where it wasn't cold...  And all of the others followed the same suit.... Except for one...

The lamb dish tasted like it was fresh, and had some VERY good flavors... It was in fact excellent...   

Now... I can accept if a dish is supposed to be room temp... but... this was as if the food was all heated up in the microwave, but just not long enough...  It could have been heated in a pan, but I have enough experience as a cook to know without question that 5/7 dishes we had were in a refrigerator less than 10 minutes prior to hitting our table...  

We didn't wait for the check, we did the quick math to come to $23.50 for the meal, and handed an even $30 to the owner as we walked out the door (he was also our server)...  He asked if we were in a hurry, and we replied that the food tasted like it had been microwaved, but not enough, and that it was for the most part, totally inedible... He seemed genuinely hurt by the fact that we had had such a terrible experience, but at no point did he say, "that's impossible, we don't own a microwave" or "all of our dishes are prepared fresh" or anything.... just more like... "$h*t... I really hope you don't tell people about this... and I'm about to go kill the cook..."  He did offer to give us our $ back, but I didn't see that as necessary... He has costs to maintain, and me having an extra $30 in my pocket doesn't change anything for me...   Having hot food, or at least tolerably warm food does...  They failed...  It looks like the other reviews are pretty positive... but in my mind, a slip like this is simply unexcusable. 

Sorry man....
author: Will W.

description: I really love going here.  The owner is so friendly and welcomes our two children whenever we arrive.  Great suggestions for kid friendly food and leaves out all spice to accomodate them.  I personally like it hot hot hot and the mushroom dish is to die for.  This is a family favorite for sure!
author: Maegan F.

description: This place rocks! I always go with the server's suggestion and he makes great suggestions every single time I'm there with a friend or a group of friends. I LOVE THEIR HONEY WINE! Just be prepared to eat with your hands as there are no utensils. I give them four stars for food and service, but man the waiters are HOT!! They get 10 stars for that alone because they are yummy like the food!
author: Maya L.

description: This place is yum.  I was nervous when I walked in and we were the only people there.  But by the time we were 1/2 way through dinner, there were hardly any seats left in the restaurant.  I can see why.  It's quality food and the staff is great.
author: Lanie W.

description: I love this place. The staff is very nice and the food is great. I really like the atmosphere. This was the first time I had Eritrian/Ethiopian food and I havent found better yet. I've noticed that ordering vegitarian dishes is always a better idea. They're more flavorful and have a nicer texture.
author: Max S.

description: The food and service where both excellent. I've never had bad Etheopian food, but this was certainly better than most. Getting a meat combo, and a veggie combo, and splitting between 2~3 people is the perfect meal for me. Prices are about $13 a dish, but the portions are very generous.
author: Lan R.

description: Based on some of the previous reviews, my boyfriend and I tried the vegetarian combo with 6 different veggie choices and a salad.  I have been to several Ethiopian restaurants over the years and I have not been so disappointed in awhile.  The portions were very small for the price - we got only a small scoop of each "dish."  The food was not very warm and we left feeling like this was not good value for the price.  We won't be coming back here.  It's too bad.  Service was fine, just hard to understand why they are so skimpy with portions.
author: Mary D.

description: New Eritrea Restaurant you get the distinction of being the best ethiopean restaurant in the SF! congratulations! you're not the best in the bay area but don't worry, your sambusas can't be beat, if you don't have a car or a bike, or otherwise can't be bothered to make it to cafe colucci in the east bay, be content that New Eritrea Restaurant exists and you will be ok, its good food.
author: Jared Z.

description: I'm all about getting takeout in my 'hood. At first I thought Eritrean takeout.. umm...that could be kinda messy and difficult to package, but nope! Done expertly and I could eat with my hands in the comfort of my home.
author: Nikke G.

description: Great Ethiopian! Makes me miss the (late) Blue Nile in Berkeley. Pretty reasonable prices here, too. I had a meat combo, girlfriend got vegetarian combo. We both enjoyed our meals. Service is very spot-on. Try the Hakim Stout beer, too.
author: Steve C.

description:
nice homey casual atmosphere!  its always nice to be welcomed by meshgina's & his wife's warm friendly smiles!   i like sitting in the back area when its bright & sunny out as its dark inside the front area.

great eritrean food (compared to axum & massawa) & a great deal !!!!  i usually start off with the:
 
honey wine & veggie sambosa (deep fried appetizer comes with 2) 

& share a large platter (between 2 people) -- the boneless marinated chicken breast (very tasty) & mushrooms (super yummy combo) with a side of injera (soft spongy bread) each.
author: Cindi N.

description: I would like to eat more meals with flatbread as my utensil. If you're not sure what to order, the sampler is probably a good idea. There are loads of vegetarian options and prices are very reasonable for a lot of food (sampler with 3 items was $11).
author: Rachel B.

description: We got the meat sampler (beef, lamb, two chicken drumsticks, plus lentils and a small salad). The beef and the chicken had the best flavor. We also had the sambousa appetizer, it's like a flat and square eggroll with just spiced meat inside and served with some kind of chili paste. And beer: Hakim Stout, which was all right, and the Meta Lager, which had a slightly sweet aftertaste. Nice cozy decor, largish bar, more old San Francisco than Eritrea, I'd imagine. Make sure your hands are clean, as this is finger food.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Just went back last week (I am probably here once every 2 months) and it was absolutely perfect (as always). Best of its kind in the Bay Area by far. I've been dreaming of the lamb in tumeric sauce ever since. Every dish in the veggie combo was delicious; perfectly cooked and seasoned. I adore this restaurant.
author: J T.

description:
first time ever eating eritrean food.
sooooo good.
we had about six different dishes. all delicious.
staff was so friendly.
thank you for making it such a great experience.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
When I walked into the restaurant. There was absolutely no one there at 730 on a Wed eve. I wondered if I had a made a wrong turn....

I decided to accept the invitation to sit int eh back of the restaurant were they have a glass roof allowing for lots of light, even overcast light. The ambiance is simple and relaxing.

I'm glad I washed my hands! I forgot that Ethiopians eat injera with their hands. Not a first date destination =)

I ordered the combo sampler which had collard green, lentil, chick pea, potatoes and lettuce.  To my surprise, I liked the collard green. The potatoes were cut too largely to allow flavor to permeate. Although  the dishes were nicely flavored. They were a bit tame and I needed salt to improve the taste experience. The injera was good. The honey wine was not bad. They do not make it themselves. If you like honey wine, Blue Nile (Berkeley, CA)  has the best honey wine. 

I would certainly come back here if I was craving Ethiopian flavors.
author: J C.

description: The food was decent but nothing to write home about, I had the mushrooms which were alright, the lentils and spinich were decent.  This place is very expensive compared to the other spots I've been.
author: Michele G.

description:
Veggie combo.

Combo has large portion of greens, pureed yellow lentils, potato and carrot, something like red lentils and salad.

The greens were my favorite, excellent flavor - not at all tart, a little spicy and fresh. 

The potato and carrot dish was very similar to the one you get at most Ethiopian/Eritrean places. 

The red lentil like dish was my second favorite, had a much different taste than the other items, also a little spicy but with a nice nutty  flavor. 

The pureed yellow lentils were interesting, I've had a similar lentil dish at other restaurants but it was never pureed. It really brought out a different flavor and was a nice change in texture. 

The salad was fine - I was happy it was not drenched with random french dressing. 

The injera was a little dried out on the edges but other than that was good and the amount was just right.

The service was great, really fast and friendly. The price is very reasonable, they have a full bar and the atmosphere is fine.

This is the best overall Ethiopian/Eritrean place I've been. I don't know how many times I'll be back since my husband said the beef in his kilwa was tough and chewy (he will never get over Cafe Colucci!).
author: Sarah J.

description:
standard minus spice. 

vegetarian dishes were quite bland.
author: andre e.

description: I had never eaten to an Eritrean cuisine before and after eating at New Eritrea, I have to say I'm honestly not a fan. Even though its nothing I would eat everyday however, it was the experience of eating an entirely different type of cuisine that made this restaurant different. The vegetarian dishes were way better than the meat ones, and provided the most interesting flavors.  The way of eating with your hands is wicked cool too.
author: Patrick C.

description: After trying Ethiopian/Eritrean food at Axum, I decided to venture out and try a different restaurant.  For the sake of comparison, I ordered the exact same dishes as I had at Axum.  I was pretty surprised that the food tasted exactly the same.  Exactly.  The only difference was that New Eritrea was slightly more expensive and the pancake bread thing at New Eritrea suited my palate better.  It wasn't as sour as the one at Axum.  So if I had to pick one over the other, I would prefer New Eritrea.  Plus the service is friendlier.
author: Kandi K.

description:
I have been to this restaraunt two times this year already. I have to say that I'm really beginning to consider Eritrean or ethiopian  food another type  of comfort food for me besides Thai and Vietnamese. Its great to eat with your hands and also having a option to use a fork. The server is also friendly.  Every time you go there, he always has a big smile and very welcoming to all of the customers.
I don't remember the names of the food I had but I definately had the chicken drumsticks which the menu said it is one of the popular dishes in the restaurant. I love the spices added into it. I also like how they add a salad on the side too. The bread for me is ok because I'm not much of a sourdough type of person, but I still eat it anyways with the dish I order. That's the only sourdough bread that I will ever eat. 
My friend ordered a fish type dish that he really enjoyed. A perfect place for meat eaters and vegetarians.
I would definately recommend this place for any one wanting to try something new and exciting. If you don't come out of the restaurant feeling full, the good thing is that you're on Irving street. Hopefully you will want to come back for more like me. : )  the music is also great too.
author: Sabrina L.

description: I am by no means a connoisseur of ethiopian/eritrean food, but I enjoyed my recent dinner here.  The service was fast and friendly.  We ordered the meat combination and the veggie combination and I generally enjoyed everything, particularly the Alicha-Ater.  It was also fun to drink ethiopian beer with our dinner.
author: Nicole J.

description: The vegetarian sampler platter was excellent - a  nice way to try a little of everything if this is your first time.  The service was good and the prices were very reasonable.  I'll go back again!
author: christine c.

description: We're always treated like long lost relatives everytime we come here. Its hard to get away from our staples - the okra is delicious and the combination meat plate just melts in your mouth. They give you more then enough bread to finish your meal.
author: Glenn I.

description: Good food. The lamb wasn't too greesy, and the bread stuff (I forgot what it's called) wasn't too yeasty, which is a good thing it was very tasty. I've had ethiopian food before but never "Eritrean" it was just as good, but a little bit better :) After I was done I didn't feel heavy, I just felt full and satisfied.
author: rosie w.

description:
So I'm not an expert on Ethiopian/Eritrean food by any means.  But this place is amaaazing.

I must admit though, the first time I went there we walked out after sitting at our table for 15 minutes and not one server coming over to give us water or take our order.

But they redeemed themselves! because the next time I came it was much better.

So normally we get the vegetarian combo, and it's more than enough food. It's actually always too much, which is okay, because take home an extra order of the injera and you have lunch for the next day.  The server is super nice, I even saw him let someone in after closing once. He must be the owner because he's always there and usually by himself, or at least the few times I've been there.
author: Kelli P.

description: Definitely an interesting dining experience.  Vegetarian portions were rather small for the cost.  My advice is to order the veggie sampler.  As for parking, you can always find parking on Lincoln near the park and walk one block down 10th Ave.
author: Brig M.

description: The food was okay; the service was very friendly, but there are definitely better restaurants for Eritrean food in the city. The BEST is Assab Eritrean on Geary, and parking's generally easier around there too.
author: J K.

description: Very Delicious. A perfect place for vegetarians and vegans who want something different. The spices were just right to provide a savory delight. The waiter was also very helpful and welcoming.
author: James K.

description: When we went here, two small children (one a diner and one a child of the owner or manager) were playing happily around the restaurant while everyone ate and smiled at them... really liked the kid-friendly atmosphere.   The food is good, especially the veggie combo.  A smidge on the pricey side though, I thought.  Great neighborhood place.
author: Dawn N.

description: I shared my first Ethiopian/Eritrean experience here, and it was a good one. I went with the "Meat Combo", since I was inexperienced in ordering, and I was pleased with the combination of flavors. There wasn't necessarily anything wrong with my meal or the restaurant, but nothing really exceeded my expectations. If you're in the Sunset and looking for this style of cuisine, I would give it a shot.
author: Matt D.

description: Awesome. Fabulous. I shared the veggie platter with a friend, and it was so good that I was inspired to learn to cook Ethiopian food. My efforts, alas, fell far short of New Eritrea. This place is damn good.
author: Frank T.

description: Probably one of the better Ethiopian restaurants I have been to.  Not really the biggest fan of Ethiopian food, but this place did a great job of spicing their foods and was priced at a moderate budget level.  My problem is that I always consider Ethiopian to be Indian food without the spices; this place did a bit to change that perspective.  A little bit.
author: Sanjiv B.

description: I got take-out--1 meat combo, 1 veg combo, 1 garden salad.  While better than Axum, still no comparison to the much mourned Sawa,  And if you've ever eaten in DC, you really don't want to bother.   It just didn't have the same spice, kick, degree of flavor that it should.  They get 3 stars for being nice and polite.  In fact, they were friendly.  But they lose points for charging me for the salad they forgot to pack!
author: Lavinia F.

description: This restaurant was very yummy. We ordered a Veg and a Meat sampler and the waiter let us change out one of the offerings for something else, since we knew we didn't like the one offered. Cute decor, good wait staff, fast food. Hot and fresh tasting. Very yummy. Would go back here.
author: wildcat g.

description: Have you ever had ethiopian or eritrean food? If you enjoy trying new exotic cuisines and have not, try this place out right away.  I will agree with Roshni's review: there is NO similarity between indian and eritrean food, except that both use curries to some extent. I'm not sure what the subtle differences are between eritrean and ethiopian, but I do know that Eritrea was colonized by Italy and some of the foods have hints of italian influence.  The staple of the food is a large, flat, spongy bread called injera. You tear off little pieces and use your hands to scoop up bits of tender meats and veggies stewed in a variety of exotic spice-rich sauces based on the main spice which is called berbere.  The place is a bit cavernous inside, adorned with cheesy tourism posters from ethiopia and eritrea and never too crowded. They do have live music sometimes and the honey wine, called Tej, is basically a tasty ethiopian version of manishevitz.
author: Rick H.

description: Great Food.  The servings are ample.  The service is great.  I have gotten take out from here a great deal, but it's also a good place to eat at.  The meats are amazingly marinated.  I recommend it to anyone.  Also, the price is affordable.  The only difficulty is parking, but that's not the fault of the restaurant.
author: Charisse L.

description: I've been here twice and its becoming a favorite. Definitely the best quality Ethiopian food in San Francisco, and a nice dining environment as well. On both visits we got the vegetable combo -- all delicious, especially the collards and the okra. Last night we had three meat dishes, including the New Eritrea Special of chicken and mushrooms. All tasty!
author: Hillary L.

description: Where I always go when I crave Ethiopian / Eritrean.  Not upscale, but the food is the bomb (a line I often put in my reviews -- I guess I like quirky neighborhood dives with great food).  They aren't afraid to make their spicy dishes spicy, they have a really tasty dark beer that I always get (forgot the name, sorry), the prices are low, the portions are big.  The service is always so warm and friendly it makes me want to travel to Eritrea; they seem like wonderful people.  The music is usually sort of African pop-jazz; it's usually good, sometimes bad, always strange.  Don't be expecting a fine dining experience; the decor is cheesy, the table tops are plastic, and it has sort of a seedy feel to it.  But it's genuine and delicious; I just worry they will go out of business because they're not chic enough for SF.  I've eaten at a bunch of other Ethiopian places around the Bay Area, and this is the one I always come back to.
author: Ben H.

description: Great for groups and kids.  Comfortable, clean and attentive service.  Only reason I rate 3 stars is b/c I had amazing eritrean in NY the week before...it just didn't compare.  Anyway, we went w/ a large group and ordered 5 different meat dishes and 2 veggies.  Nothing was bad, but I suppose everything could've been better  Good value though.  I'd like to try Assad, but I'd come back here.
author: Cali G.

description: The food is good, the staff extremely nice, and the atmosphere and background music relaxing. This is everything I want in a good restaurant.
author: Jacqueline G.

description: i've eaten ethiopian food on the west coast.  i've eaten it on the east coast.  i've eaten it in ethiopia.  yet, i've never found the food to be as boring as it tasted here.  i was way underwhelmed.
author: vlad k.

description: i love this place. it is never a disappointment. the food is fresh and the people are a joy and I always feel good and healthy when I leave!
author: Deva G.

description: This place serves delicious food in a very pleasant, friendly, low-key atmosphere. Chicken dish and mushroom dish were amazingly moist and well spiced. Injera is my new addiction!
author: Lydia B.

description:
this is my favorite eritrean/ethiopean place in the city...
i've tried axum, cafe ethiopia, assab, wazeima - but like this the best!

Their chicken+mushroom (or just mushroom alone) is awesome! not a combo you get at other places. In veg, the shiro is delicious, as is the okra. in meat, just about everythign is great!

Also love the fact that they have a full bar - a big plus when you go in a group.

The owner/manager/bar tender is super friendly. service is great!
author: Priya K.

description: Love this place.  There are few items on the menu that are not stellar.  I've brought many family and friends here who always seem to be impressed by the restaurant as well.  The food is often spicy, but it's sooo good too.
author: D Z.

description: Not that I was moved with an overriding desire to seek out Eritrean food, but I was in the mood to explore a new restaurant, so a couple of friends and I decided the New Eritrea Restaurant sounded adventurous.  Although the name "New Eritrea Restaurant" really didn't stand out in my mind as an overwhelmingly unique venue (maybe because I'm not quite sure about the distinction between new Eritrea and old Eritrea, other than Eritrea used to be a part of Ethiopia so maybe that was the "old" Eritrea?), we decided to try it.  We walked into a largely empty restaurant on a Saturday night which usually doesn't bode well, but we ignored the lack of customers, sat down and ordered dinner.  We tried the vegetarian combination platter, the meat combination platter and the Kliwa Begee (lamb strips cooked in an onion and tomato reduction).  The food is served  Ethiopian style on a large platter which everyone shares, family style.  Due to my lack of experience with this food category, I couldn't distinguish the actual difference between Eritrean food and Ethiopian food.  The two lamb dishes (Kliwa Begee and Allicha Bagee) were extremely flavorful and my favorites of the meal.  Overall, the food was very tasty and filling.
author: Matt P.

description: my wife and i love New Eritrea !  nice work with the mitmita in the  kitfo ( my favorite). a wonderful welcoming  family who provide a highly fulfilling &  pleasure inducing experience. great kantisha mushrooms and lamb dishes. skip the combos and get a mixture of  full orders. we always over order so we have plenty to take home.  well stocked bar, special glass top roof area and blue glazed tile bathroom keep things aesthetically agreeable . parking in the sunset is hell so be prepared. excellent value, and worth way more than they charge. a lot of good east african food in the bay area but New Eritrea is consistently and solidly great.
author: Tim L.

description: anyone who hasn't had eritrean food has to try it at some point-- but I wouldn't say this is the greatest place to start.  the atmosphere was cool (dim, kind of vintage/funky decor), but the service was really mediocre.  saturday night, 4 guys on the floor, and, instead of checking in on customers, decided to play it easy and hang out at the bar together.  we ordered a veggie variety platter, and instead of explaining the different (indistiguishable) dishes from one another, our waiter bolted to hang out at the bar until we signaled a runner to come over.  there's a better east african place on haight with friendlier service and equally tasty food.
author: Maggie D.

description: If you enjoy new experiences with your food - you'll LOVE this place! I thought after discovering the Tea Leaf Salad at Mandalay I'd had most everything new and somewhat esoteric in the city. I was wrong. If you've never had Ethiopian food before - I really don't know how to describe the food or the "experience" to you. Hmm...let's start with no silverware (so wash your hands ;-)). Before going, my friend said it's a lot of sauces, meats, veggies, and a very unique flat bread that you dip everything in. That pretty much described it - but doesn't really sell it. Made me think of Indian food. There are definitely some similarities - but honestly, I'd prefer this now. The Samosa-type appetizer we had was good. I loved whatever African beer they'd imported. My friend enjoyed the Honey wine - me? Not so much. But the food was EXCELLENT! And FUN! We had the meat sampler and the veggie sampler but substituted a dish with the okra (it was a TON of food). I thoroughly enjoyed everything in front of us. I've heard there are a few other Ethiopian restaurants around the city - but none live up to New Eritrea. I may have set the bar high, but I'll be back.
author: Eli S.

description: We ordered the vegetarian sampler and a fish dish. The fish dish had a nice berbere sauce with a bit of spice (we ordered it spicy) and the rest of the vegetarian dishes presented a nice variety. All in all a great deal for about $12 per person.
author: Shelley G.

description:
always delicious.  always great service.  i love this place.

try the veggie combo
author: annabel l.

description: This place had excellent service. The food  comes out faster than any other place I've ever ordered. For newbies, they platters that let you taste everything on the menu, but bring a friend to help you eat it! I had the vegan sampler and it was tasty, but not outstanding. The server was one of the friendliest I've encountered in a long time. Although the food was good, it wasn't outstanding.Interesting decor and music too. You'll be transported, whether that's a good thing is up to you to decide!
author: Lisita P.

description: The is the probably, the first restaurant I ate in SF 4 years ago, and I still love it. The food is good, the staff is friendly. They have some ehtiopian beer, which is good too. They have a bar, but doesn't have all drinks. One of my favorite places to eat.
author: Kuldeep T.

description: I LOVE this restaurant. The staff is super friendly and the food is always delicious. This place is super cozy and a great place to take groups.
author: stacy s.
